abstract: for Half a Million Men
snippet: for Half a Million Men
lead_paragraph: An Executive order, published to-day, fixes the long-delayed draft for the 10th of March. It also carries the number for which the drawing will be made from three hundred thousand men, which was the number called for last October, up to Half a Million. Against this number, however, will be credited all who may have enlisted or been drafted prior to the 1st of March and have not been credited to other calls. We have no data regarding the number that is thus to be subtracted from the 500,000, and can, of course, form no precise estimate how many may enlist during the month of grace yet remaining. We are thus left in doubt as to the exact number that will need to be drafted; but as volunteering has been quite brisk and gives promise of being so, a very handsome subtrahend should appear. There is reason to believe that the number needed will not go over three hundred thousand men.

abstract: THE DEATH BANDAGE OF GEN. WALKER. Lieut. SAMUEL H. DRENNON, of this City, who has just returned from Havana, brings with him, hermetically inclosed in glass, the bandage which covered the eye ...
lead_paragraph: THE DEATH BANDAGE OF GEN. WALKER. -- Lieut. SAMUEL H. DRENNON, of this City, who has just returned from Havana, brings with him, hermetically inclosed in glass, the bandage which covered the eye of Gen. WILLIAM WALKER, when he was shot at Truxillo, Honduras. On the glass inclosure is the following inscription: "Remnant of the bandage which encircled the brow of Gen. WILLIAM WALKER, who, having honorably capitulated to NORVELL SALMON, Commander of H.B.M. steamship of war Icarus, was treacherously surrendered to the Honduras authorities, and by them executed on the 12th September, 1860, in the town of Truxillo. Posterity will do justice to their memories. The victim will be deplored while the traitor will be execrated." The bandage is thick with gore, full of bullet holes, and is partially burned -- the file of executioners standing so close that the discharges set fire to it. It was secured by the olderly sergeant of the General, given to WILLIAM FULTON of Havana, and by him forwarded through Lieut. DRENNON to the father of Gen. WALKER, who resides at Nashville, Tennessee.

abstract: Enlisted, Not Liable to Discharge; Bland vs. Adams' Express; Who are Public Enemies?
snippet: Enlisted, Not Liable to Discharge; Bland vs. Adams' Express; Who are Public Enemies?
lead_paragraph: In the case of A. BLAND vs. Adams Express Company, for recovery of $2,279 seized by MORGAN'S band in May, 1862, while being conveyed by said Company from here to Nashville, Judge MUIR, of our Jefferson Circuit Court, decides that said MORGAN and his armed soldiers, though amenable for said seizure to the criminal laws, were "public enemies" in such sense as will exempt the carrier from liability for loss. Plaintiff takes the case to the Court of Appeals.

abstract: Our New-Orleans and Havana correspondence gives the particulars of another revolution at Mat-  amoras. It seems that CORTINAS, a subordinate military Commander, and who was concerned in ...
lead_paragraph: Our New-Orleans and Havana correspondence gives the particulars of another revolution at Mat- amoras. It seems that CORTINAS, a subordinate military Commander, and who was concerned in the revolution which ended in the death of COBOS, has again upset the State Government, and driven Gov. RUIZ into Texas, The Governor of Matamoras now is Gov. SERNA, who held coordinate authority with RUIZ. During the difficulties, Gen. HERRON, commanding our forces at Brownsville, sent three regiments and a battery over the river to protect the American Consul. One regiment marched clear up into the Plaza, stood guard all night, and brought away the Consul and two millions of dollars belonging to Americans.

abstract: SUICIDE OF A SOLDIER. About 7 o'clock on Saturday evening, a man dressed in the uniform of a United States soldier, deliberately walked off the Fulton ferry-boat Union, as she was entering the slip ...
lead_paragraph: SUICIDE OF A SOLDIER. -- About 7 o'clock on Saturday evening, a man dressed in the uniform of a United States soldier, deliberately walked off the Fulton ferry-boat Union, as she was entering the slip on the Brooklyn side. The boat was crowded with passengers at the time, and among them, Mr. WILLIAM H. BRANDES, of Myrtle-avenue, Brooklyn, divesting himself of his heavy clothing, including a Pocket-book containing $56, which he laid upon the deck, jumped into the water, and seizing a life-boat Which had been lowered, succeeded in drawing the drowning man into it. Both were hoisted on deck, and taken to the Franklin House, where the soldier died a few minutes thereafter. His name, from papers found in his possession, was ascertained to be JOHN HINES, a sergeant in the United States service, and stationed on Governor's Island While Mr. BRANDES was bravely endangering his own life to rescue a fellow-being, some miserable thief stole his money. A change of clothing was furnished him by Mr. E. BALDWIN, and he was conveyed to his residence. An inquest was held upon the body of deceased, and a verdict of suicide was rendered by the jury.

abstract: Temper of the Public regarding the War
snippet: Temper of the Public regarding the War
lead_paragraph: In estimating the value of public judgments on a great and complex question, such as the prospects of the war, it is, perhaps, worth while bearing in mind that these judgments are partly controlled by a principle belonging rather to the mind itself than to the circle of facts which enter into the given problem. We mean that remarkable law of oscillation by which any strongly marked tendency of popular opinion is sure in time to be brought round and given a direction diametrically opposite. Of this principle, the present changing, if not changed tone of public sentiment in regard to the war affords a striking illustration. For several months past, and up almost to the present hour, the dominant mood of the public mind has been pitched in the upper keys of confidence and hope. Men read the future all bright. If the rebellion was not absolutely crushed, it must crumble at the grand blow our armies were preparing to deal it in the Spring. Beyond that period few extended their anticipations of active operations in the field; and, as the imagination loves to fasten on special points of prophecy, it was currently accepted that the Fourth of July would see the war at an end.
headline: {'main': 'The Public Temper Regarding the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Public Temper Regarding the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A MILITARY MYSTERY. -- The greatest obscurity continues to hang over the rebel movements and plans, both in East Tennessee and in Georgia. Whatever information the war authorities may have on these subjects they have kept to themselves. We have information of the withdrawal of JOHNSTON's force from Dalton, but where it has gone to is yet an enigma. The one official dispatch says to "Mobile or East Tennessee." What a latitude in that "or!" In the meanwhile, not less doubt surrounds LONGSTREET's intentions and doings before Knoxville. A dispatch published by us, and coining by way of Louisville, would seem to intimate that LONGSTREET has given up his design, whatever it may have been; but it will be observed that the news in this dispatch is several days in arrear of other dispatches of a different tenor. In fact, there has been nothing in the history of the war so tantalizingly obscure as the present movements of the rebels in the West. Of course, under such circumstances, all speculation is vain.

abstract: Shedd, Dr. W. G. T. History of Christian Doctrine
snippet: Shedd, Dr. W. G. T. History of Christian Doctrine
lead_paragraph: In any case, this elaborate work would deserve notice as being the first attempt in English literature to write an account of the gradual Construction of all the doctrines of the Chris- tian religion. That a subject of this nature should so long have awaited a historiographer is remarkable; that it is now satisfactorily filled by an American author is another proof of the energy and vigor with which our scholars are addressing themselves to new fields of inquiry, where the harvest of a virgin soil is to be reaped. How powerful is this tendency a glance at some of the books published within a short time will prove, and our libraries are every day increasing by the presence of original works from native authors, that take immediate rank as standard authorities on their respective subjects. Dr. SHEDD's book is a favorable specimen of this class. It is the result of several years devoted to the study while the author hold the professorship of Ecclesiastical History in the Theological Seminary at Andover, Mass. Rich as English literature is in historical works, it is the history of events that has had the greatest attraction for writers. The history of ideas and opinions -- the main springs of action and precursors of events -- is almost a blank, and waits for illustration from minds of a less practical and more speculative cast than are usually met with among the literati of England. Finding no models existing for his work. Dr. SHEDD was compelled to originate his own method of treatment, so that it is in every respect an original production, and no doubt gains in unity and symmetry from this fact. The plan he adopted is to take up separately each grand doctrine of the orthodox Christian belief by itself, investigating the first beginnings of c[???]tific reflection upon it, and following down to the latest and most developed form of statement that it has received. After an introduction on "Methodoxy," as including the idea and definition of history, and a specification of the system followed in the work, Book I. discusses the "Influence of Philosophical Systems upon the Construction of Christian Doctrine." In it the course of free Philosophic thought is surveyed from the prevalence of Platonism and Aristotlelianism through the Mystics and the Scholastic divines of the Middle Ages to the English and American Theologies of the Nineteenth Century, and the recent Philosophic movements of the German mind, Book II. is a "History of Apologies," and reviews the Defences of Christianity, called forth by the changing circumstances of Pagan, Mediaeval and Modern times. In the succeeding Books -- III., IV., V., VI. -- are considered the cardinal doctrines of Christianity, as "Theology"' proper, or the doctrine of the Divine Existence, in its various manifestations, including "Christology," "Anthropology," or the relations of Man to the Divine," Sotenology," the doctrine of Atonement, Justification. &c., and "Eschalology," the doctrine of final things, the winding up of the great drama of human existence.
headline: {'main': 'NEW PUBLICATIONS.; A HISTORY OF CHRISTIAN DOCTRINE. By WILLIAM G.T. SHEDD. D.D. Two Volumes, Svo. abstract: Thiers, M.; The late Speech of
snippet: Thiers, M.; The late Speech of
lead_paragraph: The late speech of THIERS in the French legislative body sounds almost like a voice from the land of dreams. Twelve years have now elapsed since he was hurried off from that same legislative hall, with a felon's guard, in a felon's van, to a felon's prison, as were two hundred other representatives of the people. Since that memorable night, Parliamentary eloquence has lain dead in France -- buried forever, it seemed, from the hearing of men. There has, indeed, been a so-called legislative body still holding a place in the upper air -- but it has been a mere automaton, without a vestige of personal volition, and used simply to register decrees. It was as impossible for that Assembly to discuss political affairs with free-doom, as for the press itself. But within the last year, the Emperor has been moved by the threatening aspect of liberal opinion throughout Europe, or some other cause, to concede a certain range of utterance; and the Parisian people have shown their appreciation of the privilege by sending to the new Assembly several of their most effective orators. Now, for the first time, under Napoleon III., mind is reinstated in that Parliament hall, with some freedom to use its powers. The world of mind everywhere is watching the effect with keen interest. Can the sheer brute strength which has been controlling France during the last decade stand against the intellectual forces of France once more in free play, even though limited to this parliamentary arena? It used to be taken as an accepted truth that no form of established authority, with whatever number of bayonets at its back, could cope with the combined intellect of the nation in a fair encounter. How is this upstart imperialism in France, which began its career by consolidating the whole talent of France, almost as a unit, against it, to be an exception?
headline: {'main': 'The Speech of M. Thiers.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Speech of M. Thiers.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. MARETZEK'S new season of Italian Opera commences to-night with PETRELLA's popular work,  "Ione." The prospects are more than good they are brilliant.
lead_paragraph: Mr. MARETZEK's new season of Italian Opera commences to-night with PETRELLA's popular work, "Ione." The prospects are more than good -- they are brilliant. It would be hard, indeed, were not such the case. We have not for many years had a better company, and Mr. MARETZEK's repertoire is singularly fresh and admirable. The regular Opera nights have been increased to four each week, with every now and then a supplemental matinee. The numerical strength of the company renders this activity necessary, and the subscribers, we are glad to hear, regard it as desirable. In Boston Mr. MARETZEK played six times a week, and, strange to say, filled the house on every occasion. The "hub" was in a glow of excitement, and hailed with especial favor GOUNOD's "Faust." We presume that this work will be one of Mr. MARETZEK's earliest revivals. It is only now in the first blush of its popularity.

abstract: Hon. E.W. GANTT, of Arkansas, and for two years an officer in the rebel army, will, by invitation of a large number of prominent citizens, speak at Cooper Institute this evening. He some time since abandoned the rebel cause, convinced of its wickedness and folly, and is now one of the most earnest and serviceable advocates of the Union.

abstract: The meeting for the relief of needy soldiers' families, held at the Cooper Institute last evening, was very largely attended. The announcement that Gen. ANDERSON would preside and that Gen. BURNSIDE would speak, was sufficient to fill the house, irrespective of the charitable object of the meeting. The audience, therefore, was considerably disappointed, when, after some delay, it was announced that neither of the distinguished soldiers expected would be present. Subsequently, however, the disappointment was very considerably relieved by the appearance of Gen. BURNSIDE in the absence of Gen. ANDERSON, HORACE WEBSTER, LL.D., presided. On taking the Chair, the Doctor remarked that he hoped the audience would sympathize with him, as it became necessary for him to state that neither Gen. ANDERSON nor Gen. BURNSIDE would be present during the evening. The former was detained by sickness in his family, the latter by official duties.. Before resuming his seat, the sneaker was informed that General BURNSIDE was expected at 8 o'clock. The announcement was received with loud cheers from the audience. At the conclusion of the presiding officer's remarks the Harmonic Glee Club sang a hymn. After prayer by Rev. Mr. BURTIS, and the song, "My Country, 'Tis of Thee," by the Glee Club, Rev. Mr. C. C. Goss, pastor of the Christian Alliance, was introduced. The reverend gentleman stated briefly the objects of the Christian Alliance, which was the means of the meeting being called. The organization had been established with a view to do good everywhere in the most speedy manner. The members of the Christian Alliance were guided by none but the One above. They were to assist men, but not "pauperize" them. They never gave articles, they lent. If those assisted could ever pay, "all right." It not "well and good." The plan, having for its object the relief of poor soldiers and their destitute families was not his own. For several months the members of the Christian Alliance had been brought in contact with soldiers both in camp and City. They knew the necessity of doing something. The Alliance brought to the office of the Medical Director a knowledge of the wants of poor soldiers. There was no society for the relief of discharged soldiers. When a patriot left the army, no matter how great his distress, no funds were provided by the county for his assistance. All relief ceased. [At this point Gen. BURNSIDE made his apperance on the stand, and was received with prolonged applause.] The speaker, noticing the arrival of the General, remarked that our brave men were always in the hearts of the people; some were in Heaven. Mr. Goss concluded with a stirring appeal never to forget the cause of the distressed soldier and his family. Gen. BURNSIDE was next announced. He arose amid deafening cheers, which were continued for several moments. The General spoke in substance as follows:

abstract: On Saturday, Commissioner OSBORN issued a warrant for JOHN U. ANDREWS, theringleader of the July rioters, and who has since been confined in Fort Lafayette. The warrant was issued after a careful examination of the facts of the case, and the law applicable to them, and charged ANDREWS with treason against the United State. This warrant being placed in the hands of Marshal MURRAY, Gen. DIX isued an order to Col. BURKE that ANDREWS be turned over to the civil authorities. A deputy was sent down to the fort and yesterday morning this man, who has won such an unenviable notoriety, was brought up to the City and taken to the Marshal's office. The examination was set down for 2 o'clock in the afternoon, but a change of programme took place, and before the hour was reached, Gen. DIX sent word to the Commissioner that he would prefer that the case should be dropped for the present, and he directed the Marshal to have ANDREWS remanded to Fort Lafayette, to await the action of the Grand Jury.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, Commissioner OSBORN issued a warrant for JOHN U. ANDREWS, theringleader of the July rioters, and who has since been confined in Fort Lafayette. abstract: The steamship Hibernia, with two days' later advices from Europe, touched yesterday at Halifax, en route to this port, and the telegraph furnishes a brief abstract of her advices. The important announcement is made that Denmark absolutely rejects the ultimatum of Prussia and Austria calling for the withdrawal of the November Constitution upon penalty of their occupation of Schleswig, and in consequence of this refusal, the envoys of these Powers left Copenhagen on the night of Monday, the 18th ult. War, doubtless, has been formally declared, but according to the London Post, it is quite possible that hostilities will not immediately follow. The Post is of opinion that Prussia and Austria, instead of desiring a collision with Denmark, pursue this dangerous policy of occupying Schleswig, to become masters of the situation, so far as the minor German Powers are concerned. Allied Prussia and Austria being the belligerents on the one side and Denmark on the other, these small Powers would no longer have the right to interfere, and a peace would be brought about of which they would be the sole arbiters. The debate on the address of the Emperor still continued in the French Chambers, and it is said that the amendment in regard to Mexico will be met by a ministerial statement that the expenses of the French troops since the 1st ult. have been borne by the Mexican Government. An accident had happened to the steamship Louisiana, bound to this port from Liverpool, causing her to put back to Queenstown for repairs. Her decks were swept, and seven of her passengers and ten of her crew were lost overboard.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Hibernia, with two days' later advices from Europe, touched yesterday at Halifax, en route to this port, and the telegraph furnishes a brief abstract of her advices. The important announcement is made that Denmark absolutely rejects the ultimatum of Prussia and Austria calling for the withdrawal of the November Constitution upon penalty of their occupation of Schleswig, and in consequence of this refusal, the envoys of these Powers left Copenhagen on the night of Monday, the 18th ult. War, doubtless, has been formally declared, but according to the London Post, it is quite possible that hostilities will not immediately follow. The Post is of opinion that Prussia and Austria, instead of desiring a collision with Denmark, pursue this dangerous policy of occupying Schleswig, to become masters of the situation, so far as the minor German Powers are concerned. Allied Prussia and Austria being the belligerents on the one side and Denmark on the other, these small Powers would no longer have the right to interfere, and a peace would be brought about of which they would be the sole arbiters. The debate on the address of the Emperor still continued in the French Chambers, and it is said that the amendment in regard to Mexico will be met by a ministerial statement that the expenses of the French troops since the 1st ult. have been borne by the Mexican Government. An accident had happened to the steamship Louisiana, bound to this port from Liverpool, causing her to put back to Queenstown for repairs. Her decks were swept, and seven of her passengers and ten of her crew were lost overboard.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. Mr. MARETZEK'S season opened last night with an attendance that hardly seemed to be affected by the very Inclement weather. The house was indeed one of the most fashionable
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- Mr. MARETZEK's season opened last night with an attendance that hardly seemed to be affected by the very Inclement weather. The house was indeed one of the most fashionable that we have seen in Fourteenth-street for many months. This is the more remarkable when we consider that the opera was changed rather late in the day -- owing to the illness of Signer BIACHI -- a procedure that generally results in material damage to the exchequer. Instead of "Ione " by PETRELLA, we had the familiar "Trovatore" of VERDI. We need say nothing of the performance, except that the artists on their appearance were hailed with positive signs of approbation, and that the representation was generally good.

abstract: By last night's mail we received full files of Richmond papers from Jan.16 to Jan.29, inclusive. The news they contain is not of startling importance, but they furnish much very interest-
lead_paragraph: By last night's mail we received full files of Richmond papers from Jan.16 to Jan.29, inclusive. The news they contain is not of startling importance, but they furnish much very interesting and entertaining reading. The rebel Congress at Richmond is sitting with closed doors, maturing the important measures of taxation, conscription and the currency. The papers howl over it, but it don't seem to make any difference. The supply question is still engrossing the attention of every one. Gen. LEE had issued an order putting his army on reduced rations, and the cry from all quarters is "meat -- meat." LONGSTREET's operations are duly chronicled, but no new light is thrown upon them. The loss of a valuable blockade-runner is announced. She was the Vesta, a fine new steamer, owned by the rebel Government, and this was her first trip out. The cargo and vessel were an entire loss.

abstract: A Committee of the House of Representatives have now before them the question of a bill to establish a uniform system of bankrupt laws throughout the United States. The action of Congress in the last session, in postponing the consideration of this important question, occasioned much disappointment to the mercantile community. An efficient and practical measure, to adjust the relations of creditor and debtor, ought not longer to be delayed. Our attention has been called to this subject by a pamphlet written by Mr. EDWIN JAMES containing suggestions for a bill to enact a uniform law of bankruptcy. He proposes a system of voluntary and compulsory bankruptcy, and suggests that through the means of stamps on the various proceedings the administration of the new law would be inexpensive to the country. The author of these suggestions, when in the House of Commons, assisted in passing the English bill of 1861, which made great amendments in the practical operations of the existing laws of bankruptcy, and codified the whole system. We can commend these suggestions to the careful consideration of the Committee now organized upon this important subject, and we trust their labors will result in the passage of a just and equitable enactment, which, while it affords relief to the embarrassed and unfortunate debtor, will secure the distribution of the estate of the dishonest debtor equally among his creditors. In the Senate, in1840, DANIEL WEBSTER urged strongly the passing of a measure very analogous to that now proposed, and the suggestions of Mr. JAMES have been sent to the Committee, with the indorsement of the two Judges of the United States Court (Judges BETTS and SHIPMAN.) The question ought not to be obstructed by any party or factious feeling, and we really cannot see how any disinterested opposition can be offered to it
lead_paragraph: A Committee of the House of Representatives have now before them the question of a bill to establish a uniform system of bankrupt laws throughout the United States. The action of Congress in the last session, in postponing the consideration of this important question, occasioned much disappointment to the mercantile community. An efficient and practical measure, to adjust the relations of creditor and debtor, ought not longer to be delayed. Our attention has been called to this subject by a pamphlet written by Mr. EDWIN JAMES containing suggestions for a bill to enact a uniform law of bankruptcy. He proposes a system of voluntary and compulsory bankruptcy, and suggests that through the means of stamps on the various proceedings the administration of the new law would be inexpensive to the country. The author of these suggestions, when in the House of Commons, assisted in passing the English bill of 1861, which made great amendments in the practical operations of the existing laws of bankruptcy, and codified the whole system. We can commend these suggestions to the careful consideration of the Committee now organized upon this important subject, and we trust their labors will result in the passage of a just and equitable enactment, which, while it affords relief to the embarrassed and unfortunate debtor, will secure the distribution of the estate of the dishonest debtor equally among his creditors. In the Senate, in1840, DANIEL WEBSTER urged strongly the passing of a measure very analogous to that now proposed, and the suggestions of Mr. JAMES have been sent to the Committee, with the indorsement of the two Judges of the United States Court (Judges BETTS and SHIPMAN.) The question ought not to be obstructed by any party or factious feeling, and we really cannot see how any disinterested opposition can be offered to it

abstract: New Phase of Question
snippet: New Phase of Question
lead_paragraph: -- The advices from Halifax, brought by the 'Hibernia, put an altogether different aspect upon the Dano-German dispute. War seems none the less imminent, but the great Powers, Prussia and Austria, have determined to do the fighting with Denmark, if any is to be done, and the minor German Powers must content themselves, at least for the present, with watching the combat. It will be remem-bered that our last advices told of an Austro-Prussian proposition which, with pacific design, was presented on the 14th ult. to the Federal Diet, demanding that the Confederation should require Denmark definitely to suspend the November Constitution with regard to Schleswig, and notify King CHRISTIAN that in case of refusal, the Confederation would be compelled, in fulfillment of its demands, to occupy Schleswig by a military force. This proposition the Diet refused to entertain, when Prussia and Austria declared that they would themselves take the matter in hand, and offer the plan to Denmark as an ultimatum. It now appears that Denmark had just as strong an aversion to this mode of settling the matter as had the Federal Diet, for she met the proposition with a flat refusal. The Austro-Prussian Ambassadors at once quitted the Danish capital, and of course the two great Powers have no alternative but formally to declare war and carry out their threat of occupying the disputed duchy. It is not so sure, however, that the dispute will resolve itself into active hostilities after all. It is shrewdly surmised that the Austro-Prussian alliance has taken this bold step in order to snatch the responsibility out of the hands of the minor Powers, and themselves become masters of the situation. With Austria and Prussia as the belligerents on one side, and Denmark on the other, the minor German States would have no power to interfere between them, and the pending dispute would be settled on conditions of which they alone would be the arbitrators. Meantime the military preparations on all sides are being hurried.

abstract: For the benefit of those who would gain by my experience, I would state that I weighed one thousand bales of hay. I found the average weight of each bale to be eight pounds less than the marks
lead_paragraph: For the benefit of those who would gain by my experience, I would state that I weighed one thousand bales of hay. I found the average weight of each bale to be eight pounds less than the marks on the bale; and I found forty-one pounds of wood on each bale, and these only average sized. Considering the very high price demanded by speculators and dealers in hay, and paid by consumers, why will not the consumers insist upon having honest weights and a fair amount of wood?

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the resignation of Senator BAYAND, of Delaware, was received, and also the credentials of Mr. GEORGE READ RIDDLE, Senator elect in the
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the resignation of Senator BAYAND, of Delaware, was received, and also the credentials of Mr. GEORGE READ RIDDLE, Senator elect in the place of Mr. BAYARD. Senator DAVIS, of Kentucky, rose to a privileged question, to explain the course he had taken in reference to the expulsion of Senator BRIGHT and the proposed expulsion of Senator POWELL, by a former Congress. Mr. FOOT, of Vermont, introduced a joint resolution of the Vermont Legislature, in favor of a ship canal from the Mississippi River to the sea-board. Mr. WILSON introduced a bill for the examination of Quartermasters, Commissaries, Paymasters and their Assistants, with a view to ascertaining their competency. A petition from Baltimore, praying for reimbursement for the expenses of intrenchments around that city, was received. The resolutions of the House, announcing the death of Hon. JOHN M. NOELL, late Member of Congress, were received, and after the usual testimonials of respect the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Both Boards of the Common Council met at one o'clock yesterday afternoon. The Aldermen adopted a resolution empowering the Committee on Retrenchment and Reform to send for persons
lead_paragraph: Both Boards of the Common Council met at one o'clock yesterday afternoon. The Aldermen adopted a resolution empowering the Committee on Retrenchment and Reform to send for persons and papers. The Councilman referred it to the Committee on Law. The Aldermen referred a resolution to increase the pay of the laborers in the Street and City Inspector's Department from $1 75 to $2 per day, and adopted another resolution prohibiting the Hudson River Railroad Company from running their trains through the City except by single cars, with the space of one block intervening between each two cars. This latter resolution the Councilmen concurred in. A resolution to allow a coal merchant at the foot of West Twentieth-street to erect an elevated railway over a bulkhead, for private business uses, and which had been adopted by the Aldermen at a former meeting, the Councilmen sent to the Committee on Streets. Both boards adopted a resolution reported by the Joint Committee on National Affairs, requesting the Comptroller to arrange transfers to the City Contingent Fund, to the amount of $25,000, expressly to be used in extending a reception to the returned veteran volunteers. The committee report that they conferred with the Mayor and Gen. SANDFORD in regard to giving the veterans a reception, as previously instructed to do by both boards, and afterward consulted the Comptroller as to the means available for the purpose. Mr. BRENNAN said there was no money in the Contingent Fund, and arrears existed for music bills of receptions to the two-year regiments, amounting to $6,000, but if it were desired by the Common Council, he could recommend transfers to obtain money for a reception to the veterans. The Finance Committee of the Aldermen reported themselves unable to report on the whole City budget now, but presented an ordinance appropriating the sum of $1,019,217 85 and $967,227 36, respectively for the payment of the interest on and principal of the City debt due this year, in accordance with authority heretofore[???] given by the Legislature by various laws. Both boards adopted the ordinance by unanimous consent. The Comptroller reported a disbursement of $60,745 from the Relief Fund during the fortnight, ending on the 23d inst., to 13,597 families. The Aldermen adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M., of the 9th inst., and the Councilmen to 1 o'clock P.M., on Thursday next.

abstract: The Post says the Austrian and Prussian Representatives will doubtless quit Copenhagen, and war may be formally declared, but it is still possible that active hostilities may not instantly follow. Neither
lead_paragraph: The Post says the Austrian and Prussian Representatives will doubtless quit Copenhagen, and war may be formally declared, but it is still possible that active hostilities may not instantly follow. Neither Austria nor Prussia can possibly wish for a serious war with Denmark, and we suspect that their present policy, however dangerous, is pursued from a sole desire, In consequence of their defeat in the Diet, to become, so far as regards the other Powers, masters of the present situation. The allied Powers of Prussia and Austria on one side, and Denmark on the other, would be the belligerent parties, and the German Confederation, that is to say, the minor German Powers, would no longer have a right to interfere. In the pending dispute, Austria and Prussia would be the sole arbiters of the conditions on which they would be willing to conclude peace.

abstract: Speech on the Rebellion, Slavery, Peace, Democrats, >amp;c., at New-York
snippet: Speech on the Rebellion, Slavery, Peace, Democrats, >amp;c., at New-York
lead_paragraph: Hon. E.W. GANTT, late a Brigadier-General in the rebel army, spoke at Cooper Institute last evening, on the war, and in behalf of his repentant brethren of Arkansas and the Southwest. There was a very large audience present, and much interest was manifested in the remarks of the speaker, Among the persons noticed on the platform, were Rev. Drs. Bellows, Tyng, Judge Daly, Maj.-Gen. Robert Anderson, Attorney-General John Cochrane, William Cullen Bryant, and others. The meeting was called to order by Judge DALY, of this City, and Hon. WILLIAM E. DODGE was elected Chairman. He made a few eloquent and felicitous remarks introducing Mr. GANTT, who was received with enthusiastic cheers that lasted for some minutes.

abstract: The wind, yesterday morning, commenced from northeast, at about noon veered to southeast, when a heavy rain-storm set in; it afterward became very variable, shifting to north, northwest, and suddenly again to northeast; it finally at sunset settled at east, and became very light with fog. It has been blowing very heavy from the eastward outside during the day. Navigation has been somewhat impeded by the unsettled state of the weather, and a large number of outward bound vessels are now anchored in the North River, waiting a favorable opportunity to proceed to sea.

abstract: The New a Wise Measure
snippet: The New a Wise Measure
lead_paragraph: The public mind has been flattering itself that the fighting period was nearly over, and was little prepared for the President's enlargement of the last draft from three hundred thousand to five hundred thousand. At first look the new burden is not an agreeable one; yet every man who desires a speedy termination of the war, ought to welcome it. It is the one great requisite for that end.

abstract: Germany, War with; Possibility of
snippet: Germany, War with; Possibility of
lead_paragraph: Mr. KINGLAKE informs us, in his History of the Crimean War, of the origin of the term "drifting," as applied to the English policy at that time in regard to the Russian war. He shows how the Cabinet, by taking up a certain diplomatic position, are logically compelled to assume another just beyond, and with each new stand new feelings are engaged, until at length a great people drifts into a terrible struggle on a question to which they were at first comparatively indifferent. There are indications of a similar imperceptible and unconscious flow of the English policy on the German question.

abstract: and Pro-Slavery Democrats
snippet: and Pro-Slavery Democrats
lead_paragraph: Gen. GANTT's speech abounded with good hits, but the most telling one was his expression of amazement at finding his old Democratic friends "sitting down just where he left them." He had been out of the Government -- had his fight for the negro -- got well whipped -- shook the chattel off -- was ready to start life anew, but here were his old associates telling him, "You shall have the negro, whether you want him or not; you shan't come back unless you come back with Slavery."

abstract: The Supervisors met yesterday. The Mayor sent in several communications, one of which, nominating SOLOMON BANTA to fill the vacancy in the Board of New City hall Commissioners, was referred to the Special Committee on the
lead_paragraph: The Supervisors met yesterday. The Mayor sent in several communications, one of which, nominating SOLOMON BANTA to fill the vacancy in the Board of New City hall Commissioners, was referred to the Special Committee on the New Court-house; and another, nominating CHARLES P. WATTS Marshal for the First District, vice SYLVESTER ROBBINS, and MICHAEL DOODY Marshal for the Third District, vice GEORGE DOUGLASS, who have waived their appointments by a failure to give bonds and qualify, and VARNUM S. MILLS Marshal for the Fourth District, vice JAMES MCKEEVER, resigned, was referred to the Committee on County Officers. Communications were received from nineteen different banks and insurance companies, warning the Board and all City and County financial officers from using the moneys which have been taken from them by levy in payment of taxes on their capital stock. The aggregate amount seized from these nineteen institutions, including fees of the Marshal, amount to $485.884 36. Marshal HOLDEN enjoys a "good thing" in making the seizures, if he shall escape any unpleasant responsibility in the matter hereafter, his fees being two and a half per cent, on his "collections." The communications were all referred to the Committee on Annual Taxes. From the Comptroller's monthly statement of appropriations and expenditures, it appeared that during January $39,900 were subscribed to the Soldiers' Bounty Fund, from which $785,231 26 were expended, and at the close of the month there remained a balance of $121,012 27. A resolution by Mr. ELY was adopted, requesting the Volunteer Committee to report the number of men which the county is now deficient of under the impending draft. The Board adjourned to Tuesday next, at 3 o'clock P.M.

abstract: Prisoners should be made Work
snippet: Prisoners should be made Work
lead_paragraph: We fear that the country must give up hoping for any general exchange of prisoners. It was confidently expected that Gen. BUTLER, intrusted with full discretionary power in the matter, would be able to adjust the difficulties that had put a stop to the action of the cartel; but we now see no prospect of this. No man who has made himself acquainted with the actual transactions that have taken place regarding an exchange, will attribute this to any fault of the Government. Profoundly as it is to be desired that an arrangement could be effected that would restore to us the thousands of Union captives now confined in Southern prisons, the country cannot wish that this should be done at the price of such a sacrifice of justice as that on which the rebels condition a general exchange. Were we to yield to the only terms they will make, the concession would indeed give us back those in bonds; but it would restore to the rebels an army larger, probably, than that which LEE now has under his command. The rebels have expected to force the Government to this course. They have not succeeded, and we trust they will not succeed. We may add that it is in the power of the people, by an enlightened patience, to uphold the hands of the authorities in this just determination.

abstract: Brooklyn Police and Comptroller Faron
snippet: Brooklyn Police and Comptroller Faron
lead_paragraph: -- Notwithstanding the fact that Gov. SEYMOUR's nominations for a new Board of Police Commissioners were last week refused confirmation by the Senate, this little vagary of His Excellency has not been altogether devoid of a mischievous result. And, Unfortunately, the evil is felt in a quarter where it can be least conveniently borne. Comotroller FARON, of Brooklyn, in deference to the behests of Gov. SEYMOUR's quondam Board, withholds his signature to the warrant upon the Treasury for the funds wherewith to pay the civic guardians of that city, and their claims for wages for the present go unsatisfied. But this is not all. Comptroller FARON is Trustee of the Police Fund for the benefit of the widows and orphans of those brave fellows who have laid down the "locust" for the sterner weapons of the army, and who have fallen in the strife, and we are told that he even refuses to dole out the pittance upon which these helpless families depend for subsistence. How different is his course to that of Comptroller BRENNAN! Our New-York custodian of the money-bags knows the necessities of the police, and does not hesitate about taking the responsibility of paving them. The warrant for last month's money received his signature promptly upon presentation, and, as usual, on the first of the month, the entire force received their pay. Will not Mr. FARON follow this commendable example? or must private generosity be evoked to secure the $18,000 which are required to meet the demands of the case until such time as this puerile controversy is closed?

abstract: This regiment, Col. OSBORN, reached the Park Barracks Tuesday, on its way home to Chicago to reorganize. It was raised in Chicago, and left that city for Western Virginia in October, 1861,950 strong-Col. LIGHT then commanding. After much laborious scouting and picket duty in Western Virginia, and taking part in the sharp affair at Winchester, where SHIELDS was wounded, the regiment was ordered to the Peninsula, but reached it only in time to see Mc-CLELLAN's army leaving it, and turned and went to Suffolk, Va. From that place it was transferred to the Department of the South, reaching St. Helena in February, 1663. It was on Folly and Morris Islands under Gen. GILLMORE, helped take Fort Wagner, and the first of our men inside of the fort were from this regiment. About a hundred of its members declined to reenlist, and are serving out their term at the South. The remainder, 350 in number, have reenlisted, and we trust will receive at Chicago the warm greeting and prompt aid they deserve. Beside Col, OSBORN, there are present almost the full regimental staff and line.

abstract: In the rebel Senate, on Jan.18, while the Impressment Law was under consideration. Mr. WIGFALL re-  marked that the Secretary of the Treasury did not possess the alchymist's power of making money.
lead_paragraph: In the rebel Senate, on Jan.18, while the Impressment Law was under consideration. Mr. WIGFALL re- marked that the Secretary of the Treasury did not possess the alchymist's power of making money. Every dollar he issues is not only indorsed, but, practically, drawn by the property-holders of the country, for, upon them, will alternately fall the responsibility of the redemption of the notes which have been issued. As soon as it became obvious that a large army had to be fed, the speculator commenced laying up provisions, and prices rapidly advanced. The farmers cooperated with the speculators by taking Richmond prices as the prices at which they would sell. In proportion as prices rose, the currency increased, and at the currency increased, prices again advanced. This has been continued until the Government -- the agent of the people -- find itself almost confronted with the necessity of repudiation on the one hand, or of bankruptcy to the whole producing interests on the other.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the complimentary resolutions to Commodore RINGGOLD and Gen. THOMAS were passed. Mr. COWAN presented the memorial of the Philadelphia Board of Trade against a bankrupt law.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, the complimentary resolutions to Commodore RINGGOLD and Gen. THOMAS were passed. Mr. COWAN presented the memorial of the Philadelphia Board of Trade against a bankrupt law. The House bill to revive the grade of Lieutenant-General was referred to the Committee on Military Affairs. The resolution of Mr. DOOLITTLE, to require the presence of a representative of the departments when witnesses as to the conduct of such department was being examined, was, after discussion, postponed until Monday next. The bill to promote enlistments was taken up, and Mr. SHERMAN made a lengthy speech in defense of the policy of treating black soldiers on the same terms with white. Mr. CARLILE obtained the floor to reply, when the.Senate adjourned.

abstract: Policy, The Future
snippet: Policy, The Future
lead_paragraph: With a fresh draft impending, and a very respectable debt incurred and to be incurred, everything relating to the economy of our resources, both in men and money, of course possesses the highest interest. And it just now possesses greater interest than ever, owing to the fact that we not only begin to feel our burdens, but the public is generally satisfied that with a proper use of the means which the Government will soon have at its disposal, the approaching campaign may be made final and decisive. The exhaustion of the rebels is no longer a matter of speculation or conjecture. The evidence of it is so strong and clear as to make the fact almost notorious, and it does not consist simply in the stories of spies and refugees, or the inventives of opposition newspapers, but in the measures and confessions of the rebel Government itself. JEFFRSON DAVIS' exposition of the condition of their currency, and his plan for its redemption, coupled with the conscription which is now before his Congress, putting every white man into the ranks of the army, constitute proofs very much stronger than those on which the conclusions either of soldiers or statesmen are usually based.

abstract: A crowded audience assembled at the Cooper Institute last evening to listen to the lecture of Miss ANNA E. DICKENSON on the " Lessons of the Hour," the same lecture as was delivered in Washington a short time since.
lead_paragraph: A crowded audience assembled at the Cooper Institute last evening to listen to the lecture of Miss ANNA E. DICKENSON on the " Lessons of the Hour," the same lecture as was delivered in Washington a short time since. The doors were opened at seven o'clock, and a continuous crowd poured into the hall, so that it was nearly filled in a quarter of an hour, and before half-past seven there was no possibility of obtaining an entrance, so that very many who had purchased tickets previously, both to reserved and other s eats, were compelled to leave, causing much dissatisfaction.

abstract: Advices from the Army of the Potomac confirm the reports of discontent, mutiny and short supplies of food and clothing in LEE's army, which have been heretofore published.
lead_paragraph: Advices from the Army of the Potomac confirm the reports of discontent, mutiny and short supplies of food and clothing in LEE's army, which have been heretofore published. Intercepted letters from rebel women state that, of the late cavalry force of 3,000 sent into the Shenandoah Valley, not over 500 returned. Many were frozen to death, and the rest so badly frost-bitten as to be obliged to seek shelter in the farmhouses. Rebel deserters continue to arrive in the Army of the Potomac in considerable numbers.

abstract: Again in Command
snippet: Again in Command
lead_paragraph: -The country will rejoice to observe that Gen. ROSECRANS is again in the field of active duty. Though not placed in a sphere where his commanding talents of the military order will have much scope, it is yet one which furnishes room for the display of the highest administrative qualities, and demands a rare prudence, firmness, and sagacity. The command of the Department of the Missouri has proved too difficult a task to a long succession of generals, each of whom has in turn been compelled to exclaim: "Non nostrum est tantis componere lites." If any one bids fair to hold the balance of justice evenly, it is the distinguished soldier to whom the department is now intrusted. His order assaulting the command will be found elsewhere. It breathes the old fervid patriotism and devoted loyalty, and concludes in the following words:

abstract: From Newbern, N.C., the news is of considerable importance. Gen. PALMER, commanding at that post, reports to Gen. BUTLER that on the 1st inst., the rebels in force, consisting of PICKETT'S
lead_paragraph: From Newbern, N.C., the news is of considerable importance. Gen. PALMER, commanding at that post, reports to Gen. BUTLER that on the 1st inst., the rebels in force, consisting of PICKETT's Division and HOKE's Brigade, the latter recently detached from LEE's army in Virginia, advanced and attacked our forces at Bachelor's Creek, who fell back, it being impracticable to make a resistance. Our loss was fifty to one hundred men and two pieces of artillery, though it was believed that the latter might be recovered, as they had been abandoned, and had not yet fallen into the enemy's hands. An advance was also made on the South side of the Trent River, with a view of cutting the railroad to Morehead City, but the rebels were repulsed. Gen. PALMER was confident of his ability to hold the place.

abstract: The following statistics, taken from the Custom-house records, show the trade to Nassau. It will be seen, that notwithstanding the vigilance of our authorities as to contraband shipments, the intercourse with the suspected port is steadily increasing. If it be true, as it is asserted, that more than one half of the vessels clearing for Nassau carry goods contraband of war, the following statistics are suggestive; For the six weeks, ending Dec. 15, 1863, ten vessels sailed for Nassau, having an aggregate tonnage of 2,885. For the same period, ending Feb. 1, 1864, twelve vessels cleared, having an aggregate tonnage of 4,288, showing an increase over the first period of 1,403 tons, or about fifty per cent.

abstract: Enrollment Bill, House Action on
snippet: Enrollment Bill, House Action on
lead_paragraph: -- The House of Representatives seems to be doing its utmost to undo all that the Senate did for the improvement of the Conscription Bill. That body, yesterday, voted to reduce the price of commutation from $400, at which the Senate had fixed it, to $300 -- the old figure. But this is a small matter. It did much worse than that. It restored (by a vote of 79 against 49) the fatal error of making the payment of the three hundred dollar commutation work exemption for the whole period of three years! We cannot help thinking this a most unwise measure. The facts brought out in the course of the Senate debates on this point proved conclusively that the effect of this will be in a very short time to exhaust the military basis, and dry up the only fountain whence soldiers can be drawn. The experience of the last draft shows that a large proportion of those drafted will avail themselves of the privilege of exemption by commutation. Each man who pays his three hundred dollars will have in his pocket a certificate of exemption from draft for three years, and it will not take a great number of drawings to rule the whole serviceable population out of the lists. The Senate in its bill provided a partial remedy for this enormous evil by the provision that the payment of commutation should relieve the commuter from the draft in filling that quota only, and his name should be retained on the roll in filling future quotas. Another excellent feature of the Senate's bill was the division of substitutes into two classes -- those themselves liable to draft and those not liable to draft: and it provided that complete exemption for three years was only to be obtained by furnishing a substitute from the class not liable to draft, (as aliens, persons under twenty years of age, & c.,) while drafted persons furnishing substitutes from the class themselves subject to draft were to be again liable to draft on the exhaustion of the enrollment. The action of the House sweeps by the board all these provisions, restores all the demonstrated errors of the old act, and, we fear, will leave the Conscription Bill little more than an irritating nullity.

abstract: Rebel Movements in
snippet: Rebel Movements in
lead_paragraph: A letter from the Richmond correspondent of the London Times, written under date of Dec. 14, furnishes a striking corroboration of the purpose we, in common with all careful students of the military situation, have imputed to the rebels in regard to East Tennessee. "The operations of Gen. LONGSTREET against Knoxville," he writes, "though baffled for the moment, will inevitably lead hereafter to material results, and it is my belief that the Federals will not be left in undisturbed possession of East Tennessee during the Winter months."

abstract: Dr. CARL THEODORE MEIER, one of our most eminent German physicians, died suddenly of congestion of the brain on the 2d inst. He was born in Koenigsbergh, Prussia, in 1810, and studied at the Universities of Greifswald, Gena, Goettingen, Halle and Berlin. He was then for some years assistant physician to the world-renowned. Dr. DIEFFENBACH, and published several essays on Surgery. In this branch of medical science he excelled, and must ever be counted among the most prominent Surgeons of the present age.

abstract: Waste of Strength and Time
snippet: Waste of Strength and Time
lead_paragraph: We hear rumors -- we know not how well founded -- of another Burnside coast expedition as in preparation. Much as we respect the brave officer who is reported to be about to lead it, we sincerely trust that no men will be raised for another coast attack. It is apparent now to the dullest eye that the grand mistake of our strategy in the whole war has been our want of concentration. It may be doubted whether a single one of our coast expeditions, with the grand exception of the attack on New-Orleans, has tended to the successful closing of the war.

abstract: The steamship America, from Southampton Jan. 21, with two days' later European news than that telegraphed on Monday from Halifax, arrived yesterday morning. The Dano-German affair continued the absorbing question, and the preparations for the arbitrament of arms were hurriedly making. It is asserted that the first act of Prussia and Austria will be to order the Duke of Augustenberg to evacuate Holstein. Plans for transporting the Austrian troops across the Prussian territory had been arranged, and it was thought that the transit would last several days, the troops being divided, says one account, into fifty trains of 1,000 men each. Another account says that the Austrian army of occupation will be commanded by Field-Marshal VON GABLENZ, and that 20,000 will be the aggregate of men. The Danes were engaged in breaking up the ice upon the Schlei, and making every arrangement to meet the shock of battle. The Archduke MAXIMILIAN, whose visit to Paris is expected, will be received with the title of Emperor and the honors  paid to that rank. Official advices from Mexico state that the army is everywhere-giving in its adherence to the new Government. It was reported that the Bank of France had lost $400,000 in gold, on the 16th instant. There is little of interest in the English news. A statement in the Edinburgh Scotsman shows that since the blockade of the rebel ports, upward of sixty steamers have left the Clyde, and their purchase price amounted to Â£700,000. Some of these vessels have been an immense source of profit to all concerned. The pirate 'Florida was announced by her commander as ready to leave Brest, and also to try her mettle with the Kearsage after getting out of French waters. This latter is probably braggadocio.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors held a special meeting yesterday, and authorized the Recruiting Committee to go to Albany, and urge the passage of an act legalizing the loan which they now are dis-
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors held a special meeting yesterday, and authorized the Recruiting Committee to go to Albany, and urge the passage of an act legalizing the loan which they now are disbursing, but which is yet unsubscribed for, to the amount of $500,000. The necessity for this step lies in the fact that the fund is exhausted, and the banks are loth to subscribe till the loan is sanctioned by the Legislature. An effort to give this sanction, so far as the Senate is concerned, was made on Monday, but failed by an emphatic negative vote. So far the committee have enlisted 5,600 men. Want of funds must stop them in the full tide of successful operations, if the desired sanction of law is not granted very speedily.

abstract: Army of Tennessee; Address of "Many Soldiers" againts Conscription Act
snippet: Army of Tennessee; Address of "Many Soldiers" againts Conscription Act
lead_paragraph: The Cincinnati Commercial, of Feb. 2, publishes the following address, which it editorially vouches for as genuine. It says: "It comes to us from two distinct and independent sources, each professing to be a literal copy of the document, including italics and capitals. These transcripts of the original, are corroborative, and leave no room to doubt the genuineness of this revolutionary manifesto. How extensively it has been circulated, or to what extent it has influenced the rank and file of JOHNSTON's army, we have no means of knowing."

abstract: We left New-Orleans Jan. 26, 9 A.M. for this port direct, and were over the bar at S.W. Pass same day at 6 P.M. The steamer Matanzas left on the same morning one hour earlier. The steamship
lead_paragraph: We left New-Orleans Jan. 26, 9 A.M. for this port direct, and were over the bar at S.W. Pass same day at 6 P.M. The steamer Matanzas left on the same morning one hour earlier. The steamship Mississippi was to have sailed on the Saturday previous, but owing to some disarrangement of her propeller was obliged to remain for repairs; she will probably get away by the 30th; she is to bring home the Twelfth Connecticut Regiment. The steamer Gray Jacket is still ashore at Pass a l'Outre; her cargo has nearly all been lightered from her, and she will very soon be got off.

abstract: Ira C. Canfield, Wm.B. Canfield and Joseph H. Meredith vs. Zachariah Dederich, Harmon B. Sears and James H. Dederich. -- This suit is brought by the plaintiffs to recover $200 for the value of certain articles of silverware alleged to have been wrongfully taken and detained by the defendants. Plaintiffs demanded the return of these articles, but defendants refused to return them, and they allege that defendants have converted the goods to their own use. The defendants deny the allegations of the complaint, and it appears from the evidence that the articles were stolen, and that defendants purchased them in good faith from a young man who offered them for sale, paying for them the sum of $25.

abstract: Christine Etchron vs. Ferdinand Stribling,  The plaintiff alleges that she has always sustained a fair character for chastity, and has always been of good fame and reputation among her neighbors, and
lead_paragraph: Christine Etchron vs. Ferdinand Stribling. -- The plaintiff alleges that she has always sustained a fair character for chastity, and has always been of good fame and reputation among her neighbors, and that by reason of her fair character Max Meyer had engaged to marry her. That the defendant knowing that the said Meyer was engaged to marry plaintiff, with the intent to prevent such marriage, and intending to injure plaintiff's character and fame, some time in the month of January, 1863, in the presence of sundry persons, uttered the following words: "Christine ist ???in huhr," which, being interpreted means that Christine was a "social evil."

abstract: Whitman vs. Thompson. Clamming Sloop Seizure, Boundaries of New-York and New-Jersey
snippet: Whitman vs. Thompson. Clamming Sloop Seizure, Boundaries of New-York and New-Jersey
lead_paragraph: John Whitman vs. Joseph J. Thompson. -- This was an action of trespass, brought by the plaintiff, the owner and master of the sloop Ann L. Whitman, to recover damages for an alleged wrongful and violent seizure and conversion of the sloop, by the defendant, on the 26th of September, 1862. By a statute of New-Jersey, passed in 1820, and revised in 1846, no person other than actual inhabitants and residents of New-Jersey are allowed to gather clams in any of the waters of New-Jersey, on board of any vessel, on penalty of a fine of $20, and the forfeiture of the vessel; and the act directs the Sheriffs to seize any vessel so employed, and prescribes proceedings for her condemnation.

abstract: Early this morning our outposts at Bachelors Creek were attacked by the enemy, represented to be in force of about 15,000 strong, consisting of HOKES' Brigade and PICKETT'S entire division. It be-
lead_paragraph: Early this morning our outposts at Bachelors Creek were attacked by the enemy, represented to be in force of about 15,000 strong, consisting of HOKES' Brigade and PICKETT'S entire division. It being impracticable to make an adequate defense, our force fell back in good order, destroying the camps, abandoning but few stores, with a loss of fifty to one hundred men and one section of light artillery.

abstract: We understand that some dissatisfaction has arisen among the veteran regiments proposing to reenlist, on account of the determination of the Government to credit all such re-enlistments against the number to be drafted. It is even said that several of the veteran regiments of GRANT's army have renounced their intention to reenlist on this account. We give credit to these soldiers for a truly patriotic impulse in this matter; they wish the draft to be effectual, and do not fancy the notion of their reenlisting being the means of keeping forty or fifty thousand shirkers at home. We believe, however, that the action of the President in increasing the call to 500,000 men will entirely obviate any objection of this kind. The 200,000 added to the number originally called for, will cover four times over the total number of veterans available for reenlistment. Let them take note of this.

abstract: -- A letter was received by the Kings County Bounty Committee yesterday from Supervisor BLOOM, who in connection with Supervisor KIRBY, proceeded to the Army of the Potomac for the purpose of reeplisting and paying bounties to veterans in Brooklyn regiments. He states that they have visited all the corps and find a general desire among a large majority of the men to reenlist, provided they can procure furloughs. As there is some difficulty new in this respect, the prospect is not as good as it might be, or would have been two or three weeks since. Still they are making good progress. The men are represented as being in first-rate condition.

abstract: Enrollment Bill, Action of the House on
snippet: Enrollment Bill, Action of the House on
lead_paragraph: The action of the House of Representatives in altering the Senate Enrollment Bill by reducing the commutation from four hundred to three hundred dollars, and by making that commutation exempt for three years instead of for the particular draft, is most extraordinary. Of what stuff are these men made that they are so insensible both to the necessities of the country and the lessons o experience?

abstract: Coroner WILDEY yesterday held an inquest on the body of Mrs. ANN WOOD, a young woman, aged about 27 years, and a native of Staten Island. The husband of deceased has been for some time connected with the Union army, first as a private in the Forty-seventh Regiment New-York Volunteers, but more recently as First-Lieutenant in the Third South Carolina regiment (colored.) He returned to this City a few days since, his term of enlistment having expired. A day or two ago he informed his wife that it was his intention to reenlist. This information so affected the spirits of his wife that she became very melancholy, and about 1 o'clock on Wednesday afternoon she went up to the sixth floor of the house in which she had resided, No. 135 Crosby-street, and threw herself from the sixth-story window to the pavement below. In falling she struck and passed through a wooden awning. She was immediately taken up and conveyed to Bellevue Hospital, where she died in about hall an hour. The jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the above facts. The only motive for the commission of the rash act, which any of the witnesses could assign, was the proposed reenlistment of her husband.

abstract: Mr. WALLACK has handed to the Treasurer of the Metropolitan Fair the very liberal donation of $904 25, the proceeds of the benefit given them at his theatre on Tuesday night. Every dollar of the receipts of the night mentioned was donated. The weather was unfavorable, and but for this the munificent gift would have been somewhat increased. Mr. WALLACK has thus initiated the rivalry of generosity in behalf of the great fair and its purposes. It was done quietly, modestly, without blazoning or parade, and the generous spirit that prompted it meets with a proper recognition.

abstract: ACADEMY or MUSIC The experiment of a fourta regular night was made last night, with a degree of success that establishes at once the capacity of our public for a more liberal supply of opera than...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY or MUSIC. -- The experiment of a fourta regular night was made last night, with a degree of success that establishes at once the capacity of our public for a more liberal supply of opera than has been thought practicable or -- at all events -- desirable. Long before the performance commenced the box-office had sold out all its interest in the individual comfort of the audience, and exhibited its distress in the well-known banner inscribed "Standing room only." This result is ascribable to good management. Mr. MARETZEK, with the wily tactics of a prudent General, reserved his greatest strength for the occasion. GOUNOD's "Faust" would draw a crowded house on a far worse night than Thursday. It has, so far, only flushed the community with pleasure, and months will elapse ere the lieges are satisfied with its sweets. The performance last night was in every respect enjoyable. All the artists were in excellent voice, and the choral and orchestral masses seemed to be animated by the warmth that resulted from the general success. "Faust" is too complete a work to grain much from incidental encores. Its success is genuine, and will, we think, be lasting, because it is based upon a broad and general impression. Nevertheless, there were demands for repetition, and general satisfaction at what was vouchsafed in that way. Mr. MARETZEK may be congratulated on the complete acceptance of his Thursday evening experiment. With such a repertoire he can play not only four but six times a week, if he is so disposed.

abstract: The demand for discount is active, notwithstanding the advance in the Bank minimum to 8 percent. The Bank of France had not followed the example of the Bank of England, and specie continued to flow from London to Paris. The Stock Market was depressed by warlike appearances and the action of the bank, but there was more tone on the 21st, and Consols were fractionally higher under the more pacific rumors.

abstract: FUNERAL OF A BRAVE OFFICER. A large body of the Metropolitan Police will assemble, to-day, at the Police Headquarters to pay the last tribute of respect to Lieut. BENJAMIN F. DENTON, late of Com-...
lead_paragraph: FUNERAL OF A BRAVE OFFICER. -- A large body of the Metropolitan Police will assemble, to-day, at the Police Headquarters to pay the last tribute of respect to Lieut. BENJAMIN F. DENTON, late of Company A, One Hundred and Thirty-third Regiment New-York Volunteers, who was at one time a highly-respected and useful officer of the force. His regiment was included in the famous Metropolitan Brigade, commanded by Brig.-Gen. BOWEN, which is now in service under Gen. BANKS, in the Department of the Gulf, where it has achieved a glorious distinction for bravery and efficiency. In consequence of the absence of his Captain, who had been detached for duty in New-Orleans, the command of his company in the field devolved upon Lieut. DENTON, and it was while bravely leading his men on the occasion of the second assault on Port Hudson, that he fell mortally wounded, and was buried on the field. His body, after several days, was recovered and buried in a soldier's grave on the ground which his blood had consecrated. Recently, however, his remains were disinterred, and forwarded to this City by the steamship Western Metropolis, which arrived on Wednesday. Few men have given their lives in this struggle of the nation who were more beloved and more deserving of honor than he to whom a fitting tribute will be paid by his late comrades, to-day. Sandy Hill, Washington Co., N.Y., will be his final resting-place. A captain and twenty men from each of the twenty-four lower precincts will act as escort. The route of the procession will be up Brordway to Fourteenth-street, and up Fifth-avenue to Twenty-third-street; thence to Ninth-avenue and to Hudson River Railroad depot.

abstract: The artists of the Studio Building gave another of their pleasant receptions at the Tenth-street establishment last night. The attendance was, as usual, exceedingly full and brilliantly fashionable -- the principal saloon, the various studios, and even the passages, being tenanted with well. dressed patrons of art. Considering the rapid recurrence of these affairs, here and in Brooklyn, there was a creditable display of new pictures. In creating the necessity for novelties these social events serve a good purpose. They incite the artists to a degree of industry that they might not otherwise feel Mr. BIERSTADT's studio attracted much attention. It Is, in fact, a museum of Indian curiosities, and is always one of the attractions of the Studio Building. It was peculiarly interesting on the present occasion, inasmuch[???]as it exhibited some of the artist's recent sketches in California. There is a mine of new impressions in theso valuable transcripts of nature. In the large saloon, Mr. BIERSTADT exhibited a remarkably fine landscape, with great tumultuous-mountains, and wild flashes of aerial light, and distant visions of feathery waterfalls and steamings masses of clouds hurtling through it. This and other works of Mr. BIERSTADT will add to the attractiveness of the Spring exhibition. Mr. GIGNOUX has a large work in hand, suggested by his Summer's tour in the White Mountains. It is taken from the commencement of the descent of the Tip-top House, and is as bold in the foreground as it is comprehensive in perspective. The subject, at present, is only mapped out, but the practiced eye can already detect in it the indications of a vigorous production. Among the other artists who exhibited pictures, and attracted attentton, were Mr. Church, Mr. Whittredge, Mr. McEntee, Mr. Dana, Mr. Haseltine, Mr. Beard, Mr. Henry, (a little railway subject, hard in colors, but truthful and spirited,) Mr. de Haas, (an admirable marine piece,) Mr. Casllear, Mr. Gilford, Mr. Hart, Mr. Homer Martin, and others of the well-known personnel of the Tenth-street hive.

abstract: Rebel Hopes of, Through Elections
snippet: Rebel Hopes of, Through Elections
lead_paragraph: Solomon said long ago that though one should bray a fool in a mortar among wheat with a pestle, his foolishness would not depart from him, and his words are just as true now as when they were uttered. The race of fools has not died out either, and, from present appearances, is not likely to. They have existed in good numbers throughout rebeldom from the first, but the pressure and tribulation of the mortar and pestle of civil war has divided them into two classes: the men who have learned from this bitter hard experience, and the men whose foolishness does not in the least depart from them. This latter class is largely composed of those men wise in their own conceit, whose case seemed to Solomon even more hopeless than that of the fool. These men are ever blinded to the actual state of affairs; ever looking for help in some quarter whence experience should have shown them there was no hope of help; ever expecting results which are entirely out of comparison with the means employed; ever expecting sunbeams from cucumbers.

abstract: The report, which we publish in another column, of the trial of certain persons for conspiring to prevent the enforcement of the act of Congress in regard to a draft, contains matters of general interest. It was stated by sworn witnesses that a regular organization existed for the purpose of aiding the rebellion by secret movements in the North. It is said to have been called the "Golden Circle," and the names of sundry persons are mentioned as having belonged to it. We do not regard the testimony on this point as reliable, and, so far as names are concerned, we deem it wholly unworthy of credit. The general facts stated probably have at least a foundation in truth, and they present a condition of affairs which is certainly entitled to attention.

abstract: The arrival of the Jura at Portland last evening puts us in possession of one day's later advices from Europe than those received on Wednesday by the America. The Dano-German disturbance had assumed a less warlike phase. Denmark, it was rumored, had consented to the temporary suspension of the November Constitution, and thus the dispute was again brought within the pale of negotiation. Meanwhile the Austro-Prussian troops were getting ready to occupy Schleswig. The other news by this arrival is not of great general interest. A report had reached England of the pirate Alabama being at Singapore on the 22d of December. The plan of disposing of the steamship Great Eastern by lottery had fallen through, and Capt. PATON, her former Commander, had caused the vessel's arrest on a claim for Â£2,000.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday a number of unimportant bills were introduced, when the bill for equalizing the pay of troops was taken up and discussed; but without reaching any conclusion, the Senate proceeded to the consideration of the Revenue Bill. After rejecting several amendments to reduce the tax on spirits, the bill was passed aa it came from the Finance Committee. The clause taxing spirits on hand is stricken out. The Senate then adjourned until Monday next.

abstract: Last Move of Austria and Prussia
snippet: Last Move of Austria and Prussia
lead_paragraph: The German question has lately taken a new and interesting phase. The leading Powers of Germany -- Austria and Prussia -- finding that the popular current is sweeping beyond them, have determined to lead it. They have parted from the Confederacy and the Diet, have called summarily upon Denmark to revoke the Constitution she has enforced over Schleswig, have waited two days for her ultimatum, and then begun the forwarding of troops from a point as distant as Vienna to Holstein and Schleswig. The forces of the secondary German Powers in the Duchies have already yielded the right of way to the powerful columns approaching, and by this time Austrian and Prussian regiments have, doubtless, passed the Eider, and the first blood has been spilt.

abstract: Soon after 2 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a fire was discovered in the drying-room of the confectionary establishment of Messrs. A. & C. KAUFMANN, Nos. 444 and 446 Pearl-street, near Chatham. Owing to the combustible nature of the contents, the flames spread with great rapidity, and in a short time the two buildings and their contents were wholly destroyed. The damage cannot be less than $25,000, and probably it will much exceed that sum. The buildings were three stories in height; said to be fully insured in the Williamsburgh City, Pacific and other Insurance Companies. The premises No. 448 Pearl are occupied by Mr. THOMAS W. BAILEY, as a carpet-store. His goods are extensively damaged by water. The stock of Mr. R.TWEED, Jr., chair manufacturer, is also much injured by water

abstract: The Kings County Supervisors Committee continued the payment of bounties yesterday to the reenlisted men of the Forty-eighth Regiment New-York State Volunteers, just returned from Hilton Head. About 300 men have now been paid, and it is understood that over one hundred of those remaining in South Carolina have reenlisted since the main body of the regiment left. A number of the Sixty-seventh Regiment were also paid yesterday. About twenty new recruits were enlisted.

abstract: Our local columns this morning show that the refluent tide of our reenlisting veterans has already set in -- several New-York regiments being now on their way back to the Army of the Potomac. These regiments have been home, enjoyed their thirty-five days' furlough among their friends, received the handsome bounties offered by the National, State and local authorities, and now return to take their places in the organizations to which they belong. By a judicious timing of the furloughs, it is so arranged that' others arrive as these go back, and thus the important work of reorganization goes on without the army's being seriously depleted at any one time -- a process analogous to the beautiful economy of nature, by which the human body successively undergoes waste and repair.
