abstract: The rebels are trying to get up a stir about of reenlistment among their troops. As they will all be mercilessly conscripted unless they do, a few have been persuaded into it. The Richmond papers announce with great gusto the fact that JOHNSTON'S and BATTLE'S Brigades, of LEE'S army, and BATES' and STRZHL'S brigades, of JOHNSTON'S army, have reenlisted for the war.

abstract: THE NEW CITY HALL COMMISSIONER Mayor GUNTHER has nominated Ex-Alderman SOLOMON BANTA for New City Hall Commissioner, to fill a vacancy, and the Board of Supervisors have referred the nomination to the Committee on County Officers. It might be well for this committee to inquire particularly into the matter of Mr. BANTA'S residence before reporting his name and nomination for approval by the board.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW CITY HALL COMMISSIONER. -- Mayor GUNTHER has nominated Ex-Alderman SOLOMON BANTA for New City Hall Commissioner, to fill a vacancy, and the Board of Supervisors have referred the nomination to the Committee on County Officers. It might be well for this committee to inquire particularly into the matter of Mr. BANTA'S residence before reporting his name and nomination for approval by the board. Mr. BANTA, although well known for his wealth, does not appear on the tax books as being responsible for personal property, but is charged with considerable real estate. His financial Interests in the City are large; he is a Director in the Greenwich Bank, and holds a similar position in other moneyed institutions here, and it may be that he does not hold any personal property taxable direct to himself. However, It is understood that about two years ago he purchased and removed to a house at Eaglewood, New-Jersey, from his residence in West Tenth-street, Since that time, it is said, he has had a room at the house of his son-in-law, in Hammond-street, which; he occasionally occupies, and upon this fact of occasional occupation of that room he claims a residence in New. York. His name cannot be found in the Directory.

abstract: Mr. THEODORE TILTON addressed a large audience at the Church of the Puritans, on Wednesday evening, on the "The Present Crisis." He quoted a saying of DE TOCQUEVILLE, uttered on his return to France from his visit to this county, to the...
lead_paragraph: Mr. THEODORE TILTON addressed a large audience at the Church of the Puritans, on Wednesday evening, on the "The Present Crisis." He quoted a saying of DE TOCQUEVILLE, uttered on his return to France from his visit to this county, to the effect that "such was the strength or our local State governments, and such the tenacity of our people for State rights, and such the weakness of the Federal compact, that in case of a conflict between the Nation and a State, the former would have to yield." The speaker thought that in 1830, secession might have been possible. That it was impossible in 1860 was due to the efforts of a few men called Radical Abolitionists, who roused all the spirit of liberty in the country, thus making rebellion in behalf of Slavery an impracticable thing.

abstract: The Indianapolis Courier says: "We learn from a gentleman who met JESSE D. BRIGHT, at Kent Station, White County, a week or ten days since, that the distinguished Ex-Senator has greatly modifield his views on the rebellion.
lead_paragraph: -- The Indianapolis Courier says: "We learn from a gentleman who met JESSE D. BRIGHT, at Kent Station, White County, a week or ten days since, that the distinguished Ex-Senator has greatly modifield his views on the rebellion. It was refreshing to hear him talk of the inexhaustible power and resources of the North, in connection with the inevitable liable overthrow of the conspirators. He yields to the inexorable logic of events on Slavery question, and doubts if the peculiar institution can possibly be restored to its former position and security, even in the sections where practical Abolition is not already an accomplished fact. He says the South staked the institution upon the fortuues of war, and having lost in the desperate chance, must abide the result."

abstract: A remarkable tusk of a mastodon has just been added to the cabinet of the Rochester University. It is a genuine fragment of the Mastoden Giganteus, the old king of the North American plains. The tusk is six inches in diame er at the larger end, and about two and a half inches at the smaller. Its length is about four feet, which is perhaps not more than one-half the original.
lead_paragraph: -- A remarkable tusk of a mastodon has just been added to the cabinet of the Rochester University. It is a genuine fragment of the Mastoden Giganteus, the old king of the North American plains. The tusk is six inches in diame er at the larger end, and about two and a half inches at the smaller. Its length is about four feet, which is perhaps not more than one-half the original. The shape of the tusk is quite unlike that of the elephant, and the quality of the ivory is very inferior to the latter. It was exhumed by a party of salt-miners in Oregon, about three years since. The owner was offered $1,000 for it, but refused the money, and subsequently brought it to New-Orleans, via the Isthmus of Panama, thence to St. Louis, and finally to Rochester.

abstract: On Monday next, the new Hippodrome, which has lately been erected on Fourteenth-street, opposite the Academy of Music, will be opened to the public. Last evening a number of the friends of the proprietors were invited to attend a private view of the "Hippotheatron," by which high-sounding name the new structure is to be known.
lead_paragraph: On Monday next, the new Hippodrome, which has lately been erected on Fourteenth-street, opposite the Academy of Music, will be opened to the public. Last evening a number of the friends of the proprietors were invited to attend a private view of the "Hippotheatron," by which high-sounding name the new structure is to be known. The building is constructed of corrugated and ridged galvanized iron, of SEELEY'S patent, and is supposed to combine strength and durability with the additional advantages of being fire-proof. In capacity it surpasses any of the cloues of Continental Europe, as accommodation will be afforded for over 4,000 spectators. The entrance is through a beautiful Italian arch, 23 feet in height and 22 feet in width, the columns of which are richly decorated with statuesque and arabesque work of the Italian school. The seats are spacious and comfortable, rising tier upon tier to the height of 22 feet from the ground -- so arranged as to afford an uninterrupted view of the arena. A retiring-room has been provided for the accommodation of ladles, as also another for gentlemen. In case of any emergency, two large exit doors have been pro vided, so that the entire audience of 4,000 persons can leave the building in an incredibly short apace of time. The decorations are simple, yet at the same time pleasing, the ground work being a pale pink, lighted up with, and enriched with light blue and gold. Messrs. LAWRENCE B. VALK and W.G. LORD are the builders of the "Hippotheatron." Take it altogether, it is one of the most completely arranged establishments for the purpose that the ingenuity of show givers in this country has invented, and it will speedily take is position among the popularities of the City.

abstract: The rebels of North Carolina, who had been for some time threatening an attack upon Newbern, put their threat in execution on Tuesday last. A dispatch from Gen. BUTLER says that on the 2d inst, the enemy seized the railroad between...
lead_paragraph: The rebels of North Carolina, who had been for some time threatening an attack upon Newbern, put their threat in execution on Tuesday last. A dispatch from Gen. BUTLER says that on the 2d inst, the enemy seized the railroad between Newbern and Morehead City, and captured the gunboat Underwriter, which they destroyed. A dispatch one day later announces, however, that the rebels did not hold their ground, but retired to Kinston. As long as the river is kept open from Newbern to Pamlico Sound, our forces there are not in special danger.

abstract: The proposition to revive the military grade of Lieutenant-General, with the view of conferring the title on Gen. GRANT, commands the hearty approval of the country; and if the purpose of the resolution which has...
lead_paragraph: The proposition to revive the military grade of Lieutenant-General, with the view of conferring the title on Gen. GRANT, commands the hearty approval of the country; and if the purpose of the resolution which has passed the House of Representatives was simply to confer a great honor on one who has greatly served his country, few would question its entire propriety. We do not think much of the argument of some of the members opposed to the resolution, that, as the war is not yet over, it would be better to wait till the finale and see whose head towers above all others, and then give him the crown. The services of Gen. GRANT have already been so signal as to merit a signal honor; and we should be willing to see it become a law that any General, who shall take a hundred thousand prisoners and four hundred pieces of artillery, shall thereby be entitled to the rank of Lieutenant-General. We have always held that our military hierarchy is entirely too restricted; it was arranged for the cadre of the insignificant army we have hitherto kept on foot; and we should be glad to see. not only the revival of the grade of Lieutenant-General, but the creation of the still higher grade of General, as prizes held out to the laudable ambition of commanders, and as a proper extension of the military hierarchy, to meet the vast proportions of our military organism.

abstract: The memory of OLIVER GOLDSMITH has at last received due honor in his native country. On the 5th of January, Mr. FOLEY'S statue of the poet, was inaugurated by the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland (CARLISIE) and a company consisting of the Lord Chancellor, the Judges, the authorities of Trinity College, and most of the distinguished residents of the Irish Capital.
lead_paragraph: -- The memory of OLIVER GOLDSMITH has at last received due honor in his native country. On the 5th of January, Mr. FOLEY'S statue of the poet, was inaugurated by the Lord Lieutenant of Ireland (CARLISIE) and a company consisting of the Lord Chancellor, the Judges, the authorities of Trinity College, and most of the distinguished residents of the Irish Capital. When the green drapery which covered the statue was withdrawn, Lord CARLISLR, in eloquent address, characterized the poet and humanist so dear to English Literature. Apropos to the locality of the statue he said: "Here, in front of his own University, when he was the obscure sizar -- but when he has given occasion to every sizar since, to feel proud of his position, -- even here,, where we are told that be was laid prostrate by his brutal tutor Mr. WILDLR -- the goodliest of the city -- rank, amiability, talent, and beauty are gathered around the first statue to pay honor to his genius, before London has erected a single statue In the open air to any of England's mighty bards." A companion statue to EDMUND BURKR, is proposed to be erected by the City of Dublin, and will doubtless soon be executed.

abstract: A gentleman direct from Wilmington informs the Petersburgh Express that "the enemy now have 26 vessels blockading that port. These vessels are scattered for a mile or two off the mouth of the Cape Fear, and guard all the avenues of approach with the most sleepless vigilance. The consequences are that the chancel of running the blockade have been greatly lessened, and it is apprehended by some that the day is not far distant when it will be an impossibility for a vessel to get into that port without incurring a hazard almost equivalent to positive loss."

abstract: Yesterday afternoon Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest at the New-York Hospital on the body of WM. SMITH, the man who was shot by DANIEL BROOKS at the saloon of JOHN H. McKINLEY, No. 93 South-street, at an early hour on Tuesday morning last, a pretty full account of which has been published in the TIMES.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon Coroner NAUMANN held an inquest at the New-York Hospital on the body of WM. SMITH, the man who was shot by DANIEL BROOKS at the saloon of JOHN H. McKINLEY, No. 93 South-street, at an early hour on Tuesday morning last, a pretty full account of which has been published in the TIMES. Below we give all the testimony that is material in the case, and also the verdict of the jury. There is considerable interest manifested in regard to the matter in certain circles, and this arises no doubt from the fact that the prisoner, DANIEL BROOKS, is known to be a man of some wealth and position in society.

abstract: Circulation among Rebels Important
snippet: Circulation among Rebels Important
lead_paragraph: A HINT TO OUR GENERALS. Nothing could more forcibly evince the dangerous importance which the rebel leaders attach to the President's Amnesty Proclamation than the conspicuous omission of its publication in the rebel papers. This enjoys the distinction of being the only document of the war which has not been promptly seized and reproduced in their journals. Even the President's Proclamation of Emancipation received wide circulation in the rebel press, for it was relied on as an addition to their stock of fuel for "firing the Southern heart," while it was safe from the eyes of the class immediately interested in it. But the Amnesty Proclamation has not been reproduced in a single rebel paper. It has, indeed, been spoken about plentifully, but with such utter perversions of its scope and terms as to very clearly indicate the dread inspired by the thought of the real article finding its way among the masses of the people and the armies. Now this significant circumstance makes it all the more incumbent on the Generals commanding along the front of the great rebel armies to use every effort in giving the widest possible introduction of this dreaded document within the rebel lines. By a strange oversight of our commanders, this important matter has been but little attended to. Gen. Foster seems to have tried its effect in East Tennessee, and the amusing letter, which it called forth from LONGSTREET, adds strong confirmation of the fear the rebel leaders have of its circulation. The chivalric LONGSTRET is under the impression that the diffusion of this kind of useful knowledge among his soldiers is a breach of military etiquette. "We fear that perhaps it is open to that frightful imputation; but as business of killing men is rather a breach of etiquette anyhow, we think we shall survive this stigma. The fair retaliation would be, for the rebels to get up a similar proclamation of amnesty, promising pardon to all the deluded Yankee soldiers who may be disposed to come into the Confederate lines. If they see fit to do so, we will promise to give it all the circulation they could desire and we don't see why they should be so ungallant as to refuse to reciprocate. In the meantime, we trust our Generals will omit no opportunity to send the document into the rebel lines. Every picket guard should be provided with copies of it, and the scouts might sow the seed by the wayside. It is the unanimous testimony of deserters, that were the terms of the President's offer of amnesty generally known among the rebel rank and file, thousands would avail themselves of the first occasion to come over to our side. It was, if we remember rightly, a device of ancient warfare for setting fire to combustible stuff within the enemy's lines, to send in bulls on whose horns firebrands were fastened. The Amnesty Proclamation would prove a still more formidable firebrand to the rebels; and it is a realizing sense of this that makes the leaders so particularly punctilious on the point of "etiquette."

abstract: RECRUITING IN BROOKLYN. Recruiting was pretty good yesterday in this city. Thirty-four men were enlisted, of which three only were veterans. The members of the Forty-eight regiment have nearly all been paid. Some few stragglers are still entitled to their bounty, and will be paid as soon as they make their appearance.
lead_paragraph: RECRUITING IN BROOKLYN. -- Recruiting was pretty good yesterday in this city. Thirty-four men were enlisted, of which three only were veterans. The members of the Forty-eight regiment have nearly all been paid. Some few stragglers are still entitled to their bounty, and will be paid as soon as they make their appearance. A number of the Sixty-seventh regiment -- some thirty-four who had been enlisted for New-York, have been transferred to Kings County, at their own regiment, and will be paid the bounty to which they are entitled to-day. The funds appropriated to pay these bounties have nearly been exhausted. There are still sufficient for a day or two, when more will be procured. The Forty-seventh regiment, it is reported, is coming home on furlough. They, like the Forty-eighth, participated in the siege of Fort Wagner, and other engagements in the department, under command, respectively, of Gen., GILLMORE, HUNTER and SHREMAN. The Forty-seventh was mostly recruited in this city.

abstract: Bacon, Francis, Works of, Collected by Spedding, Ellis >amp; Heath
snippet: Bacon, Francis, Works of, Collected by Spedding, Ellis >amp; Heath
lead_paragraph: Let us, in the beginning, give a word of cordial praise to the American publishers of these splendid volumes. The undertaking, in the first place, was an intellectual compliment to the country. It was based on the faith that there is in this country enough of philosophy and scholarship to justify a new and complete edition of the writings which one of the greatest thinkers that ever lived has left to the world as his immortal legacy. When the edition was first undertaken, times were quiet, and the peace, the prosperity, the regular, permanent economy of the nation did not seem to be seriously threatened. There was, indeed, a small cloud in the sky, a low, grumbling noise in the air -- yet none but a prophet could have seen in that cloud the commencement of the thick gloom which has since encompassed us in its darkness, or heard in the murmur of the grumbling noise the coming of the tem-pest which has since shaken our political institutions almost to their foundations. But, amidst all this fear, trouble and uncertainty, the publication of BACON'S works has been continued, with only necessary interruptions. We praised the intelligence which commenced the publication, and we still more praise the courage which has continued it, until it is now given in its fullness to the public. Never before has the public of the civilized world -- and that is BACON'S public -- had a more complete view and exposition of BACON'S mind. Of the several editors, each is perfect in his own department; and it would seem now as if all the materials were collected, which are necessary to a full and fair judgment on BACON'S personal character and philosophical genius.
headline: {'main': 'LORD BACON.; THE WORKS OF FRANCIS BACON, collected and edited by JAMES SPEDDING, ROBERT LESLIE ELLIS and DOUGLAS DENON HEATH. lead_paragraph: The U.S. steamer Flambeau, Acting Volunteer Lieut. E. CAVENDY commanding, arrived at this port last evening from the South Atlantic Blockading Squadron, having left Charleston Bar on the night of the 1st inst. She comes North for repairs. While on the passage she encountered heavy weather and northwest gales. She has been absent from this port for more than seventeen months, most of which time has been passed in blockade duty. She brings about 50 seamen whose time has expired.

abstract: The steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the 23d, via Queenstown on the 24th ult., bringing two days' later news than that received by the Jura, at Portland, arrived at Halifax early yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the 23d, via Queenstown on the 24th ult., bringing two days' later news than that received by the Jura, at Portland, arrived at Halifax early yesterday morning. There is nothing particularly new in the advices. No change had taken place in the aspect of the Schleswig-Holstein question. A telegram from Kiel says that in consequence of the "thaw," the Danish outposts had been ordered to retire on the advance of the Prussian troops. It is expected that the Danes will defend Dannewicke stubbornly. The Prussian Chambers have adopted a resolution opposing the policy of Prussia in separating herself from the other German States, and threatening resistance thereto. The Emancipation Society in London had given a farewell breakfast to GEORGE THOMPSON, who is about to visit the United States, at which they passed resolutions complimentary to him and expressing their sympathy with the country in its effort to restore the Union on the basis of freedom to the slaves of the South. The Mexican deputation of Notables, who returned to Mexico for the purpose of obtaining: guarantees from the chief Mexican cities of their desire to be ruled by the Archduke MAXMILIAN, were expected to return to France during the first fortnight of the current month. The Archduke would then assume the sceptre and visit Paris in the quality of Emperor. The Epoca, of Madrid, announces that the Spanish Government will appoint a Minister to Mexico as soon as it receives official information of the crowning of Maximilian. News from Japan says that Prince Satsuma refuses to pay the indemnity demanded by the English until they shall evacuate Yokohama. This they are not willing to do, and have sent for reinforcements.

abstract: An inquest was held yesterday at the New-York Hospital, on the body of WM. SMITH, the barkeeper of the saloon No. 93 South-street, who was fatally shot by DANIEL BROOKS, at an early hour on Tuesday morning last. The Jury found a verdict against BROOKS, who was committed to the Tombs to await the action of the Grand Jury. He is reputed to be a man of wealth and position, and this doubtless accounts for the interest that has been manifested in his behalf in certain circles.

abstract: Taylor, Jeremy, Selections from Works of; Familiar Quotations, with Index; Ouede's Held in Bondage--a Novel; Prime, Rev. S. I. Five Years of Prayer
snippet: Taylor, Jeremy, Selections from Works of; Familiar Quotations, with Index; Ouede's Held in Bondage--a Novel; Prime, Rev. S. I. Five Years of Prayer
lead_paragraph: The design of this elegantly-printed volume is quite unique. Instead of offering, like other dictionaries of quotations, a collection of, "elegant extracts" on selected subjects, its aim is to ascertain the paternity of the current phrases and passages familiar to the ear of every one, but whose origin is generally lost sight of and forgotten from their very adoption into the body of the written and spoken language of ordinary literary and social intercourse. Its execution implies an amount of reading perfectly appalling to think of. The whole series 'of British classics, from SHAKESPEARE, BACON and HOOKER, to TENNYSON and Mrs. BROWNING, must have been gone over and "contents noted," (in mercantile phraseology) whenever the familiar word or sentence was met with. It is a curious study to observe what authors have most enriched the language with this current mental coinage -- this verbal mintage which is recognized by all as sterling. SHAKESPEARE, of course, stands first in amount, one hundred pages are taken up with the recital of his contributions to the stock of popular allusions, quotations and references. The English version of the Bible is one of the other most copious sources, and of modern poets ALEXANDER POPS ranks highest. occupying thirty-four pages, while twenty suffice for MILTON, six for YOUNG, nine for COWPER, twelve for WORDSWORTH, six for THOMAS MOORE, and seventeen for LORD BYRON. In thus tracing home the waifs and strays of literature, the editor (who is understood to be an accomplished bookseller of Boston,) has done a real service to letters, and his little manual should be on the desks of all who are studious of correctness, and conscientious in the matter of giving credit to whom credit is properly due. To that much enduring class, the editors of popular newspapers, who are expected to answer all the questions of their correspondents, from some encyclopedic fount of knowledge, this book must be a perfect treasure. There need be no further difficulty experienced in deciding in a moment to whom belong "When Greek meets Greek," &c., (LEE;) "Welcome the coming, speed the parting guest," (POPE;) "Comparisons are odorous," (SHAKESPEARE;) "No pent up Utica," & c, (SEWALL;) and the thousand and one other quotations of as general acceptance, whose source has long been the subject of wager, discussions, and disputes innumerable. A reference to the admirable verbal index of this book will settle all such questions at once and forever.

abstract: -- The following schedule of prices for making and repairing boots and shoes is charged at an establishment in Richmond which is generally overrun with orders: "For making boots, $225; for footing boots, $140; for ordinary cavalry boots, $250; for gaiters, $110; for high lace shoes, $100; for Oxford ties, $90; for fixing, half-soling and heeling boots, $62; for half-soling and heeling boots, $20; ditto shoes, $18; for new gores to gaiters, 110; for half soling boots or shoes, $12; for heeling do., $8. If calf-skins are furnished, the charge will be for making boots, $120; shoes, $60. Where it will not be possible to fill an order in the course of four weeks from the time it is taken, no price will be set, but the price will be fixed at the time of delivery."

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- VERDI'S opera, "I Due Fos???ari," was given here last night with good effect. The music is not very pronounced in its character, and to ears accustomed to VERDI'S later works it is apt to sound tame. There are, however, some admirable numbers in it, and passages of great suavity and grace. The principal role was admirably sustained by Signor BELLINI, who combines talent as an actor with great vocal ability, M???e MEDORI was the Lucretia, and Signor MASSOLENI was admirable.

abstract: Hon. T. Stevens' Speech; Speech on Confiscation Bill
snippet: Hon. T. Stevens' Speech; Speech on Confiscation Bill
lead_paragraph: Hon. THADDEUS STEVENS is not only one of the ablest, but, in his way, is one of the most patriotic members of the, House. We have not a doubt that his heart throbs as earnestly as any man's for the national prosperity and glory. Nobody would feel more wronged in being called a Secessionist. Yet were we to judge him by his recent speech in the House on the Confiscation Bill, we could not possibly avoid the conclusion that he is a Secessionist; and, what is more, that he acknowledges the independence of "the Confederacy" -- the very thing which our Government has declared it would make a casus belli against England and France, if done by them.

abstract: Thiers' M.; Speech--Liberty in
snippet: Thiers' M.; Speech--Liberty in
lead_paragraph: The speech of M. THIERS, in the French Corps Legislatif, treating of the actual political condition of France, and already the subject of dis- cussion in these columns, gives us a glimpse of her future, from which nobody who is interested in her progress can derive much satisfaction. It is impossible on laying it down to avoid asking, as so many of the best men in France have been asking for so long, what she has gained by all the changes through which she has gone in the last eighty years, except the reduction of all ranks and classes to the same level before the law. This was no doubt an immense gain, but it was achieved before a drop of innocent blood had been shed. The nobles had lost their privileges before the revolution had entered on its sanguinary phase, and all the troubles, and turmoil, and broils, and mortal anxieties, loss of life and loss of treasure, which Frenchmen have since suffered, would seem on M. THIERS showing to have been utterly wasted. It does not appear, as we remarked a few weeks ago, that a subject of Louis NAPOLEON enjoys a single legal guarantee for life, liberty or property, as against the Government, which the subjects of Louis XIV. did not enjoy. He is better off, it is true, better fed, and better clothed, and possesses general exemption from gross tyranny and outrage, but this is due to the general progress of the world in humanity, and the greater force of public opinion, which has been bred by greater publicity to politics, properly so called. France is to-day very much what it was in 1700.
headline: {'main': "M. Thier's Speech Progress of Political Liberty in France.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "M. Thier's Speech Progress of Political Liberty in France.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Police Boat No. 1, Capt. James TODD, commanding has become a feature of our harbor. Although a very modest and unassuming little craft, more real service has been accomplished by her and her active crew consisting of twelve men during the last two years she has been in commission, than by any other branch of the City government, requiring no greater outlay.
lead_paragraph: Police Boat No. 1, Capt. James TODD, commanding has become a feature of our harbor. Although a very modest and unassuming little craft, more real service has been accomplished by her and her active crew consisting of twelve men during the last two years she has been in commission, than by any other branch of the City government, requiring no greater outlay. The vessel is: extreme length, 105 feet; breadth of beam, 33 feet; depth of hold, 12 feet, and is one hundred and thirty tons burden, the engine being very powerful for the steamer's size. The arrangements of the boat are admirably adapted to the business in which she is engaged. In its forward part is located a powerful double steam fire-pump, to which can be made two attachments, and from which immense streams of water can be thrown upon any fire within reasonable distance. Upon this pump hag depended the safety of a large amount of property at the different fires which have occurred along the river. The recent extensive conflagration of piers and shipping on the North River was checked in its progress by the Police boat, which for more than thirty hours was actively engaged throwing water on the flames, tearing down piers, scuttling vessels, and dragging burning craft to the middle of the stream. Thousands on thousands of dollars were in this manner saved to the owners of property in the vicinity of the fire. This is only one instance out of very many where the police-boat has rendered invaluable service in checking extensive fires. Frequently warehouses are so situated along the docks as to make it almost impossible for engines to reach them. In such cases, when a fire occurs, the principal reliance is upon the police-boat. This little vessel is also of great service in cases of collision, mutinies and ships on fire in the bay. In her connection with such matters, so well has she become known to our merchants, that when the slightest thing occurs on shipboard she is at once noticed by them, or the Captains of vessels hoist the usual signal of distress -- Union down. Within the last two years the brave officers and men of the Police-boat have been present at, and quelled, some of the most desperate and bloody multnies that have ever taken place in our harbor. Besides the steamer, there are two small boats which are kept in active operation in saving lives of parties falling overboard, and in search of river-thieves. These river-thieves, who for some time, inconsequence of numerous arrests, became rather shy have again ventured out more boldly than ever. Our River Police find in this class of thieves a more dangerous body of men to contend with than has and existence on land. They have bouts, and sometimes go in gangs of eight and ten, with a view to the wholesale plunder of vessels lying in the stream. When interrupted in their operations, they make a most desperate resistance. They are generally well armed, and fight under cover of darkness as coolly and with as much persistence as a cand of pirates. There are frequently disturbances on ships as they are about sailing, in consequence of the drunken condition of seamen shipped by boarding-house keepers. On such occasions it frequently becomes the duty of the Harbor Police to iron the men until they get sober.

abstract: The annual festival of our City Teachers' Association on Saturday evening, in the hall of the Board of Education, corner of Grand and Elm streets, was an occasion of much interest, and deserves more than the brief notices given of it.
lead_paragraph: The annual festival of our City Teachers' Association on Saturday evening, in the hall of the Board of Education, corner of Grand and Elm streets, was an occasion of much interest, and deserves more than the brief notices given of it. President NICHOLS, of the Free Academy, occupied the chair. Many of the prominent teachers of the City, several members of the Board of Education, and distinguished friends of education were present. Columbia College, the Free Academy and the Common Schools were well represented.

abstract: The stated meeting of the Managers was held at the Bible-house, Astor-place, on Thursday, the 4th inst., at 3 1/2 P. M., WM, B. CROSBY, Esq., in the Chair, assisted by BENJ. L. SWAN, JAMES LENOX and FRANCIS HALL, Esqs. The decease of Rev. GEORGE SHELTON, a member of the Board, was announced, whereupon Rt. Rev. Bishop LEE, of Iowa, read the 90th Psalm and offered prayer. Two new auxiliaries were recognized: one in Indiana, the other in Iowa. Communications were received from the Maryland Bible Society, respecting their hearty cooperation In the work of this Institution, and commending Its action in relation to the distribution of the Scriptures in the South; from the United States Christian Commission, with an account of the distribution of books granted by this society, amounting to 568,275 volumes; from Rev. JAMES HICKEY, Monterey, with an account of Bible work in Mexico; from Rev. L. S. JACOBY, Bremen, asking permission to use funds granted by this society, to make stereotype plates of the Testament and Psalms, which was granted; from Rev. J. J. AUDEBEZ, Paris, Secretary of the French find Foreign Bible Society, requesting the transmission of funds already appropriated but not paid; from Rev. S. VAN DISBELL., Curacoa, seeding the Gospei by Luke In the Creoles' language, and requesting its publication, which was granted; from Rev. I. G. BLISS, Constantinople, in regard to funds required for Bible work the coming year, and in regard to the further printing of the Scriptures. Grants of books were made, amounting to nearly 70,000 volumes. They were for distribution in Richmond and Georgia; to Confederate pris ???ers at Johnston's Island and Columbus; for camps and hospitals in the army, for contrabands in Virginia; to the Christian Commission; for Ven. Zuela and Lima, S. A.: with several smaller grants, including twelve volumes, in raised letters, for the blind. In money, $.2, 600 were granted to the American and Foreign Christ an Union, for the distribution of the Scriptures in Italy, Greece, and elsewhere. An agent was appointed for Nebraska and Dacotah Territories, and another for South America. The meeting was unusually large and interesting.

abstract: Corinth was evacuated, as before announced, on Monday last, everything of value in that section being brought to Memphis. The Memphis and Charleston Railroad, which was at the same time abandoned east of Lagrange, will to-night be evacuated from Lagrange to Memphis.

abstract: Fair at N. Y.
snippet: Fair at N. Y.
lead_paragraph: The fair in behalf of the Sanitary Commission, which is to open in Brooklyn on the 22d inst., is the fourth of that series of fairs which are being held in the great cities of our country, Chicago, Cincinnati, Boston, have each, in their turn, shown what they could do in this way for the soldier, and now Brooklyn is to take her turn. She has not hitherto shown herself backward in good works, and we presume she will not now. Her citizens propose to raise at least a quarter of a million dollars, and they are all united heartily in the work. They are putting; up temporary buildings in connection with the Academy of -Music, in which the fair is to he held, and lumbermen send material as their gift, and carpenters furnish their days labor as their contribution. On every hand is to be heard nothing but preparations for the fair. Churches and Sabbath schools, and private schools and private individuals give money and time, and labor and thought, to make the affair a grand success.

abstract: In a letter from Flensburg we have the following account of the "Dannewerk," the great bulwark of Schleswig: "The Dannewerk is of very ancient origin. It is situate at the extreme southern part of the ??? of Schleswig, and is now an enormous earthwork that stretches almost across the entire country. The length of the peninsula of Schleswig-Holstein to the end of Jutland, is said to be near three hundred miles; so that it extends almost us far as the base line of our country, from the North Foreland to Land's End. The bread III of the pe???, however, is but one-third of its length, and the D ??? is a ???fication that reaches very nearly across the land from the German Ocean to the Baltic. This 'border wall' is said to have been erected in the ninth century, and. according to the accounts given of it in ??? Saga,' it was built of wood, stone and earth. in the year 937 the wall, we are told, was strengthened by Queen Turn*, whom the people, in their thankfulness for the national defence, christened Danabod, which, literally translated, means the pride of the Danes; and, as a proof of the extreme antiquity of the structure, 1 have myself seen at Fle???burg a splendid collection of flint arrow-heads and axes which have been collected from the barrows or earth mounds in the immediate neighborhood. There were spear points wrought out of splinters of flint no thicker than paper knives, and worked sharper than the best steel. Here, too, we were shown the knuckle-bone-like stones which had been used to separate the line layers of sil???eous earth from the solid mass, and which were found embedded in these same barrows with the very flint chip beside them that the people, thousands of years before, had broken from the integrel block. Here, moreover, we saw the slabs of stone that the old Celts had used to grind their spearheads on to the sharpest possible points, grooved with the toils of the workmen, and seeming as if they were destined to tell the present age how this wonderfully fine workmanship of the hardest possible material was executed. Indeed, in this collection of works long precedent to history, I saw arrow-heads made out of ??? hardly thicker than mother-of-pearl, and wrought as sharp as a needle. The fortress consists at the present day (without going into all the niceties of historical detail) of three enormous earthworks stretching across the entire breadth of the land; they are so arranged as to form the neck, or funnel, with a long outwork to protect the narrow channel through which the troops are ultimately intended to be driven. Toward the Baltic, or East Sea, there runs the 'Oster-Wolden' (or east rampart;) this lies toward the 'Eckenforde,' and is sometimes called the 'Camel-Dannewerk.' It is about two English miles long, the earthworks being from four feet to five feet high, and sixteen yards broad, and beset with a ???, the depth of which varies from six feet to ten feet. Beyond this is the great bay formed by the river Schley, which is so wide that no troops could possibly attempt to pass it. Stretching immediately in front of this is the 'Kurgraben,' which is upwards of a mile in length, beginning at the end of the Selker Lake; it is from 10 feet to 12 feet broad, and from 4 feet to 6 feet high. Behind this lies the great 'Dannewark' itself, which consists of an earthwork net less than 14 miles long. In some parts it is from 30 feet to 30 feet high, and the ramparts are from 16 feet to 20 feet broad. The whole of these earthworks are immediately in connection from one side of the peninsula to the other, with the river Treene, which fall into the Northern Ocean; so that the Danish forces have it within their power to flood not less than 64 square miles of land in front of the great bulwark of Schleswig at a moment's notice. 'But,' said the Saxon soldiers to the writer, 'what are the uses of the sluice-gates in this time of frost?' On talking with the Danish engineers, however, they told us they had flooded the country a fortnight before with the, thinnest pellicle of ice, and let the water out immediately afterwards, so that any troops attempting to cross the country would be mowed down by the artillery like corn. Indeed, from what I heard during ??? is not the least doubt that 40,000 men could hold the Dannewerk against 100,001 opposing troops; and from what I saw myself of the fortifications, and heard from the engineers as to the means of flooding the country, either with a thin sheet of ice or???slough of water, I am convinced that it would require as strong an army as united Germany could possibly muster to wrest Schleswig from Denmark."

abstract: At about 6 o'clock last evening a most destructive fire broke out in the large six-story building known As the Empire Works, situated on East Twenty-fourth-street, running through to Twenty-
lead_paragraph: At about 6 o'clock last evening a most destructive fire broke out in the large six-story building known As the Empire Works, situated on East Twenty-fourth-street, running through to Twenty-fifth-street, which, before it could be extinguished, resulted in the entire destruction of the building and contents. The fire originated on the sixth floor of the building, in the drying-room of the twine factory of R. HOLDEN, and spread through the whole building with fearful rapidity, enveloping everything it could reach in destruction. Owing to the great height of the premises, it was found almost impossible to throw water on the burning building, and it was owing to the almost superhuman exertions of the firemen that the flames were prevented from spreading to the adjoining buildings. At one time it was thought that the fire would be prevented from spreading below the third floor, but toe flames, defying all efforts to check them, spread on all through the premises. The contents will prove an entire toss to the occupants. The following is a hot of the occupants of the building and their losses:

abstract: The steamship Ocean Queen from Aspinwall, Jan. 29, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing $365,938 in specie, and putting us in possession of our correspondence from the States of Central and South America.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Ocean Queen from Aspinwall, Jan. 29, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing $365,938 in specie, and putting us in possession of our correspondence from the States of Central and South America. A treaty of peace has been concluded between New-Grenada and Ecuador, and good feeling is again established. There are rumors of a threatened disturbance between Peru and Spain, relative to the murder of some Spanish subjects in the interior. A curious step had been taken by the United States Consul at Callao, who had given the American flag to a foreign steam vessel/which it was generally understood had been purchased from the British by Gen. MOSQUERA, to be used in the war against Ecuador. The Peruvian Government have detained her. Two thousand one hundred corpses had been taken from the ruins of the burned church at Santiago. Many other lives were lost, and the bodies were utterly destroyed.

abstract: The Paris correspondent of the Post says: "Skating is becoming a courtly amusement beyond the ice-bound regions or the North. Whilst Royal ???nesses are skating in France. It will hence forward be necessary that persons, from chamberlains down to powdered footmen, should know how to dance attendance not m???rely in withdrawing and reception halls, but on the slippery frozen floors of lakes and ponds. Yesterday (Sunday) a new set of courtiers and household servants surrounded their Imperial Majesties, who again honored the small lake. In addition to the usual park company assembled on such occasions, the waters were surrounded by a number of the fashionable world, who evidently expected the imperial party, the court circle arriving about three o'clock. Already the skaters had mustered pretty strongly. There were German, English, American, and one or two French ladies gliding about with men companions, and there were sledges driven swiftly onward by cavaliers of the ice, containing those of the fair sex who were born in days when the ladies of France did nothing gymnastic but dance. How shall I describe the skating modes of Paris? Most of the lair creatures wear a pretty round hat, with a red or white wing, or feathers, and a veil which incites the curiosity of youthful imagination. Any gay-colored jacket, of any cut, decorated with any description of fur, is allowed; and very pretty it is to observe the animated patches of red, violet, blue, white, and black, darting about amid the gloomy great-coats and ugly caps and hats or the men. But to continue my description of the ladies' costume. Now comes the difficulty, to describe the toilette, costume, dress, robes, modes -- how ought it to be called? -- of what comes below the jackets, casaques, polonaises, paletots -- how ought such things also to be called? Well, that portion of female covering which begins after the waist, and in our day assumes awful proportions before it hides the feet, is in the ice ??? of Paris drawn up in festoons by unseen mysterious mechanical aid, leaving, (and here again I feel a difficulty) very visible nearly a whole pair of stockings which may be red or black, or, if ??? use the word in such a place, 'fancy.' Then comes the Polish boots, and then the silver skates. My limited descriptive powers are hap-??? longer required; out ??? such ??? toilettes do not lead to holy matrimony, men's hearts are ??? as well as the waters of the Bo??? it should be observed, in the Parisian polite world is only beginning to be ??? Switzerland and England; but whereionable. The Emperor, no doubt, learned to skate in Switzerland and England; but where did the ??? learn to glide-over the ice so ??? in a pretty ??? costume, and appealing ??? with the sport, her Majesty several times, accompanied by two gentlemen not in waiting, but in going, skated amongst the moving multitude, whist the little Imperial Puree and heir to the throne, was showing the crowd of spectators on shore that be had already become familiar with this slippery world and its accidents. There may be those who, sunning on the shores of the Mediterranean, think with ??? just now of us living in more Northern climes; but with such a scene as I have attempted to describe --

abstract: JOSEPH LEENY was placed at the bar yesterday morning, and plead guilty to an indictment for burglary in the fourth degree. Judge RUSSELL said that the crime which he had been guilty of was alarmingly on the increase, and it was the determination of the court to punish all who were found guilty of burglary with severity. The prisoner, however, had presented evidence of good character. He had fought bravely in the army and been discharged honorably. The judgment of he Court would be suspended and the prisoner was discharged.

abstract: The Panama Railroad Company's steamship Guatemala arrived at Panama on the 21st from Central American ports. She has but little cargo for New-York, most of it being destined for England.
lead_paragraph: The Panama Railroad Company's steamship Guatemala arrived at Panama on the 21st from Central American ports. She has but little cargo for New-York, most of it being destined for England. The dates from Guatemala are to the 10th, Salvador to the 15th, Nicaragua to the 16th, and Costa Rica to the 19th inst. The Central American States are all quiet, with the exception of Honduras, which is in confusion, in consequence of the rival claims of three persons for the Presidency in the place of Gen. GUARDIOLA, who was assassinated a year or two since, The preterit acting President had removed the Capital to the Gity of Gracias, for greater security in the coming contest.

abstract: There are two or three additions pretty certain to be made shortly to the lists of the London clubs. A junior Atheneum has been long talked of. The old club is not only full, but so many names are put down for ballot that a new candidate can form no reasonable hope of obtaining admission for several years.

abstract: We regret to have to record the death of Mr. DUDLEY PERSSE, a well-known and highly esteemed merchant of this City, which event took place at his residence be???c, on Friday last. Mr. PERSSE was a younger member of a family holding high position and large estates in the County of Galway, Ireland. When very young he emigrated to this country to do the battle of life, and by his industry and enterprise raised himself to the position of head of the house of PERSSE & BROOKS, paper merchants. Mr. PERSSE was a man of most generous and kindly nature, and his death will be regretted by a large circle of friends, to whom his many noble qualities of heart most warmly endeared him. The funeral will take place from St. Bartholomew's, conner of Great Jones-street and Lafayette-place, at 2 o'clock.

abstract: We have additional correspondence from Newborn, N.C., giving details of the rebel demonstration there on the 1st and 2d instant, and the destruction of the gunboat Underwriter.
lead_paragraph: We have additional correspondence from Newborn, N.C., giving details of the rebel demonstration there on the 1st and 2d instant, and the destruction of the gunboat Underwriter. The enemy's movement was an utter surprise, and they showed much boldness in the execution of their plans. At the time our correspondent wrote affairs looked very badly respecting our ability to hold the city, but later advices received by telegraph, and published yesterday, showed the rebel advantage was of temporary duration, and that their forces had retired.

abstract: Senator SHAFER introduced a bill amending the several acts relating to the above companies, ordering that it shall not be lawful for any person to act within this State as agent for any company incorporated under laws of any other State Government, unless such company is possessed of the amount of actual capital required by the
lead_paragraph: Senator SHAFER introduced a bill amending the several acts relating to the above companies, ordering that it shall not be lawful for any person to act within this State as agent for any company incorporated under laws of any other State Government, unless such company is possessed of the amount of actual capital required by the sixth section of the act relating to such companies and the same is invested in stocks or Treasury notes of the United States or this Slate, or of the State in which such company is located, or in such securities as bonds, mortgages, &c., as are receivable by the Bank. Department; but all mortgages so deposited by any company under this section shall be upon real estate worth 75 per cent, more than the amount loaned thereon; such stocks. &c., &c., to be deposited with the chief financial officer of the State incorporating the company, and this State must be furnished with the certificate of such Auditor that he holds in trust for the benefit of the policy holders the securities before mentioned.

abstract: A correspondent of the Missouri Democrat, writing from Fayetteville, Ark., gives the following account of the meaning of a word of very common use, as applied by the native Arkansians: "The country has long since been emptied of corn and oats, and no roughness is to be had. This word roughness is an old one with, to me at least, a new application. In conversation with officers and others, I have remarked the bad condition of their horses, and they invariably accounted for it by saying 'We have some corn, but no roughness.' To look at the horse frames and equine Shadows bridled and saddled, or the corrals of animals gnawing rail fences, turned in to die, one would think they wanted something in addition to roughness. Solders on half rations 'can't see it;' dependent on the charity of the everything upon which rather be without it; and everything upon which their eye rests gives no evident of a scarcity of ???ness. To hear a sensible man account for the famishing of horses and cattle which hare been starved because they couldn't get roughness, is laughable. In fact, there is nothing but roughness here and that's what's killing the stock. That you may know the use of the term, I will explain that may they (not the horses) understand it, is used in speaking of hay, straw forage, or anything but ???ness."

abstract: This distinguished Indian warrior, Chief of the Majoves, Wallapas, Toutos, Apaches and Chimanavas, arrived last evening at the Metropolitan Hotel, accompanied by Capt. JOHN MOSS, from California, on the steamer Ocean Queen. IRATABA commands 9,000 warriors, who live mostly in Arizona Territory. The Chief is a splendid specimen of physical development. He is about fifty years of age, six feet two inches in height, and very muscular. Although for a long time a terror to white settlers, he has within the last few years become very friendly. His battles with our soldiers and fights with hostile tribes are said to have been conducted with an extraordinary degree of generalship. IRATABA comes North, using his own expression, "to see where so many pale faces come from." He proposes spending a few days in this City, when he will visit Boston, Philadelphia. Baltimore, and finally take his departure West, returning home by the overland route.

abstract: Chesapeake Case; the
snippet: Chesapeake Case; the
lead_paragraph: The telegraph informs us that the Admirally Court at Halifax has decided to restore the Chesapeake and her cargo to her owners. This decision was expected, and, indeed, it is not easy to see how any other one could have been arrived at. Even if the vessel had been lawfully captured, on the recapture by our forces, the right of the owners would be reinstated, and any claim on the part of the captors would not be listened to by the court. But we do not learn that any such claim was made.

abstract: A number of our merchants hitherto standing in loyal repute, it is rumored, are seriously implicated by the exposures contained in the papers of J. C. RAHMING, who is now enjoying a season or leisure in Fort Lafayette. Surveyor ANDREWS secured the documents, and slowly and reluctantly are they unearthing treason in the shape of participation in blockade-running. Surveyor ANDBEWS, it is said, is determined to get at all the facts, let suffer who may, and has zealously given himself to this end. That somebody will be injured is the current report and belief.

abstract: Greco Conspiracy Against the Emperor
snippet: Greco Conspiracy Against the Emperor
lead_paragraph: Was this a real or a spurious plot? Was it a plot got up by Italian fanatics against the life of the French Emperor, or a plot got up by the Parisian police against French liberty? People are divided in opinion on this subject, but perhaps an epitome of the history of the mysterious affair will best enable us to form a correct conclusion as to its true character. On Christmas Day four Italians, named GRECO, IMPERATORI, FRABUCO and LAGLIO, arrived in Paris, with the intention, according to their subsequent admission, of killing the Emperor. They had each two uncharged shells concealed on their persons, were armed with daggers and revolvers, and possessed cash to the amount of 4,000f. They dallied away their time in the French metropolis till their money was nearly spent, when they bethought themselves of the business which brought them thither; but while they were preparing, or affecting to prepare, for the execution of their crime, the police pounced on them, and the bubble burst. Now who was it that furnished these men with the eight shells and the 4,000f.? Who was it that armed them with daggers and revolvers? Who was it that instigated their to travel from Lugano to Paris, and to attempt the assassination of the ruler of France? If we are to believe their own evidence after arrest, it was GIUSEPPE MAZZINI that supplied them with money and arms, that suggested to them the foul deed, and that invited them to undertake its commission.
headline: {'main': 'The Greco Conspiracy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Greco Conspiracy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A few days since, a soldier was knocked down and robbed of $150 in money, on Riker's Island. The money was subsequently recovered, and, for safe-keeping, it was placed in the hands of Lieut.
lead_paragraph: A few days since, a soldier was knocked down and robbed of $150 in money, on Riker's Island. The money was subsequently recovered, and, for safe-keeping, it was placed in the hands of Lieut. GEORGE KNIGHT, of the United States Army, who is also Assistant Provost-Marshal. While the latter was passing through West Houslon-street, on Friday night last, a young woman, named JAKE WHITE, accosted him, and in her company he. went to a saloon, corner of Houston and Mercer streets. While the two were taking refreshments. the Lieutenant felt the hand or his companion in his pocker. He seized her hand and his pocket-book fell to the floor. Picking it up he thrust it into his pocket without examining to see if any of the contents were missing. Soon after he parted from JANE; a block or two from the place, and then he thought to examine his pocket-book, when he found his money was all missing. He at once pursued her and found her in a saloon in Greene-street. Officer MCPHERSON, of the Eighth Precinct, healing a disturbance mere, went in, and on the representations of the Lieutenant arrested JANE. When they were on the sidewalk the officer noticed something drop from her hand. and on examining it found ii to be $130 of the Lieutenant's money. What, in the meantime she had done with the other $20 does not appear. She was taken before Justice DODGE and committed for trial in default of $1,000 bail.

abstract: three-masted schooner Maria Pike, Capt. LETTS, loaded with 1,300 bales hay, bound to Washington, D.C., and chartered by Government, while hauling from the pier in the North River, at 9 o'clock this morning, was discovered to be on fire, and in less...
lead_paragraph: The three-masted schooner Maria Pike, Capt. LETTS, loaded with 1,300 bales hay, bound to Washington, D.C., and chartered by Government, while hauling from the pier in the North River, at 9 o'clock this morning, was discovered to be on fire, and in less than twenty minutes she was completely enveloped in flames. She was towed in the river, when the police-boat, in charge of Sergt. O'BRIEN, came to her assistance, and immediately got her pumps to work, throwing a copious stream upon the burning vessel. Several of the Harbor Police went on board, and through their utmost exertions succeeded in saving -considerable property, but the inflammable nature of the cargo defied their untiring efforts to save the vessel, and after drifting down the river some distance she was finally scuttled, when she filled, and la now anchored off the Battery. She will probably be a total loss. The vessel is valued at $12,000; her spars and rigging are completely gone, with the exception of about $300 worth, saved by the harbor police-boat. The propellers Columbic and Levis were also at the fire, using their pumps, which threw immense quantities of water into the vessel, but all of no avail.

abstract: This splendid regiment will probably arrive about 2 o'clock to-day. Most extensive arrangements have been made for their reception by the New-York Fire Department. Chief-Engineer DECKER.
lead_paragraph: This splendid regiment will probably arrive about 2 o'clock to-day. Most extensive arrangements have been made for their reception by the New-York Fire Department. Chief-Engineer DECKER has issued a circular to the Foreman of each company, requesting that the Foreman, Assistant Foreman and Fire Delegates be appointed to represent the company on this occasion, to be equipped as follows: red shift, fire cap and dark fire coat, the officers to carry trumpets. The signal notifying the department of the arrival of the regiment will be twenty successive strokes of the fire-alarm bell, repeated three times. The department will form in Cortianct-street, march up Broadway to Fourteenth-street and Eighth-avenue to Hudson-street, down Hudson-street to Clarkson-street through Clarkson and Carmine to Sixth-avenue and Jefferson Market, where a fine collation will be provided them, prepared under the supervision of Chairman HENRY WILSON. The parade will, doubtless, be a very large and fine one; fourteen Engine companies, twelve Hose companies and four Hook and Ladder companies, have already signified their intention to parade, and many others will probably do so. The Zouaves will make Jefferson Market their Headquarters during their stay in this city.

abstract: Maj. MEANS' cavalry battalion, composed mostly of loyal Virginians, residence in Laudon bounty, recently returned from an extensive scout, during which they found no enemy, but discovered that a reign of terror existed among the people of the Loudon and Shenandoah Valleys, in consequence of the execution of the new rebel conscription, which sweeps every. male person, between eighteen and fifty-five, into the rebel army.
lead_paragraph: Maj. MEANS' cavalry battalion, composed mostly of loyal Virginians, residence in Loudon County, recently returned from an extensive scout, during which they found no enemy, but discovered that a reign of terror existed among the people of the Loudon and Shenandoah Valleys, in consequence of the execution of the new rebel conscription, which sweeps every male person, between eighteen and fifty-five, into the rebel army. In view of these conscripting operations outside the enemy's military lines, Gen. SULLIVAN, commanding at Harper's Ferry, had ordered that a Secessionist be arrested, imprisoned, and held as hostage for every loyal man thus conscripted.

abstract: Examiner on the Presidential Election
snippet: Examiner on the Presidential Election
lead_paragraph: The comments of the Richmond Examiner, which we published Saturday, upon the approaching Presidential election at the North, as well as those which are likely to issue in future from the same quarter upon the same subject, will furnish us with the most instructive reading that has yet emanated from the Confederacy. The speculations of the rebels as to what is likely to happen at the North are not of much value, because they rarely know the truth about what is actually occurring amongst us, and never know anything about the feelings of the people. But all that they say as to the effect which our course of action is likely to have on them and their fortunes, as to the influence of our various political changes upon public opinion at the South, is of great value, and ought to be as carefully noted by those who undertake to guide the popular action here, as the information of spies by the Commander-in-Chief.

abstract: The steamship Ocean Queen from Aspinwall, Jan. 29, arrived at this port Saturday, bringing  $365,938 in specie, and later news from the States of Central and South America. A treaty of peace has been concluded between New-Grenada and Ecuador, and good feeling is again established.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Ocean Queen from Aspinwall, Jan. 29, arrived at this port Saturday, bringing $365,938 in specie, and later news from the States of Central and South America. A treaty of peace has been concluded between New-Grenada and Ecuador, and good feeling is again established. There are tumors of a threatened disturbance between Peru and Spain, relative to the murder of some Spanish subjects in the interior. A curious step had been taken by the United States Consul at Callao, who had given the American flag to a foreign 6team vessel, which it was generally understood had been purchased from the British by Gen. MOSQUERA, to be used in the war against Ecuador, The Peruvian Government have detained her. Two thousand one hundred corpses had been taken from the ruins of the burned church at Santiago: Many other lives were lost, and the bodies were utterly destroyed.

abstract: This regiment being now on their way to this City, to enjoy a furlough of thirty days, will arrive here, probably, about Wednesday or Thursday next. The friends of the regiment have made arrangements for a worthy and hearty reception of them.
lead_paragraph: This regiment being now on their way to this City, to enjoy a furlough of thirty days, will arrive here, probably, about Wednesday or Thursday next. The friends of the regiment have made arrangements for a worthy and hearty reception of them. An appropriate fund is being collected by subscriptions, and it is expected that, by the unanimous consent of military and civil organizations, a fine reception will be got up for these brave boys.

abstract: Garibaldi's Address to Italians

abstract: National Banks, Taxes on; State Sovereignty Considered by T. L.
snippet: National Banks, Taxes on; State Sovereignty Considered by T. L.
lead_paragraph: What we call States never were such in the strict sense of the term. There never was a moment in history in which they were independent, sovereign Powers, that is -- according to Mr. LINCOLN'S most true and terse definition -- "having no human power above them." Take the largest of them, or the most historical among them; neither New-York nor Massachusetts were ever sovereign States, like Britain, France, Spain, or even Portugal. They never had a war with any other nation carried on in their own name, and in their own sovereignty; they never had a treaty of peace with another nation, or one of commerce, amity or alliance; they were never acknowledged as sovereignties by any other nation, or ever sought such recognition. To this day, New-York and Pennsylvania have never had conceded to them what, by the law of Nations, has been freely given to Chili, Hayti, and even Liberia. They were not sovereigns before the Revolution; they dill not assume to act as such during the Revolution. No State declared itself independent in its separate capacity. "By the joint declaration in 177G, the colonies held themselves out to the world, and made treaties", not an separate and Independent sovereignties, but as one united nation, known, in that capacity alone', to foreign Powers. "As colonies, they passed from the sovereignty of Great Britain into and under the collective sovereignty of all the similar colonial Powers with whom history and the shaping God of history had connected them. If, at the close of the war which destroyed British sovereignty, any of them had thus attempted to break out of history, on the ground of the absolute right of each part to act for itself, it could only have given the same right to every subordinate municipality included within its asserted independence. It would have been theoretically and actually an entire disintegration. When the great bond of the parent country was loosed, there was no other historical unity, no other sovereignty, than that which had kept them together during the long struggle that resulted in making them a nation collectively -- one sovereignty, known as such to all the other political sovereignties of the world. It was this that had "raised and maintained armies;" it was this that had asserted independence; it was this that received and appointed- Ambassadors; and, finally, it was this that made the treaty of peace, securing the national independence, and so making it for the whole, that even if any part had claimed, and been permitted to stay out, it would only have been to lose ail the benefit of the treaty of recognition, and revert to the old dominion. In short, they emerged from one sovereignty to find themselves under another; and this was the only way in which the civic life could historically have its transmission as one civic life passing from the parent, unbroken in its continuity though changed in form.

abstract: The main building destroyed in the extensive conflagration on Saturday night, an account of which we published in the TIMES of yesterday, was 90 feet front on Twenty-fourth-street, extending 200 feet through to Twenty-fifth-street, and was six stories in height. Mr. LEGGETT, the owner of the building, es-...
lead_paragraph: The main building destroyed in the extensive conflagration on Saturday night, an account of which we published in the TIMES of yesterday, was 90 feet front on Twenty-fourth-street, extending 200 feet through to Twenty-fifth-street, and was six stories in height. Mr. LEGGETT, the owner of the building, estimates his loss on building, machinery and stock of coal at about $150,000. The machinery alone is said to have cost $50,000. The engine was regarded as the largest stationary one in use, being 1,000 horse power. It supplied power not only for the whole of the east wing of Mr. LEGGETT's premises, but also for all the machine-shops and factories in the building known as the Old House of Refuge, situated on the south side of Twenty-fourth-street, the pipes and shafting to supply which being laid under the street. The occupants of these buildings will have to suspend work for want of steam-power. Taking all things into consideration, at least one thousand persons have been thrown out of employment by this conflagration.

abstract: N. Y. Banks, >amp;c., Forced Collection of Taxes
snippet: N. Y. Banks, >amp;c., Forced Collection of Taxes
lead_paragraph: The annexed statement, compiled from the books of Mr. JOHN MURPHY, the Receiver of Taxes, shows the entire payments of taxes made by and collected from all the different banks and insurance companies in the City. Where payments were made Voluntarily and without objection, no remark is attacked, but where payments were made voluntarily and accompanied with a protest the word "protest" clearly shows, and the forcible collections by Marshal HOLDKN are also indicated. The date of each payment is also noted. To November, it will be observed, a discount was allowed on payments. During November payments were made at par, and all the late payments included an additional item of interest in a penalty for neglect to step up to Mr. MUROHY's [???] and settle before Dec. 1.

abstract: Richmond papers of yesterday, received at Fortres Monroe, contain the somewhat unexpected information that a Union force, consisting of three brigades of infantry, four regiments of cavalry and twelve pieces of artillery were advancing upon that city, evidently with more serious intentions than making a raid.
lead_paragraph: Richmond papers of yesterday, received at Fortres Monroe, contain the somewhat unexpected information that a Union force, consisting of three brigades of infantry, four regiments of cavalry and twelve pieces of artillery were advancing upon that city, evidently with more serious intentions than making a raid. The rebel pickets at Bottom's Bridge, four miles from the city, are reported to have been driven in on Saturday, and a fight yesterday was considered more than probable. The same journals say that a force of 30,000 Union troops in the Southwest had crossed the Big Black River and were advancing upon Mobile.

abstract: The activity of the rebel forces in that part of Western Virginia contiguous to Martinsburgh, New-Creek and Cumberland, has of late been so great, and their success so general, as to cause us to wonder why our supposed energetic Commander in that region was not able to interfere with or defeat the numerous raids of these forces. "We have had a great many voluminous dispatches from headquarters at Cumberland, all assuring us that the enemy were completely defeated and being vigorously pursued; but the result has nearly always been that the rebels have got away with their plunder, and left the loyal people of that section so much the poorer. We now have a letter from a thoroughly loyal and reliable resident of that section, complaining bitterly of Gen. KELLY's management, especially in the matter of the late raid by the rebel cavalry on the line of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad. Our correspondent says the rebels moved at their pleasure, and succeeded in robbing the loyal citizens of and carrying off several thousand cattle, sheep and hogs, all of which might have been prevented by energetic and competent management. Our correspondent also says that many of the reports as telegraphed are unreliable, and successes are reported for us when there really are none. We fear there is ground for these statements, and hope, for the sake of the oppressed loyal residents of that part of Virginia, that an improved military management there may soon be instituted.

abstract: Strange Conduct at Produce Exchange
snippet: Strange Conduct at Produce Exchange
lead_paragraph: At the close of last fall, Mr. LUTHER C. TIBBETTS gained considerable notoriety for himself, by asking very heavy speculative purchase of Mixed Western Corn, at extraordinary high prices, the corn deliverable in the first ten days of the current month of February. He had subsequently some difficulty with his bankers. because of what is called Che defamatory representations of certain rivals in business. He managed, however, to work through this difficulty, and determined to gain control of the available supply of corn here, so as to render It next to impossible for those who had sold to him, to ill their contracts unless on such terms as would suit his interest or convenience. On Friday last, at about noon, he made his appearance on Change and commenced buying briskly, until he had purchased twenty-three loads at prices varying from 1 3301 40, agreeing to pay 3c. percent bushel cash on that day, and the balance of the purchase money within ten days. He also sold a single load at 51 26, cash. About one o'clock P. M., he grew very much excited, having been greatly annoyed by soma unknown parties, who had been pelting him with lumps of dough and quantities of grain; also by the persistency of a merchant, who bad been offering a load of corn at $1 40, but with whom ha. had repeatedly declined to have any direct business transactions. He began to talk loudly about combinations which had been organized to crush him; about his fidelity to principle; his determination to ???ght out the battle of principle, even if it cost him his ??? his enemies might take his corn and his money, but he would maintain his character, which he prized above everything else. Efforts were made to reason with him, but these efforts only Increased his nervousness and mental excitement. He appealed to his God for protection, and refused to be pacified or reasoned with, warning all parties to avoid interfering with him or his rights. At this lime the excitement on the floor was intense, and business was totally suspended. Shouts of "Put him out" were heard on all sides; he defied any one to put him out; he was fighting for principle, and he would not be put down. Two merchants then took hold of him, drew him to the stairway and down the ???airway to the street, whence he started by himself for his office.

abstract: the Homeless Children
snippet: the Homeless Children
lead_paragraph: While sympathetic hearts are working for the disabled soldier, a word is due in behalf of his children. They are neglected. New-York should do more for them than it does. Our places of shelter for these children are few; in fact, there are but two or three in the City, and each is capable of accommodating but a limited number. Fairs have been held, and contributions have been made, toward building a commodious house, to be ready in the Spring. But what is to become of the little ones during the cold Winter? It is a mistake to suppose that there is less poverty now than ever before in New-York. The thirfty laboring man is well supplied with work, and is paid well for it -- no more, comparatively, however, than heretofore -- but there are as many as ever suffering among a different class. The dead or disabled soldier's family -- those whom sickness or intemperance prevent from work -- the orphaned or forsaken children living on the uncertainties of the street, are as numerous and as much in want as ever. There are a thousand children in this City now, whose fathers have been or are now at the war, who are knocking in vain at the doors of the Soldier's Child's Refuge for admittance. They cannot enter, for there is no room for them. This ought not to be. Innocent childhood should not be left to starve and die, or beg and steal. Houses should be hired now, and over them should be placed kind and Christian men and women, who will open the hitherto closed avenues of life and love to those little ones.

lead_paragraph: GEORGE THOMPSON the famous English Abolitionist, whose oratorical displays against Slavery excited such commotion in our large cities thirty years ago, is about to revisit this country. He will undoubtedly be made the object of a good deal of glorification by the old-line Anti-Slavery men of the Garrisonian stamp. This is well enough for them, for he was once their fellow-laborer and fellow-sufferer. But is he entitled to any such welcome from our people generally? Do the Anti-Slavery Union men of the North owe him any special tribute of respect and honor for what he once here said and did?
