abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, yesterday, a resolution by Mr. JACQUES was adopted, directing the Finance Committee to prepare and report a memorial to be presented to Congress, asking a reimbursement to the City, from the Federal Treasury, of the moneys advanced in 1861 to equip and arm troops from the $1,000,000 Union Defence Fund.
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, yesterday, a resolution by Mr. JACQUES was adopted, directing the Finance Committee to prepare and report a memorial to be presented to Congress, asking a reimbursement to the City, from the Federal Treasury, of the moneys advanced in 1861 to equip and arm troops from the $1,000,000 Union Defence Fund. Another resolution by Mr. JACQUES, directing the Street Commissioner forthwith to advertise for proposals, and contract with the lowest bidder, for the Corporation printing, was referred. A resolution making an appropriation in blank, and providing for a Joint Committee of ten, to celebrate WASHINGTON's birthday, was adopted. A numerously signed petition from property owners in the Eleventh, Seventeenth and Eighteenth Wards, requesting that steps be taken to erect a public market upon the "Lowber property," foot of East Sixteenth-street, was presented by Mr. GROSS, and was referred. to the Committee on Markets, with instructions to report upon the subject as early as possible. Mr. GROSS presented a resolution to memorialize the Legislature for the passage of an act increasing the limit of the number of Commissioners of Deeds in this City to 500, and legalizing all the Appointments of these officers heretofore made by the Common Council. This' was adopted, and Immediately afterward, by 19 to 3, the board overruled Mayor GUNTHER's veto of the resolution appointing about 200 new Commissioners to fill vacancies. The new half-million Belief Fund Ordinance (No. 8) was concurred in. On the recommendation of the Comptroller, a resolution was adopted to transfer $16,000 from the Buss pavement Improvement Fund to the account of City Contingencies, specially to give a reception to the reenlisted veterans now in the City. On motion of Mr. Gross, Dr. Sayre, the Resident physician was requested to assist the Corporation Counsel in drafting an ordinance for the better regulation of tenement houses, Adjourned to Thursday, at 1 o'clock P.M.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC, The performance of " Norma" last night was witnessed by another brilliant audience. Mr. MARETZEK'S artists seem to have rejuvenated this popular work. Since its production last Spring, it has been one of the favorites of the repertoire.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The performance of "Norma" last night was witnessed by another brilliant audience. Mr. MARETZEK's artists seem to have rejuvenated this popular work. Since its production last Spring, it has been one of the favorites of the repertoire. The distribution is in all respects admirable. Mme. Medori infuses great dramatic power into the role of the Druidess, and sings the music with admirable knowledge and command of her own ample resources, Mlle. Sulzer as Adalgisa, is seen to the greatest advantage. The male part of the distribution is remarkably strong, and leaves nothing to be desired. Both Signor Mazzoleni as Pollio, and Signor BIACHI as Oroveso, are capital.

abstract: Reenlistments, the Farce of
snippet: Reenlistments, the Farce of
lead_paragraph: The rebels have lately been getting up a great hulabaloo about the "reenlistment" of their troops, and the files of Richmond papers are filled with announcements of the reenlistment of regiments and brigades en masse, while the reports of the proceedings of the rebel Congress contain numerous votes of thanks to different organizations for their "patriotism." Now, considering that the rebel Congress had already voted the whole Confederate army into a continuation of service "for the war," these reenlistments are a very pretty joke indeed. We think we see through this mockery: the rebel leaders have been alarmed at the significant contrast presented by the spontaneous patriotism of the veteran regiments of the Union armies in voluntarily coming forward for another term of service, end the despotic measures they (the rebels) were compelled to use, and they have resorted to this dodge for the purpose of spreading a thin veneer over the rot-ton fabric. Another part of the same shallow system is to represent that there are but few reenlistments among the Union armies. "Reenlistments," says the Examiner of the 8th inst., "progress slowly in the Yankee camps. They have been surprisingly numerous and enthusiastic in ours. The two facts supply a good augury for the decisive campaign of 1864. We have no evidence that enlistments are going on with alacrity in the enemy's camp. On the contrary a new draft is proclaimed, which is the last expedient that can be employed for recruiting depleted ranks." We are doubtless greatly to be pitied at having to resort to this "last expedient;" but what are we to think, of the "last expedient" to which the rebels have been forced to come. Here is what the journal just cited says in another column on the rebel Conscription Bill:

abstract: By the arrival of the schooner Oriental, Capt. BURMEISTER, from St. Johns, P. R., we have advices from that place to Jan. 30. Two regiments had just arrived from the old country, and 400 men sailed on the 22d ult. for St. Domingo. The British frigate Immortalite had been to Viegues or Crab Island to recognize the Spanish flag. Sugar is high and not much made, in consequence of the heavy rains. Two animals, called the manita, were captured by a Mr. LATIMER, and are now alive and well in his possession. He will present them to the Central Park Commissioners, provided they will send for them.

abstract: The rebel papers are in a flutter of excitement at the prospect that the newspapers of the Confederacy will be compelled to suspend their publication. "The Congress of the Confederate States," says one of them, "have gotten into a pet of passion with some of the newspapers, and in the efforts to punish the offending journals, are about to cover the land with darkness and ignorance." It appears that there are now in the whole of rebeldom but about thirty-five daily papers. The rest have all died out, for though the South has a great supply of rags, it has a very small stock of paper. Considering the ungrammatical, illogical and lying character of these Southern sheets generally, we don't know that the world would lose much if the rest of the thirty-five were to follow suit. The maxim De mortuis nil nisi bonum can only apply to them in the sense that "there's nothing good to be said of them except that they are dead."

abstract: This establishment in Fourteenth-street, opposite the Academy of Music, opened on Monday to literally an overwhelming audience. At 8 o'clock there was not even standing-room. The building lighted up beautifully, and was acknowledged to be most elegant and admirably adapted. The performances were "first-class," second to no "Cirque" in the world, and the audience throughout, and expressively at the close, gave evidence of their approval. Last evening another audience, as large us the opening one, testified to approval of the enterprise. In consequence of all this rush, a matinee is announced for to-day, doors opening at 1 and performances commencing at 2. The Director requests, in order to avoid delay and confusion, that tickets be procured, so far as possible, this morning.

abstract: Atlanta, the, and her Captors --Prize Money
snippet: Atlanta, the, and her Captors --Prize Money
lead_paragraph: A decision, embracing several novel and interesting points, has just been rendered by Judge SPRAGUE, in the United States District Court of Boston, in the case of the capture of the rebel ram Atlanta, and the distribution of the prize-money to the captors. The finding adjudges one-half the net proceeds of the prize ($350,829 26) to the captors, and decides these to be the monitor Weehawken, which was the vessel that caused the surrender, the monitor Nahant, which was present during the conflict, without actually taking part, and the gunboat Cimmerone, which lay off at signal distance.

abstract: The effect of Gen. BUTLER'S demonstration against Richmond is described by two refugees, who arrived at Fortress Monroe from that City yesterday, as having been perfectly fearful. Utter consternation and panic seized upon the people of Richmond, which had been almost denuded of troops to reinforce LEE, who was threatened by Gen. MEADE.
lead_paragraph: The effect of Gen. BUTLER'S demonstration against Richmond is described by two refugees, who arrived at Fortress Monroe from that City yesterday, as having been perfectly fearful. Utter consternation and panic seized upon the people of Richmond, which had been almost denuded of troops to reinforce LEE, who was threatened by Gen. MEADE. The citizens stood guard over our prisoners, while the guards went into the fortifications. Our troops on Belie Isle annoyed the rebels very much, by manifestations of joy when the alarm-bell rang.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- The peculiarities of GOUNOD's music have become so familiar to the artists who sing the various roles in "Faust," that that opera is now presented in a manner that leaves little to be desired, and is infinitely more clear and direct than on the first night. This is especially the case in the part of the hero himself. I: required several performances to accustom Signor MAZZOLENI to the vagueness of some of the melodic forms, and to the mysticism that hangs so suggestively about the music of the opening scene. He has now made himself at home in the role, and it gains new strength not merely from thoroughness of study, but from intelligence of interpretation. Signor BIACHI, as Mephistopheles, has also vastly improved. The rondo in the second act is full of diabolical enthusiasm. It is sung with superb effect by this young and very excellent artist. If the serenade came in any other part of the opera than the fourth act, it would certainly be encored. It is one of the best executed and quaintest numbers in the opera. Signor BELLINI, we need scarcely say, has been a very valuable addition to the cast. The death of Valentine is a fine dramatic sketch, with musical touches of high emotional import. It requires a first-class artist to do full justice to it. The ladles in this opera saved it on the first night, and we need only say that Miss KRLLOGG is still supreme as Marguerite, Miss SULZER is good as Siebel and Miss STOCKTON acceptable as Martha, The performance last night was witnessed by an audience that occupied every nook and corner of the house. On Friday next "Faust" will be again repeated, after which it is to be withdrawn to make room for novelties.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen yesterday adopted a resolution, by Mr. JONES, directing the Comptroller to lease, at auction, for a term often years, all ferries and piers and all real estate yielding no revenue to the City at present. A resolution, by Mr. RYERS, was adopted, requesting the Comptroller to furnish a statement of the valuation, amount and sources of income and cost of sustaining all the public markets not included in his late communication on the same subject. The Mayor ??? a communication notifying the board of the Supervisors' request that the Common Council will memorialize Congress for a reimbursement of the moneys advanced in 1861 to equip and arm troops. Mr. OTTIWELL thought the Supervisors were rather cool in making such a request. He was certain the Common Council could take care of itself, and did not need to have the mantle of the Supervisors' care thrown over it. Mr. JONES wished to defer action on the subject, and await the resolution from the Council Board directing a memoralization of Congress. Mr. OTTIWELL said our Congressmen ought to see that we get our own from the Government, and one of them had already taken earnest steps toward recovering the moneys in question. The communication was laid over. The board concurred to appoint a joint committee of ten to make arrangements for celebrating WASHINGTON's Birthday, and adjourned to the 16th inst., at 2 o'clock P. M.

abstract: -- There appears to be one golden opportunity a year for capturing Richmond; but though this opportunity has been twice within our reach, we have missed it both times. Last year we had it when STONEMAN got within the rebel works of Richmond, and finding it all but deserted, could have entered and burnt it, and taken off JEFF. DAVIS to boot, but failed to do so. There appears to have been another equally good opportunity the other day, when the Peninsula expedition got as far as the Chickahominy, threw the rebel capital, which was again almost stripped of troops, into a blaze of excitement, and retired before obstacles that would never have retarded a soldier of the stamp of JOHN BUFORD. Of course, we can't hope to repeat such experiments, for the rebels forewarned will be forearmed; but it is tantalizing to think what a slip was here twist the cup and the lip.

abstract: It is pretty generally understood that thus far all types of iron-clad vessels of war introduced into this country and elsewhere are failures.
lead_paragraph: It is pretty generally understood that thus far all types of iron-clad vessels of war introduced into this country and elsewhere are failures. The broad-side ships of England, France and America, with four and a half inches of iron plates, rolled so heavily that if they are not unseaworthy themselves, they prove the impossibility of putting a heavier armor on sea-going vessels. A novel system of armor has been introduced in the form of corrugated iron, which has the merit of imparting lightness and strength to the vessel. It, of course, permits a proper armament to be carried, by dispensing with an immense amount of superfluous solid iron. In a vessel of 1,800 tons burden, there is a saving of 400 tons, and 18 inches less draft of water. In a vessel of 7,500 tons burden, there is a saving of 1,600 tons weight of metal, and three feet six inches saved in the depth of water. This invention was presented to the Navy Department, and Secretary WELLES, with his usual discrimination, ordered a board to examine it. The board was composed of Rear-Admiral DAVIS, Prof. BACHE, Superintendent of the Coast Survey; Gen. BARNARD, Lieut.-Colonel of Engineers, and Mr. JOSEPH HENRY, of the Smithsonian Institute. These officers reported as follows:

abstract: At 9 'clock to-night a fire burst out in the Presidential stables, between the Treasury and the White House. The gates to the Treasury vard being looked, great delay ensued in getting at the building.
lead_paragraph: At 9 1/2 o'clock to-night a fire burst out in the Presidential stables, between the Treasury and the White House. The gates to the Treasury vard being looked, great delay ensued in getting at the building from the east, When our reporter reached it by escalade of two fences, he found two soldiers running out a coach, and Mr. LINCOLN regarding the fire, already in possession of the whole building, with great concern. It could not be saved. Nothing could be saved. Mr. LINCOLN was heard to express a wish that TAD's pony might be rescued, but it was burned, and with it Mrs. LINCOLN's black carriage-horses and Mr. NICOLAY's horse. Col BAKER, of the detectives, busied himself in preventing the spread of the fire to Treasury lumber piles.

abstract: Curtis vs. Van Eeton; Broker Charged with Bad Faith
snippet: Curtis vs. Van Eeton; Broker Charged with Bad Faith
lead_paragraph: Robert B. Curlis vs. Louis B. Van Eeten. -- The defendant in this case is a stock-broker, doing business in this City, and the plaintiff alleges that he employed him as his broker and agent in certain stack transactions. In September, 1862, plaintiff being desirous of speculating in stocks, was introduced to defendant as a person to be employed as his broker. Defendant stated to plaintiff, as alleged, that he had peculiar facilities for buying and selling stocks: that he transacted all his business at the Stock Exchange, with Ludlow, Patton & Co., and that he paid them so much a year to do all his business of that nature. Plaintiff employed defendant as agent and broker to purchase 100 shares of Illinois Central Railroad scrip, and deposited with him a margin of five per cent. On the following day defendant represented, as alleged, that he had bought the stock at the Board of Brokers, and presented to plaintiff a paper for him to sign, which purported that plaintiff had purchsed from defendant 100 shares of Illinois Central at $75, and paid on account $500. Plaintiff being ignoraut of stock operations, as claimed, believed it to be what was customary in buying stock and signed the paper, Subsequently plaintiff bought and sold stock through defendant to the amount of several hundred thousand dollars, in all of which transactions he gave a margin and paid commission, and he alleges that defendant pretended to acconnt to him and settle the losses and gains, but persuaded plaintiff to allow the gains to remain in his hands as a further margin.

abstract: London Times on Mr. Gibson's Speech
snippet: London Times on Mr. Gibson's Speech
lead_paragraph: The London Times, criticising Mr. GIBSON's speech, for the first time directly confesses that British favor toward the rebel South springs from British dread of "an overtoping and overshadowing Republic." Of course, this is no revelation to us this side of the water. We have known and said from the outset that all this cry for the right of a distinct people to a national independence; all this denunciation of the despotic conduct of the Federal Government; all this sophistical showing that Slavery had no connection with the outbreak, and could not be affected by the result; all the reiterated assertion that the rupture was irreparable, that the South could never be conquered, and that the continuance of an useless effusion of blood was an outrage upon humanity; all the extraordinary haste to give the rebels the status of belligerents; all the neglect to enforce the neutrality laws -- proceeded from just that craven and sordid fear, and nothing else. The hostile British press, with the London Times at its head, and the hostile majority in the Government and in the Parliament, began and kept up their efforts under false pretensions. Their motives have been feigned; their arguments have been a sham.
headline: {'main': 'Real Motive of British Sympathy with the Rebels.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Real Motive of British Sympathy with the Rebels.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The, as a Practical Measure
snippet: The, as a Practical Measure
lead_paragraph: Gov. PARKER has issued a proclamation to the people of New-Jersey, in which he says : Believing that the people of New-Jersey desired to avoid a draft, I have labored to give them the opportunity to furnish volunteers. The greater part of the State is already exempt. There is yet time for each township and ward to fill its entire quota if the people will be earnest in the effort. The advantages of such action, especially to the laboring classes, have been more than once presented. I can add but little to the appeals already made. I leave the subject with the people, in confidence that their response will be such as will gladden the hearts of every Jerseyman.

abstract: ARRIVAL OF THE TWELFTH CONNECTICUT REGIMENT. -- The Twelfth Connecticut Regiment, 438 men, Lieut.-Col. PECK commanding, arrived here yesterday from New-Orleans on the steamer Mississippi, which made the passage from bar to bar in five days and nineteen hours. The men have all reenlisted and are home on a furlough of thirty days. They have been absent two years, having left this port in February, 1862, under Gen. BUTLER. They spent six weeks on Ship Island, one of the most desolate spots along the coast, and were the first to ascend the Mississippi River after the capture of the forts by the fleet. They were stationed under Gen. PHELPS at Camp Parapet, during the Summer of 1862, and were brigaded under Gen. WEITZEL, and continued in his command during his entire campaign through Louisiana. The regiment took part in the battle of Lebadieville, and were active in the destruction of the rebel steamer Cotton. For a long time they held Alexandria, on the Red River, and marched thence to Port Hudson, where they were under fire forty-two days, within easy range of rebel muskets. After the capture of Port Hudson they occupied Donaldsonville, from which place, by way of Brashear City, they joined the feints through eastern Louisiana to Opelousas, which were made to attract the attention of the enemy from the movements of Gen. BANKS' expedition to Texas. It is expected the veterans will leave for Connecticut to-day, where extensive preparations have been made for their reception.
lead_paragraph: ARRIVAL OF THE TWELFTH CONNECTICUT REGIMENT. -- The Twelfth Connecticut Regiment, 438 men, Lieut.-Col. PECK commanding, arrived here yesterday from New-Orleans on the steamer Mississippi, which made the passage from bar to bar in five days and nineteen hours. The men have all reenlisted and are home on a furlough of thirty days. They have been absent two years, having left this port in February, 1862, under Gen. BUTLER. They spent six weeks on Ship Island, one of the most desolate spots along the coast, and were the first to ascend the Mississippi River after the capture of the forts by the fleet. They were stationed under Gen. PHELPS at Camp Parapet, during the Summer of 1862, and were brigaded under Gen. WEITZEL, and continued in his command during his entire campaign through Louisiana. The regiment took part in the battle of Lebadieville, and were active in the destruction of the rebel steamer Cotton. For a long time they held Alexandria, on the Red River, and marched thence to Port Hudson, where they were under fire forty-two days, within easy range of rebel muskets. After the capture of Port Hudson they occupied Donaldsonville, from which place, by way of Brashear City, they joined the feints through eastern Louisiana to Opelousas, which were made to attract the attention of the enemy from the movements of Gen. BANKS' expedition to Texas. It is expected the veterans will leave for Connecticut to-day, where extensive preparations have been made for their reception.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. TRUMBULL, from the Judiciary Committee, reported a joint resolu- tion for the amendment of the Constitution,
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, Mr. TRUMBULL, from the Judiciary Committee, reported a joint resolu- tion for the amendment of the Constitution, which abolishes Slavery -- this resolution being a substitute for the one previously offered by Mr. HENDERSON, while Mr. SUMNER's resolution to the same effect was reported adversely upon. Mr. CLARK introduced a bill ratifying the President's Proclamation of Emancipation, and giving it the force of a statute. Mr. BROWN submitted amendments to the Enrollment Bill subjecting colored men to enrollment and draft, basing such liability upon their status as declared by the Emancipation Proclamation. Mr. GRIMES� bill to reduce the salaries of unemployed officers and officers on leave was reported adversely to Mr. SUMNER introduced a resolution to investigate the outrage of the expulsion of a Major (colored) in the United States service from the cars of the city railroad in Washington. A discussion ensued, but the resolution was adopted. The bill prohibiting members of the Senate or House from being employed as counsel in cases where the Government is a party, was taken up and all the amendments agreed to. The bill to equalize the pay of troops was discussed, but no conclusion reached. The feature debated is that which gives the colored troops the same pay and allowances as white soldiers. After an executive session the Senate adjourned.

abstract: OLYMPIC THEATRE.-A new piece and an old piece were produced at this house on Monday, andsuch are the fearful and tragic vicissitudes of theatrical life-the old piece carried the night. We are
lead_paragraph: OLYMPIC THEATRE. -- A new piece and an old piece were produced at this house on Monday, and -- such are the fearful and tragic vicissitudes of theatrical life -- the old piece carried the night. We are sorry for it. Mrs. JOHN WOOD so seldom produces a new piece, that the force of such an example may be fatal to an entire generation of American dramatists. And yet the old piece was good, and the new piece was bad. Let us hasten to explain that the latter came from the other side of the Atlantic. It is a burlesque on "Trovatore," by Mr. H.J. BYRON, slightly localized by the infant of the establishment. The jokes for about ten minutes are pretty good, deriving some of their brilliancy, perhaps, from the new clothes of the actors. After that they are provocative of locked-jaw from excess of yawning. The intellectual ???tillation of a pun on a single word is sometimes agreeable, but Mr BYRON is not prodigal of his puns. He spreads them over a large surface, as the Vauxhall caterer spreads his ham. In a dozen lines there may be a single recurrence of a punistical sound, and then so far-fetched and covering such a yast abyss of emptiness, that it is hardly more inspiriting than ans elegant extract from the Directory. The relative merit of a pun is determined by its quick intellectual atrocity; never by its deliberate strain on the memory or patience. People do not laugh at Mr. BYRON's herculean efforts. They sigh, and slumberously doat upon Mrs. JOHN WOOD; or wildly leave the theatre, hurling imprecations into the box-office where they paid their money and didn't get their choice.

abstract: A dispatch from St.Louis confirms the report that Gen.SHERMAN'S army left Vicksburgh about two weeks since, on its expedition southward.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from St.Louis confirms the report that Gen. SHERMAN's army left Vicksburgh about two weeks since, on its expedition southward. The Sixteenth and Seventeenth Army Corps compose it, under the command respectively of Gen. HULBURT and Gen. MCPHERSON, the latter having the advance. On the 3d inst. Gen. SMITH's cavalry expedition left Memphis for Corinth, to operate in the interior of Mississippi and Alabama. Gen. STEELE's Union forces in Arkansas are also preparing for an early move southward, which will put the rebel MAGRUDER between them and the forces of Gen. BANKS.

abstract: Evening Post Advising Removal of Police Commissioners Acton and Bergen; Police Commissioners, Efficiency of--The Bill to Remove
snippet: Evening Post Advising Removal of Police Commissioners Acton and Bergen; Police Commissioners, Efficiency of--The Bill to Remove
lead_paragraph: -- We are a good deal surprised to find the Evening Post advocating the removal of Messrs. ACTON and BERGEN, the present Police Commissioners, and the appointment of two new men in their places. And we are still more surprised to find it assigning as a reason for the change, that the incumbents rest under the suspicion of "using the police force to further party ends." We should like to know who "suspects" them. It is the first time we have ever heard an intimation of the kind against them. We have heard complaints, from hot-headed partisans, that Mr. ACTON would not permit the force to be used for party purposes, and this, we are inclined to believe, has been the head and front of his offending. So far as we have any information in the matter, Mr. ACTON's conduct in this respect has been above reproach. We do not believe that the Post can specify an instance, or cite a trustworthy witness, to sustain the charge it brings against him.

abstract: Motion to Amend Constitution, Abolishing Slavery
snippet: Motion to Amend Constitution, Abolishing Slavery
lead_paragraph: The Judiciary Committee in the Senate have reported against Mr. SUMNER's proposition to amend the Constitution of the United States so as to abolish Slavery in all the States and Territories. In our judgment, they have done a wise thing. Whatever may be the merits of the proposition itself, this is not the time to take action upon it. We do not believe in the wisdom of amending the Constitution at all now. We are in the midst of a war. The whole political atmosphere is red-hot with revolutionary fervor. Men's minds are excited, their resentments are aroused, and their passions are in the ascendant. This is not a favorable mood for digging about the foundations of our great temple of republican liberty. Things are very apt to be done in such a temper which the very men who do them will regret, and would gladly undo, when cool reflection takes the place of heated and intemperate zeal.

abstract: -- Why does not the Legislature authorize a company to build railroads wherever it chooses in this City -- to tear up any street, lay down rails, run cars, charge what it pleases, and make men and women sit down, stand up, or ride on their heads, to suit its own convenience and fill its own pockets, without regard to anything or anybody else? If it would do this at once it would save time and let us know precisely what we have to expect. It could not possibly act with more reckless disregard of the public good than it is doing now. Bills are introduced every day to build some new road through streets where they are not needed, or where they would be simply an intolerable nuisance. The whole City is already grid-ironed with roads that belong to private companies; and the chances are that in a year or two more, as things are going on, we shall have no public streets at all. They will all be monopolized and substantially owned by men who use them simply for their own profit.
lead_paragraph: -- Why does not the Legislature authorize a company to build railroads wherever it chooses in this City -- to tear up any street, lay down rails, run cars, charge what it pleases, and make men and women sit down, stand up, or ride on their heads, to suit its own convenience and fill its own pockets, without regard to anything or anybody else? If it would do this at once it would save time and let us know precisely what we have to expect. It could not possibly act with more reckless disregard of the public good than it is doing now. Bills are introduced every day to build some new road through streets where they are not needed, or where they would be simply an intolerable nuisance. The whole City is already grid-ironed with roads that belong to private companies; and the chances are that in a year or two more, as things are going on, we shall have no public streets at all. They will all be monopolized and substantially owned by men who use them simply for their own profit.

abstract: It has come to be the fashion to keep at least one dead body exposed to public view at the Barge-office. What particular object there can be in allowing a corpse to remain forty-eight hours within sight of hundreds of passers by, is difficult of explanation. During most of the day, yesterday and the day before, the dead body of a sailor lay at the dock, in the rear of the Barge-office, and it was not until twenty-four hours after the Coroner held his inquest that the corpse was removed. In the meantime, the rats would have eaten the flesh from the bones, had it not been for the kindness of the bargemen, who stood watch. This outrage on public decency is but one of several that have recently occurred.

abstract: Sherman, Gen., the Grand Spring Campaign in Southwest
snippet: Sherman, Gen., the Grand Spring Campaign in Southwest
lead_paragraph: The Spring campaign in the Southwest opens with moves of a bewildering complexity. We have the news of no less than three grand columns which are either already under way or on the point of moving. Gen. SHERMAN's column, comprising the corps of HURLBUT and MCPHERSON, started from Vicksburgh two weeks ago, moving eastward across the Big Black. A powerful cavalry column, under Gen. SMITH, GRANT's Chief of Cavalry, has taken its departure from Corinth and Holly Springs. Signs of speedy activity, military and naval, also show themselves in the Department of Gen. BANKS.
headline: {'main': 'The Grand Spring Campaign in the Southwest.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Grand Spring Campaign in the Southwest.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Committee on National Affairs of the common Council have determined to move immediately in the matter of honoring the returned and returning veteran volunteers. The want of funds has been the obstacle to this step, but as a resolution to transfer $15,000 for the purpose has passed the Board of Counscilmen, and is now before the Board of Aldermen, the committee feel warranted in going ahead. Even this transfer could not be attempted until the Comptroller had recommended it, which he did in response to a request of the Common Council. They asked for $25,000. Mr. BRENSAN suggested, in reply, that application be made to the Legislature if more than $15,000 were wanted for the purpose. This amount probably will be at the command of the committee in the course of a week, and, therefore, they are taking steps to give some pleasant entertainment to the Fifty-first, One Hundred and Second, Sixty-eighth and Fifty-eighth Regiments, which are to report for departure to the seat of war in a short time. The Fifty-first is to report a; Fort Schuyler, on the 20th inst; the One Hundred and Second at the Park Barracks, on the 24th; the Sixty eighth at Fort Schuyler, on the 25th; and the Fiftieth at the Park Barracks on the same date. The design is to give each of these regiments a cheeting entertainment just before leaving home. There are three regiments to go away on Saturday of this week, but as the Committee cannot have money to use before next week, it is regretted that they will be unable to extend any substantial courtesies to them.

abstract: A dispatch from Cincinnati, dated the 11th, ???, persons who have recently arrived from Knoxville, report that communication between that place and Cumberland Gap is suspended, and that nearly the whole of East Tennessee is now in the hands of the rebels. About JOE JOHNSTON's army, it is said, that the Tennessee and Kentucky troops have been sent South, ostensibly to defend Mobile, but in reality to prevent desertions. JOHNSTON's Headquarters are at Atlanta.

abstract: In the State Senate, yesterday, the Metropolitan Police Bill was under vigorous discussion. Mr. COZANS moved to strike out the names of Messrs. ACTON, BERGEN, PURDY and JONES, which was disagreed to. He then moved to substitute the name of Mr. CAMPBELL for that of Mr. BKRGEN, which was also lost. On this question Senator FIELD declined to vote, Senate being in Committee of the Whole, he claiming that while in committee it had no right to compel him to do so. The committee was dissolved, and Senator FIELD was compelled to vote. During the discussion one of the Senator's Democratic brethren bitterly denounced him, charging him with having made a corrupt bargain with the opposition, and with having violated his pledges to the Democratic party. The Senate came to no conclusion.

abstract: The steamships City of Washington and China, from Liverpool, touching at Queenstown, both arrived at this port last evening, bringing advices to the 31st ult., being six days later intelligence. The news is varied and interesting. The Dano-German troubles had not eventuated in hostilities, and an earnest effort was being made by England, to which France and Europe lent their moral support, to induce Austria and Prussia to preserve the peace. Meanwhile the movement of troops continues. The Danes are actively at work in preparations for resistance, and Great Britain is reported to be getting ready a sufficient naval and military force to give effect to her remonstrances against the invasion of Denmark. Sweden has given in her adhesion to the Danish cause, and is preparing vigorously for eventualities. The great and small German Powers were coming into more harmonious relations. In France the debate upon the Address had continued and given rise to some interesting utterances. In the consideration of the Mexican question M. THIERS had made a bold and vigorous speech, reviewing the policy of the Throne, which he concluded by demanding that France should treat with JUAREZ, so as to preserve her honour and the interests formerly guaranteed, else the expedition would only result in an indefinite and ruinous occupation. M. CHAIX D'EST ANGE defended the expedition as being just, and affirmed that it was impossible to treat with JUAREZ. In Poland the insurrection is reported to be increasing, and the insurgent leaders had met with successes. It had been announced in England that on the night of Nov. 6, about 150 miles W.S.W. of Java Heads, an unknown vessel was seen on fire, with a steamer, supposed to be the Alabama, in close proximity. This information was taken to Table Bay at the end of December, end communicated to the United States steamer Mohican, when that vessel started on a cruise to the eastward, in search, it was supposed, of the Alabama. The pirate was coaling at Singapore on the 22d of December. The United States corvette St. Louis is reported to have left Lisbon on the 25th ult., to intercept an English bark having guns and stores for the rebel cruiser Rappahannock. A later dispatch says that the Alabama left Singapore on the 24th ult., and afterwards, in the Straits of Malacca, burnt the British ship Marlaban, from Moulmein, and the American ships Sonora and Hihlander.

abstract: Longstreet's Reinforcements
snippet: Longstreet's Reinforcements
lead_paragraph: -- There has been much speculation as to how largely LONGSTREET has been reinforced, and as to where the troops came from. All the assertions that any portion of JOHNSTON's army has been sent him are contradicted as fast as made, and the statements that LEE has furnished aid to LONSTREET are also disputed, especially since the late reconnoissance in force by the Army of the Potomac. But that considerable reinforcements have been added to LONGSTREET's army seems no longer to admit of question, for we have the statement of the fact, even to the figures, from creditable rebel sources. A correspondent of the Richmond Whig, writing from Carter's Station, Tennessee, on the 22d ult., says:

abstract: Loyalty and Elections
snippet: Loyalty and Elections
lead_paragraph: That Kentucky loyalty is not mere pulp -- that it has substance and something of a back-bone, we have never doubted. But it yet puzzles as whether it be fish, flesh or fowl. We never could agree with those who have called it altogether lishy. yet, we must admit, it tapers off in a very fishy way. With all its shapely front, there is that piscatory ending, say what you will -- desinit in piscem.

abstract: Steamship Merrimac
snippet: Steamship Merrimac
lead_paragraph: -- We publish this morning a prize decision of Judge BETTS, which, though brief, is of some importance and interest. The steamer Merrimac was captured by the Iroquois. During the chase, the steamer Eagle, an unarmed merchant steamer, came in sight, and, by her presence, if not by active cooperation, aided the Iroquois in the capture of the blockade-runner. The vessel being condemned as prize, the Commander of the Eagle put in a claim to be allowed to share in the prize money. He no doubt thought that he had done as much to help the chase with his vessel as if she had carried guns, as long as she was not near enough to have used guns if she had them, and since an armed vessel would be entitled to share as being within "signal distance," he and his crew ought also to be so entitled.

abstract: The Battery Grounds, so long a favorite resort for strangers, have recently become a decided nuisance. Vagabends, loafers, thieves and bounty brokers are now "monarchs of all they survey" in the immediate vicinity of Castle Garden. It is positively dangerous for an honest man to venture upon the grounds after dark, and even during the day the chances of being knocked kown by some vagrant, or having your pockets picked, are not by any means slim. Formerly there were paths "visible to the naked eye," but they have nearly all merged into the common, which may be likened unto a country cow-pasture. The removal of a portion of the old iron fence by an enterprising railroad company is another item to add to the deformity of the Battery Grounds. The trees have a sickly appearance, and those who ought to know insist that the flag-staff will hardly survive another gale of wind.

The removal of a portion of the old iron fence by an enterprising railroad company is another item to add to the deformity of the Battery Grounds. The trees have a sickly appearance, and those who ought to know insist that the flag-staff will hardly survive another gale of wind.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, yesterday, the Mayor sent in a very short veto message on the resolution appointing a joint special committee of ten to make arrangements to celebrate WASHINGTON's birthday," that the same may be adapted in a form less liable to objection." The resolution gives the committee full power to create liabilities, yet contains no appropriation to defray the expense which may be incurred, and without such a specific appropriation no expenditures can, in my judgment, be legally made." Mr. BRICE proposed to make a specific apropriation in a new resolution. Mr. OPDYKE said that course would not legalize the committee already appointed. A resolution by Mr. WEBSTER. same as the one vetoed, except that it appropriates $7,000, was laid over. A resolution to amend the Relief Fund Ordinance was adopted, so that families of soldies who were not residents of the City at the time of their enlistment, and of members of the Invalid Corps not credited to our quota, are cut off from its benefits. The resolution from the Aldermen, directing the Comptroller to lease at auction all ferries and piers, &c, not now paying revenue to the City, was referred. On the ordinance from the other board, making appropriations to pay the interest and principal of the City debt falling due in 1863, there was a prolonged and animated debate, arising upon a motion by Mr. OPDYKE to strike out the item to liquidate the Union Defence Redemption Funds, advocated on the ground that the amount, $897, 570, would soon be reimbursed to the City by Congress, or that it might be met by a further issue of bonds and paid hereafter, so as to lessen the burden of taxes this year. Mr. JAQUES strenuously supported the motion, and, in the course of his remarks, incidentally mentioned that City taxation had increased largely under Democratic rule. Mr. GROSS replied that the war and Republican Legislatures were the causes of the increase. The motion was lost, and the ordinance was concurred in by 20 to 2. Adjourned to Monday at 1 o'clock P.M.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, there was little business done. Mr. ANTHONY presented a memorial from warrant officers in the navy, asking for assimilated rank with line officers of the navy. Mr. WILSON presented the petition of O.S. STEARNS, praying that a portion of the property of one SOTHERON. a Maryland rebel, may be set aside for the support of he family of the officer murdered by said SOTHERON, while engaged in recruiting slaves on the latter's plantation. Mr. COLLAMER reported a bill removing the disability of color, as affecting persons of African descent, in performing Government contracts, and appearing as witnesses in United States Courts. Mr. SUMNER introduced a bill to indemnify the owners of the British schooner Glen, which was passed. The Lieutenant-General Bill was taken up, and debate ensued upon the proposed amendments striking out the clause designating Gen. GRANT, and that which provides that the Lieutenant-General shall command all the armies. Without coming to a vote, the Senate adjourned.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, there was little business done. Mr. ANTHONY presented a memorial from warrant officers in the navy, asking for assimilated rank with line officers of the navy. Mr. WILSON presented the petition of O.S. Mr. SUMNER introduced a bill to indemnify the owners of the British schooner Glen, which was passed. The Lieutenant-General Bill was taken up, and debate ensued upon the proposed amendments striking out the clause designating Gen. abstract: Liquor Dealers and Internal Revenue Law
snippet: Liquor Dealers and Internal Revenue Law
lead_paragraph: -- The Internal Revenue law was very generally accepted by our people with cheerfulness. We have heard of but one effort of any consequence to nullify its provisions or to seriously oppose them, and that has been on the part of the liquor dealers, many of whom refused to take out the license required by the act, and clubbed together to oppose the law in the courts. Their battle with the Government is ed one of them of retailing liquor without a license, an offence which renders the transgressor of the law liable to an imprisonment for a period to be fixed by the discretion of the now fairly set. The Government has convict court, not exceeding two years; and a day or two since some forty or fifty more of them were indicted in a batch for the same offence.

abstract: The Senate, yesterday, devoted its time chiefly to the consideration of the Deficiency Bill. The amendments of the Senate Ways and Means Committee were agreed to. They strike out all pro visions for an increase of the regular clerical...
lead_paragraph: The Senate, yesterday, devoted its time chiefly to the consideration of the Deficiency Bill. The amendments of the Senate Ways and Means Committee were agreed to. They strike out all pro visions for an increase of the regular clerical force of the departments, and authorize the employment of about one thousand extra clerks for a period not exceeding one year after the close of the rebellion; $150,000 is appropriated for repairs at the Norfolk Navy-yard; $144,000 for works at Port Royal; and $47,000 for repairs at the Brooklyn Navyyard. Amendments were adopted appropriating $80,000 for deficiencies in the Quartermaster's, Commissary and Ordnance Departments. The Senate then went into Executive Session, when it adjourned until to-day.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, the Metropolitan Police Bill being under consideration and sharply discussed, it was decided to substitute the names of Messrs. BOSWORTH and MCMURRAY for Messrs. PURDY and JONES. Thus amended, the bill passed to a third reading. The Commissioners now named are Messrs. BOSWORTH, MCMURRAY, ACTON and BERGEN. Among the bills passed was one making appropriations for the payment of the Canal debt for the fiscal year; and one limiting the term of office of Notaries Public to two years, and providing for one for each bank in the State.

abstract: The iron-clad gunboat Chickasaw was launched at Carondelet on Wednesday morning. A sad accident marred the occasion. A coil of rope attached to the anchor spun out so rapidly as to carry overboard a daughter of Capt. EADS, three other ladies and a son of Ex-Mayor FILLEY. All were rescued save one, Mrs. BRADLEY, who was drowned.

abstract: City Reforms and Citizens' Associat'n
snippet: City Reforms and Citizens' Associat'n
lead_paragraph: The "Citizens' Association," which has been formed for the purpose of promoting reform in the Municipal Government, will be a very valuable organization if the members do not mistake its object, and no not expect too much. They must not imagine, in the first place, that any number of "appeals" to the tax-payers will be productive of the smallest benefit, no matter how cogent they may be. The tax-payers know all about the corruption of the City Government, and all heartily detest and abhor the "Ring," but they are divided into two classes: The first consists of those who, knowing to what extent they are plundered by the banditti of the City Hall, nevertheless find that it "pays better" to submit quietly than to devote any time to trying to bring about a reform, and will, consequently, as long as indifference pays a good dividend, not suffer themselves to be distracted into vigilance by considerations of general patriotism. The second consists of those who are shocked, disgusted, and grievously robbed, and anxious to do something to put a stop to the abuses from which they suffer. But this class is numerically so small, that when it comes to counting votes, they are one against a thousand. Even if all the tax-payers were united, however, they could do little at elections. The non-taxpayers are in the majority, and they are completely controlled by "the Ring." It is true that the frauds and corruption of their leaders, and their persistent plunder of the City Treasury affects them as it does the property owners, but it affects them only indirectly, through their rents, and the price of their provisions, and it is of course always easy to conceal this from them, and ascribe the increasing drafts on their wages to the war and the paper money. Moreover, they are generally foreigners, generally very ignorant, unused to thinking on any subject, and least of all on political subjects. Their votes are generally cast in accordance with their feelings, and their one idea of political duty is faithful adherence to a leader, and through him to a party.
headline: {'main': 'THE TROUBLE ABOUT CITY REFORM.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE TROUBLE ABOUT CITY REFORM.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The dilapidated condition of many of the East River docks has become a matter of general comment. For several years the piers about the City have attracted the attention of our shipping merchants, and efforts have been made to have them repaired. The almost unprecedented flow of drift ice this Winter has rendered some of the docks along the East River a nuisance to their localities, and at least ten of them have been almost entirely carried away. What provision will be made for the protection of vessels obliged to discharge cargoes in some of the more exposed slips is not known, but it is evident there must be something done very soon to repair our East River docks, or many of our shipping merchants will land their vessels elsewhere; in fact Hoboken has already been selected by several foreign ship owners as a safer place for their vessels than this City.

abstract: The steamship Fulton, from Port Royal, arrived yesterday, bringing news of an expedition, consisting of three brigades and a light battery, under command of Brig. Gen. TRUMAN SEYMOUR, having successfully landed, on the 8th inst., at...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Fulton, from Port Royal, arrived yesterday, bringing news of an expedition, consisting of three brigades and a light battery, under command of Brig. Gen. TRUMAN SEYMOUR, having successfully landed, on the 8th inst., at Jacksonville, Fla. -- a place which has already been twice occupied and abandoned by our forces. Gen. GILLMORE had followed Gen. SEYMOUR, to look after matters. At Charleston there was nothing new in the position of affairs. The desultory bombardment was not intermited. An Anglo rebel steamer had been destroyed. She attempted to run the gauntlet of our iron-clad fleet during a fog, but only succeeded in getting ashore on Sullivan's Island, where she was riddled by our gunners.

abstract: FATAL ACCIDENT ON THE FOURTH-AVENUE RAILROAD. THE CORONER'S JURY CENSURR THE COMPANY. About 10 o'ctocK yesterday morning, a girl aged 8 years, named CATHARINE MILLER, was run over in Broome-street, near Centre, by car No. 41 of the Fourth-avenue Railroad Company, and instantly killed.
lead_paragraph: FATAL ACCIDENT ON THE FOURTH-AVENUE RAILROAD. -- THE CORONER'S JURY CENSURR THE COMPANY. About 10 o'ctocK yesterday morning, a girl aged 8 years, named CATHARINE MILLER, was run over in Broome-street, near Centre, by car No. 41 of the Fourth-avenue Railroad Company, and instantly killed. The deceased, who was partially idiotic, took an apple from a store in Broome-street, and attempted to escape with it. In trying to cross the street, the horses attached to car No. 41 knocked the child down and trampled upon her; the car also passed over her neck. Coroner COLLIN held an inquest on the body at the Fourteenth Precinct Station-house, when it appeared that DANIEL CLINE, the driver of the car, did everything in his power to prevent the accident. In his testimony, the driver said the brake of the car was not in good order, and that if it, (the brake,) had worked well, the child's life might have been saved. The jury rendered the following verdict: "We find that the deceased CATHARINE MILLER came to her death by injuries received by having been accidently run over by car No. 41 of the Fourth-avenue Railroad; and we exonerate the driver from all blame in the matter, and censure the Company for allowing a car with defective brakes to be driven, and we recommend the Company to have a flagman at the corner of Broome and Centre streets." The deceased lived with her grandfather at No. 145 Baxter-street.

abstract: THREATENING TO BLOW UP A HOUSE AND TO MURDER. -- In the Hudson County Court, yesterday, WILLIAM KINNEY was placed on trial, under an indictment for sending an anonymous letter to DAVID H. BAKER, Superintendent of the New-Jersey Railroad shop. It appears that KINNEY, who was employed in the shop, demanded an increase of wages, and also the payment of a certain amount for over-work, whichhe claimed that BAKER had received and withheld from him. This was refused, when KINNEY left, and subsequently Mr. BAKER received an anonymous letter purporting to come from strikers in New-York, threatening that if he did not pay the money withheld from the man within three days, they would "blow up his house about his ears," and if he escaped the ruins he would "be subject to the revolver." KINNEY's handwriting was identified by two witnesses. The case was given to the jury, and, as the court adjourned until Monday, they were instructed to bring in a sealed verdict.

abstract: Report on Resources of U. S. Ordered Printed by Congress
snippet: Report on Resources of U. S. Ordered Printed by Congress
lead_paragraph: SUPPLY OF GOLD. The Senate of the United States have directed the publication of the report on the resources of the United States, presented to the International Statistical Congress by Mr. SAMUEL B. RUGGLES, delegate to that body from our Government. Its statements excited much attention in the Congress and throughout Europe, intended, as they were, to exhibit the ability of the United States to pay in gold any debt it might incur in repressing the existing rebellion. The subject was presented under the heads; First, of Territory, exhibiting the vast field of fertile land open to gratituitous occupation, and inviting immigrants from Europe; second, of Population, with its irrepressible growth at the ratio of 35 per cent for every succeeding decade; third, of Production, and consequent creation of taxable property, with its arithmetical rate of increase, showing that the last decade has added; and that each succeeding decade must add, an amount far exceeding any probable amount of public debt; and fourth, of Precious Metals, unfolding the vast deposits of dormant wealth in gold and silver in our metalliferous regions between the Missouri River and the Pacific. The report concludes with the suggestion peculiarly proper for a Statistical Congress, that measures should be immediately adopted to ascertain by authentic evidence the present and probable future supply of gold and silver by the United States, by Russia, by British America and Australia.

abstract: His Slavery Amendment Unreasonable because Unseasonable
snippet: His Slavery Amendment Unreasonable because Unseasonable
lead_paragraph: Attempts are vigorously kept up in some quarters to force upon the public mind Mr. SUMNER's project of amending the Constitution so as to bury Slavery forever. Hot headed men are unwilling to acquiesce in the wise conclusion of the Judiciary Committee of the Senate, that the time has not come for the agitation of that subject. They are determined that it shall be agitated, and forthwith. The only appeal then is to the sound patriotism and calm good sense of the people. We are confident that public opinion will set itself like adamant against the introduction of any such new subject for political controversy at this stage of the war.

abstract: Bright, John, Speech on American Affairs, >amp;c., at Birmingham
snippet: Bright, John, Speech on American Affairs, >amp;c., at Birmingham
lead_paragraph: On Jan. 26, Hon. JOHN BRIGHT addressed his constituents at Birmingham -- making the first speech that be has delivered since the famous Cobden-Delane Controversy. Mr. SCHOLEFIELD, M.P., of the same borough, preceded Mr. BRIGHT, and said, in the source of his speech on America, that the present war was not a war for the emancipation of the slaves, and if it were, it was not the less on that account an immoral and unjustifiable war. [Cheers and hisses.] The preservation of the Union was the great idea which pervaded the minds of the Northerners, from the President downward. The President on one occasion declared: "My promised object in this struggle was to save the Union. [Cheers.] Without freeing any slave I would do it; and if I could save it by freeing all the slaves, I would; and if I could save it by freeing some and leaving others alone, I would do that. What I would do about colored men and slaves, I would do because I believe it helps to save the Union." [Cheers.] After such an expression of opinion he was surprised to hear people say that the object of the President was to put down Slavery. ["Hear, hear," and marks of disapprobation.] The proclamation emancipating the slaves was issued by the President solely as a war measure to crush the rebellion and restore the Union. He believed that it was impossible to restore the Union by war. [Cheers and uproar.] If this was a war for the emancipation of the slave, then he said most emphatically that it was an immoral war. If it was morally right in America to put down Slavery in that country, it was equally morally right for this country to make war upon Spain to put down Slavery in Cuba, upon Russia to put down serfdom, or upon the King of Dahomey to put down infanticide. [Cheers, hisses and great uproar.] He had never been an advocate for peace at any price, but he had always been opposed to any war that was not a defensive war. An aggressive war was to his mind a great crime, and would never meet with his sanction and assent. He was told that he was blamed not so much for the opinions he had expressed in 1862, but for having joined a Confederate association. He thought he should have been more open to condemnation it after expressing his views he had not had the courage to carry them out. He was told that in consequence of the course he had taken he would lose his seat. Deeply as he valued the honor they had conferred upon him, there was something he valued still more highly than a seat in Parliament, and that was the right to speak and act freely and independently within the scope of the powers with which they themselves had intrusted him. If for the course he had taken they deemed him no longer worthy of representing them, he should bow to their decision without a murmur. [Loud cheers.]

abstract: Assistant Surgeon, the Case of
snippet: Assistant Surgeon, the Case of
lead_paragraph: Since the launch of the line-of-battle ship NewHampshire at Portsmouth, N.H., orders have been received to fit her out as soon as possible for active service. Workmen are now engaged in preparing her rigging, and the Ordnance Department has her armament nearly ready. She was docked a few days after her launch to have her bottom made all right, and came out of the dock last week. It is understood that she is to go to Port Royal to be the permanent guard-ship there in place of the old Vermont, one of our line-of-battle ships which has been for many years afloat. On the arrival of the New-Hampshire, the crew and invalids of the Vermont will be transferred to her, and the former ordered to some navy yard for repairs. The New-Hampshire was over fifty years on the stocks. She was called the Alabama for a long period, until the present Administration changed her name.

abstract: DECEASE OF COMMODORE McCLONEY. Commodore WILLIAM J. McCLONEY, of the U.S. Navy, died. At his residence, No. 23 Smith-street, Brooklyn, on the 11th instant, in the 69th year of his age. The deceased belonged to the old school of naval heroes ...
lead_paragraph: DECEASE OF COMMODORE McCLONEY. -- Commodore WILLIAM J. McCLONEY, of the U.S. Navy, died. At his residence, No. 23 Smith-street, Brooklyn, on the 11th instant, in the 69th year of his age. The deceased belonged to the old school of naval heroes who participated in the brilliant engagements with the British in the war of 1812. He entered the navy on the 1st of January of that year, (1812,) and took his first cruise in the United States sloop-of-war Wasp as midshipman, and participated in the fight between that vessel and H.B.M. sloop Frolic, commanded by the late Commodore JONES, in which the latter was captured. Both vessels were subsequently recaptured by H.B.M. ship Poictiers, and carried into Bermuda as prisoners of war. The officers and crew were released by cartel in November following, and in 1813 transferred by the U.S. authorities to the frigate Macedonian. Shortly after they went to Lake Ontario, where the Commodore remained until the close of the war. He afterward commanded a schooner on the Southern Station, and then became attached to the U.S. brig Saratoga as Acting Lieutenant. In 1821, he commanded the brig Dolphin, and then the Franklin, 74, in the Pacific Ocean, where he remained for three years and four months. In 1825, he was placed in command of the frigate Constitution (the old Ironsides) on the West India Station. In 1828-29, he commanded the sloops Fairfield, Lexington and Warren in the Mediterranean. During the Mexican war he commanded the U.S. sloop-of-war John Adams, and participated in the engagements with the Mexicans under Com. PERRY until the ending of hostilities. In 1852, he was ordered to the steam frigate Mississippi, as flag-officer, but on the eve of sailing was transferred to the command of the frigate Powhatan, which vessel was fitted out at Norfolk, Va., and sailed for Japan In February, 1853. He remained absent on this cruise for three years, being attached to the expedition of Commodore PERRY. His last cruise was as Commander of the Home Squadron, in which capacity he received the Japanese Ambassadors on his flagship, the Roanoke, at Aspinwall, and brought them to this country. By the act of Congress, since passed, he was retired from active service, and took up his residence in this city. The disease of which he died was contracted during the Mexican war, but he was enabled to remain at the post of duty until within the past eight years, since which time he had been an invalid. A wife and one daughter remain to mourn his loss. The funeral will take place from his late residence, No. 23 Smith street, on Monday, 15th inst., at 2 1/2 o'clock, P.M.

abstract: Enrollment Bill, the, as Passed
snippet: Enrollment Bill, the, as Passed
lead_paragraph: Congress yesterday completed the Conscription Bill, and having already gone through the Senate, it now only awaits the President's approval to become the law of the land. The measure has had a stormy passage through the House, and there were times when we much feared it would suffer shipwreck. The Copperheads exhausted every resource of their peculiar tactics to obstruct action on the bill, and if they felt it was out of their power to kill it, they resolved at least to delay it as much as possible. As some important measures of the enrollment could not be carried into effect until the passage of the bill, they doubtless hoped to be able to throw the draft itself over beyond the 10th of March. This triumph has not been allowed them. And in the final vote on the bill as amended, the patriotic voice of the House spoke out clear and bold in a vole of ninety-three yeas against sixty nays.

abstract: Present and Prospective Strength of
snippet: Present and Prospective Strength of
lead_paragraph: The aggregate of force which the rebels now have in the field would be a very interesting as well as very important matter to settle definitely; but the absence of reliable data renders it somewhat difficult to do so. The rebel estimates themselves vary from a given number up to three times that number. In the late debate in the rebel House of Representatives, Mr. SMITH, of North Carolina, stated that "the Confederacy has at this time 400,000 men on its muster rolls;" but he goes on to add, "probably not one-half are actually in the field."

abstract: Thiers' M.; Speech
snippet: Thiers' M.; Speech
lead_paragraph: he momentous events of which our country is the theatre so absorb the public mind that there are few, probably who give heed to the operations of vital interest which the French for the past two years have been conducting in Mexico. The advices which from time to time have come to us respecting the cause of the French invasion of that Republic and the progress on the war have been of such a fragmentary character and generally colored to suit the French market on the one hand or the Mexican sympathizers on the other, that to the reader who has not made the matter a special study, the exact primary and present condition of the case is still likely to be a mystery. But in the speech of M. THIERS, delivered in the French Chamber on the 26th ult., which we publish this morning, this whole question will be found lucidly explained, and evidently with the highest regard to truth. Those, therefore, who would know the facts, will be thankful of an opportunity to read them as presented in the terse logical, and incisive manner which always characterizes the utterances of this French statesman.

abstract: Spencer, Herbert. Essays
snippet: Spencer, Herbert. Essays
lead_paragraph: Those who have read the Education: Intellectual, Moral and Physical, by this writer, will be prepared to welcome this new volume from the same source. Mr. SPENCER has achieved a high position as an original and comprehensive thinker, who subjects the most abstract and subtile questions to a searching and exhaustive analysis, with a rare efflux of illustration and a lucid and attractive style. These traits are fully displayed in the variety of articles constituting the present volume. Several of the papers, as "Representative Government -- What it is Good For;" "Reform: Its Dangers and Its Safeguards;" "Prison Ethics;" "State Tamperings with Money and Banks," and the "Morals of Trade," discuss the fundamental principles of government and society, and have an interest for all classes at the present time.

abstract: Scatteration Policy in Warfare
snippet: Scatteration Policy in Warfare
lead_paragraph: -- We confess to a decided inability to appreciate the wisdom of such expeditions as that to Florida, which we record to-day. Gen. GILLMORE has suddenly transferred the scene of his operations from before Charleston to Jacksonville, and we do not think the change one much to the credit of those who directed it. If the detachment of the expeditionary force does not in the least jeopardize the possession of Morris Island, if its works and garrison are still sufficient to hold their own against any enterprises into which BEAUREGARD might be tempted, it still remains difficult to see any adequate object to be accomplished by it. Jacksonville has already been twice occupied by our troops, and twice abandoned as useless, and because the forces were wanted elsewhere. There is not the smallest military importance in Florida, for the rebels have no force there worth speaking of, and the State has no strategio value whatever. Had we indeed a surplus of force which we did not know how to dispose of, it might be worth while in a purely political sense, to send an expedition to Florida which would occupy il en permanence, and enable the State to come back into the Union. We believe a majority of the people of Florida are in sympathy with us, and would gladly see the restoration of their State; but in order that this shall be made available, it is necessary to insure the permanent protection of the people. They cannot afford to show their loyalty if this is merely to be such another flying visit as they have had every Summer for the past three years. But have we the force to spare to do this? Can we afford to send ten thousand men into a kind of military coventry merely to accomplish this object? Surely not. We trust there is a wisdom in this move other than meets the eye; but, for the present, we can't see it.

lead_paragraph: Confederate currency has nearly lost its purchasing quality, and the strong arm of impressment has been substituted. This, too, has almost failed, and in a few months more will have lost its potency altogether. Efforts to improve the finances must be slow, no matter how effectual they may prove in the course of time. The army must be fed, while the experiments for improving the currency are being tested. How shall it be done?

abstract: Omens of Ruin--Debate on Employing Negroes
snippet: Omens of Ruin--Debate on Employing Negroes
lead_paragraph: Among the many despairing proceedings of the Congress at Richmond, which betoken the approaching dissolution of the rebel Government and the so-called Confederacy -- the gigantic impressment, (driving every able-bodied man into the army,) the forcible seizure of the crops, the summary repudiation of a debt of hundreds of millions, the public confession that they cannot feed an army of two hundred thousand men -- the most striking to our mind is the bill passed on Feb. 1, entitled "an act to increase the efficiency of the army by the employment of free negroes and slaves in certain capacities." By this act the Secretary of War is empowered to impress all male free negroes between the ages of 18 and 50, and to employ or impress all male negro slaves, to a number not exceeding 20,000, for any military service he may select. The wages and rations for both are to be the same with those of white soldiers; in the latter class, the wages are to be paid to the masters. In case of the death, or capture, or escape of the slave, the masters are to be compensated.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday a report was received from the Secertary of War, giving a list of officers in Washington who, by reason of being stationed there, draw commutation for quarters and fuel. A memorial was received from the Milwaukee Chamber of Commerce, asking that the Government grant military aid in opening a new route to Idaho, through Central Minnesota, in order to draw out the gold now awaiting shipment. The Senate then took up the bill equalizing the pay of soldiers. An amendment was adopted, giving colered soldiers the same pay as white troops, after Jan. 1, 1864. The discussion continued, but without coming to a conclusion, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Centralization in; Debate on Address; M. Pelletan's Speech
snippet: Centralization in; Debate on Address; M. Pelletan's Speech
lead_paragraph: The French Opposition have a truly Herculean task before them. Not only have they to win back liberty for the press, and to establish the right of the people to freedom of election, not only have they to restore independence to the tribunals, and to substitute responsible for arbitrary government, but, if they would not leave their work incomplete, they must destroy, root and branch, that all pervading system of centralization which is everywhere paralyzing the energies of their nation and unfitting it for the appreciation and enjoyment of political blessings. Centralization is that all-absorbing power of the State, which, under pretence of excessive concern for the welfare of the individual, strips him of all municipal responsibility, and reduces him to the condition of an automaton, who lives and moves and has his being merely as the sovereign authority directs.

abstract: Mr. Gibson's Speech
snippet: Mr. Gibson's Speech
lead_paragraph: Mr. T. MILNOR GIBSON, in his recent speech on American affairs, expressed himself as much surprised at one fact which he stated to his audiences, viz., that though this country was engaged in a gigantic war, which taxed all its resources, and though we had put into the field an army of a million men, who were of course so many withdrawn from peaceful avocations, and in the main from agricultural pursuits, yet the production of wheat in the country actually increased from 169,000,000 bushels in 1862 to over 191,000,000 bushels in 1863. The statement was felt to be so damaging by the secession sympathizers in England, that their Ajax, Mr. SPENCE, took it up at the meeting of the Society for the Establishment of Southern Independence. He admitted the fact as stated, but claimed that other products had diminished, and that this fact alone gave an erroneous impression.

abstract: Died, at the Union Hotel, in Kansas City, Mo. on Saturday, Jan. 23, 1864, THOMAS R. HOWLAND, o[???] Company F, Third Regiment Colorado Volunteers, aged 44 years, a native of New-York City. Mr. HOWLAND emigrated from New-York to the new El-dorado, then known as Pike's Peak, in 1859, and enlisted at Denver in 1863, in Capt. HOLLY's Company, Third Regiment Colorado Volunteers, and was appointed the company's clerk. They were ordered, via the Arkansas route, to Kansas, Mo. The deceased accompanied his command in their long and memorable march, crossing the snowy range through fifteen feet of snow, traveling on foot, a great part of the time on half rations, eight hundred miles in thirty-eight days. During this extraordinary journey, in the coldest weather ever known in this latitude, the thermometer had often fallen to twenty degrees below zero.
lead_paragraph: Died, at the Union Hotel, in Kansas City, Mo. on Saturday, Jan. 23, 1864, THOMAS R. abstract: The Washington Republican is authorized to announce that the telegraphic reports, published under date of Cincinnati, Feb. 11th, to the effect that parties arriving at Nashville from Knoxville, on the 10th instant, report that Cumberland Gap is cut off, and that nearly all that part of East Tennessee is in possession of the rebels, is not confirmed by any information in the possession of the Government, but, on the contrary, there is good reason to believe that the report is not true. If such news had been received at Knoxville on the 9th or 10th instant, it would certainly have been communicated to the Government before this time.

abstract: On Thursday night last the westward bound train on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad was captured ten miles west of Harper's Ferry, by a band of guerrilla robbers. The usual signal to stop the train was given, when the guerrillas surrounded it, and commenced a general robbery of the passengers, male and female.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night last the westward bound train on the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad was captured ten miles west of Harper's Ferry, by a band of guerrilla robbers. The usual signal to stop the train was given, when the guerrillas surrounded it, and commenced a general robbery of the passengers, male and female. Greenbacks, jewelry, and other valuables were taken, and few of the passengers escaped without losing something. The object seemed to be entirely to obtain booty, as notwithstanding several Union officers and soldiers were on board, no prisoners were taken. It is reported that the passengers lost, altogether, not less than $30,000 in money and valuables. The engine and tender were run off the track, but the train was not injured. The robbers then left, and it is surmised that they were a party of plundering desperadoes from both sides.

abstract: Report of Passage of the Potomac
snippet: Report of Passage of the Potomac
lead_paragraph: I have the honor to report that on Saturday, 6th inst., at 7 o'clock, I marched my command in the direction of Morton's Ford, in accordance with orders received about three hours previous to that time. I arrived at the headquarters of the cavalry reserve within half of a mile of the Ford, at 10 o'clock, A.M., and halted. At 10:35 I received orders to cross the river, which I succeeded in doing, and pushed the enemy back about half a mile, and then under orders not to press the enemy too hard, but to skirmish with him if he appeared so disposed, I halted my advance and made my disposition to hold the favorable ground which I had taken. In a short time the enemy began to concentrate troops in my immediate front, and to advance a stronger line of skirmishers. I communicated this fact to Corps Headquarters, through the signal officer, and asked for reinforcements; at 3:10 P.M., Cols. CARROLL and POWERS reported to me by order of Gen. HAYS, and I massed their brigades, (First and Second of the Third Division,) under cover from the enemy's fire, and in a position whence they could be readily deployed to the right or left, as circumstances might require. The enemy kept up a vigorous fire of small arms durng the day, and, at intervals, a heavy artillery fire from a battery in position on his left. Fresh troops were arriving continuously, and in great haste. At 5:20 P.M. the enemy opened with a heavy fire from his batteries, and shortly afterward advanced and attacked vigorously our right and right centre; but it was futile, as, under the personal supervision of the General commanding the division, the enemy was met and repulsed at all points.

abstract: XIX. The last year's experience shows that the planter and the negro comprehend the resolution. The overseer, having little interest in capital, and less sympathy with labor, dislikes the trouble of thinking, and discredits the notion that anything new has occurred. He is a relic of the past, and adheres...
lead_paragraph: XIX. The last year's experience shows that the planter and the negro comprehend the resolution. The overseer, having little interest in capital, and less sympathy with labor, dislikes the trouble of thinking, and discredits the notion that anything new has occurred. He is a relic of the past, and adheres to its customs. His stubborn refusal 10 comprehend the condition of things, occasioned most of the embarrassments of the past year. Where such incomprehension is chronic, reduced wages, diminished rations, and the mild punishments imposed by the army and navy, will do good.
