abstract: GENEROUS OCULIST. Mr. PETER GOUGLEMAN, oculist, doing business in Broadway, has been for some time furnishing poor soldiers, who have lost an eye in battle, with artificial ones, and so well has he counterfeited nature, that yesterday he was the object of a millitary visitation under the following circumstances. It appears that a soldier by the name of BAETER,...
lead_paragraph: GENEROUS OCULIST. -- Mr. PETER GOUGLEMAN, oculist, doing business in Broadway, has been for some time furnishing poor soldiers, who have lost an eye in battle, with artificial ones, and so well has he counterfeited nature, that yesterday he was the object of a millitary visitation under the following circumstances. It appears that a soldier by the name of BAETER, formerly of the First Massachusetts Artillery, who lost an eye at Fredericksburgh, called at the oculist's, and stated that he was poor, but, nevertheless, desirous of having a glass eye. Mr. GOUGLEMAN kindly furnished one, and the soldier went on his way contented. His journey, however, extended only to the Park Burracks, where he offered himself as a veteran for reenlistment. He passed the examination was sworn in, and received his bounty, $50 of which he sent to his mother in Massachusetts; the balance he deposited with the oculist. Before the glass-eyed recraft was fairly one of the rank and file, his former Captain, knowing of his defect, mentioned the matter to the recruiting officer, who singled BAXTER out, and accused him of dishonesty. BAXTER protested that he wanted to fight for his country again, and that nobody would know he had a glass eye if they would mind their own business. The recruiting officer, not satisfied with the argument, and imagining there was some complicity between the recruit and the oculist, waited on the doctor and threatened to arrest him if he did not produce the money BAXTER had deposited with him. This Mr. GOUGLEMAN was very willing to do, as the whole of the a[???]air both as far as the eye was concerned and the money, was the result solely of a generous motive. BAXTER still retains his eye, the recruiting officer the money, and the oculist his good reputation.

abstract: -- Major-Gen. F.P. BLAIR, in a letter indorsing Col. TAILOR, who has been speaking in different parts of the country, regarding the sufferings of East Tennesseans, writes: "After the battle of Chattanooga, I marched in command of the Fifteenth Army Corps, under Gen. SHERMAN, to the relief of BURNSIDE, at Knoxville. We passed through a country which had already been visited by both hostile armies, and pillaged with unrelenting cruelty by the rebels, on account of the loyalty of the people. Our troops worn without rations or supplies of any kind, having been ordered to give up the pursuit of BRAGG'S flying army, and march to the relief of Knoxville without an opportunity of obtaining anything of the kind, and were compelled to forage on the country. The people on our approach came out to meet us, bringing witn them their scant supplies, and freely offered them to our soldiers. They cheered us with kind words, and waved the old flag, which they had cherished in secret, and implored us to hasten to succor of their kindred, who composed a part of the garrison of Knoxville."

abstract: The Ministry and the Constitution; Resistance of Deputies to Government
snippet: The Ministry and the Constitution; Resistance of Deputies to Government
lead_paragraph: The Prussian imbroglio, though not likely to be attended with such tragic consequences as that about the Duchies, is yet little less complicated, and difficult of solution. Since WILLIAM and VON BISMARK deserted from the ranks of the Confederation, the breach between them and the Lower Chamber has been widening. The deputies have passed a series of resolutions denouncing the conduct of the Government, as traitorous to Germany -- have refused to sanction the loan demanded by it to meet the expenses of the war -- and have proclaimed that they will resist the Austro-Prussian "execution" by every means in their power. The latter avowal, however, on the part of the Chamber, was hardly necessary, for its rejection of the Minister's scheme was ample evidence of its determination to embarrass him as far as possible. But the Premier has resolved not to be incommoded by the action of the House, if he can at all avoid it. He declared to the committee that, should the deputies refuse the loan, he would get the money wherever he could, and if he can only find capitalists who will run the risk of advancing the cash to the Government, he is the very man that will not scruple to take it. Meanwhile, the ministerialists, in order to retaliate on their adversaries, have commenced a regular series of attacks on the Constitution, and the privileges of the members.

abstract: Police Bill at Albany; Premature Discussions in
snippet: Police Bill at Albany; Premature Discussions in
lead_paragraph: Congress seems to be acting on the belief that the world will come to an end as soon as it adjourns -- so far at least as opportunities for legislation are concerned. The members think it necessary to do everything instantly, lest the chance of doing anything should be lost forever. One would suppose that the prosecution of such a war as the Government has on its hands might wisely engross the attention of the National Legislature. The raising of men, the enactment of laws for the guidance and government of our armies, the wise imposition of sufficient and judicious taxes, these, and the kindred acts which the vigorous prosecution of the war requires, would seem to be sufficient for the present session. Congress thinks differently. It is fiercely eager for the settlement of all possible questions to which the war may now or hereafter give rise. What will be the position of the rebels after they are conquered; what shall be done with the lands we intend to seize; what is the present status, and what is to be the future history of the negro race; what loyalty is, and what it is not, -- these are some of the topics which Congress finds greater pleasure in discussing than in acting upon the plain, simple matters of business which might safely and profitably absorb their whole attention.

abstract: The Legislature of Colorado, convened at Golden city Feb. 2, and organized on the next day. Gov. EVANS' Message shows that Colorado is out of debt. Her relations with the Indian tribes are Satisfactory. The new modes of saving gold have given a new impulse to mining. The mines haw quadrupled in value during the past year. The Richest discoveries have been made during the same period. The quartz gold mines of Colorado already tested are found to be better, refined ledges recurring more closely together, extending over a wider district of country, surrounded with better facilities of working and yielding richer ores than those of any other country in the world. Agriculture has increased rapidly, and the profits from ten acres in Colorado, are equal to one hundred and sixty acres in Iowa or Illinois. The Governor recommends Congress that assistance be given to the wagon road to Salt Lake.

abstract: The steamship Morning Star from New-Orleans, Feb. 7, via Havana 9th, arrived last evening. At New-Orleans public attention was altogether engrossed in the canvass for the election of Free State Officers on the 22d ult., and the...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Morning Star from New-Orleans, Feb. 7, via Havana 9th, arrived last evening. At New-Orleans public attention was altogether engrossed in the canvass for the election of Free State Officers on the 22d ult., and the supporters of the opposing candidates for the Governorship -- Messrs. HAHN and FLANDERS -- Were carrying on a sharp contest for their respective candidates. Gen. Banks had issued a very important order bearing on the election, regulating a system of free labor, and prescribing the conditions of a residence in the State. No military operations are reported in the journals. The Morning Star brings information of the capture of a brig on the north side of Cuba, with a cargo of 700 slaves. The Spanish war-steamer Neplunio made the prize.

abstract: Reilly's Case
snippet: Reilly's Case
lead_paragraph: REVENUE LAW. -- As we expected, the contest between the liquor-dealers and the Government has resulted in the defeat of the former. We publish in another column the decision of Judge SHIPMAN, denying the motion for a new trial in REILLY's case. The new trial was asked for upon several grounds, mainly technical ones. Thus, his counsel claimed that because a jury was impanneled to try him before he was arraigned of had pleaded to the indictment, and when this fact appeared, that jury was discharged, and after he had been arraigned and pleaded another jury was impanneled by which he was tried. The trial was error, because it was contrary to the rule which provides that a man shall not be put in jeopardy twice for the same offence. But the judge holds that as he could not have been tried by the first jury, he was not then put in jeopardy. Law and justice appear to agree upon this point.

abstract: Gen. Niegre and Archbishop of Mexico, Differences Between; the Campaign now Opening
snippet: Gen. Niegre and Archbishop of Mexico, Differences Between; the Campaign now Opening
lead_paragraph: Those who, in the affairs of the war, are able to look somewhat beyond the active situation on the military chess-board, and reason on the effect of new moves and combinations, would do well to direct their attention to the campaign now opening in the Southwest. Unless we greatly misjudge, a reasonable success in the operations just set on foot in that quarter, must have the effect to bring about a complete change in the general military programme. If the interpretation we give these operations be correct, they form perhaps the grandest, boldest, and, by rights, most decisive move of the war.

abstract: The announcements at the various places of amusement to-night are as follows: At the Academy of Music, VERDI's celebrated opera of "Un Ballo in Maschera," with Mmes. MEDORI, ORTOLANI, BRIGNOLI, Mlle. SULZER and Signori MAZZOLENI and BELLINI in the cast. At Winter Garden the "Ticket-of-Leave Man" still holds the boards, and is likely to for many weeks to come. The management at Niblo's has announced the reengagement of Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS for twelve nights more, and admirers of the Irish drama may gratify their tastes by witnessing the successful comedy of the "Connie Soogah." At Wallack's, the coming week is to be devoted to "Pure Gold" and "Rosedale" on alternate nights. Mrs. WOOD announces a revival of the play -- some time since presented here -- of the "Pride of the Market," to be preceded by the petite comedy entitled a "Curious Case." At BARNUM's Museum "Helvel" has met with such success that it will be continued one week longer. The Museum presents an immense variety of other attractions, also, without additional charge.

abstract: Peace or War in Europe
snippet: Peace or War in Europe
lead_paragraph: The German question still remains unsettled and threatening. The Prussian troops are said already to have occupied Kiel, the port of the Duchies, the Federal troops from Saxony yielding place to them. Yet, as if to show that they did not mean to decide on the "succession question," the Prussians have ordered the withdrawal of the Duke of Au-gustenburgh's private guard. The combined Austro-Prussian forces are also reported to be just occupying the Duchy of Schleswig. The sole and avowed purpose of this occupation, it should be borne in mind, is to compel Denmark to respect the conditions to which she assented under the Treaty of 1852.

abstract: The members of the Produce  Exchange have acted most promptly and most liberally toward Officer ABRAHAM BESIMER, of the First Precinct, who was so badly stabbed recently while attempting to arrest Mr. TIBBETS, who made his appearance at the Exchange armed with knives, and threatening to kill end main all around him. Since the occurrence, the members have quietly gone to work and raised a munificent sum for Mr. BESIMER, which, by permission of Commissioners AOTON and BERGEN, was presented to him yesterday by Capt. WARLOW. The gift consisted of  $500 in Five-Twenties six per cent United States Bonds, $250 in cash, and sufficient money  besides to procure new suit of clothes in lieu of those cut pieces by the frenzied man's dirk. The action of the gentlemen of the Produce Exchange is most generous and appreciative, and while whole department will recognize its kind and stimulative character, we may say that to no officer in the department could it have been batter applied than to the ever faithful, reliable and courageous ALEXANDER BESIMER. It is pleasant to add, that the friends of the unfortunate Mr. TIBBETS have exhibited the utmost solicitude and consideration for Officer BESSIMER, extending to him every kindness and attention in their power. He is getting along well, and will entirely recover from his wounds.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday. The. Veterans of 1812 petitioned for $100 to pay their expenses of music, dinner, , on last 4th, of...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday. The. Veterans of 1812 petitioned for $100 to pay their expenses of music, dinner, , on last 4th, of July. They represent that this sum was appropriated for them, according to custom, by the committee to arrange the public celebration, but that they have not received it. Now they ask that it be given to them out of the appropriation to celebrate WASHINGTON's birthday. Referred to the committee to arrange the celebration of that day. The resolution containing an appropriation of 87,000 for use of this committee was taken up and adopted. A motion by M.JACQUES, to reduce the amount to 84,000 was lost. The Comptroller reported the receipts into the treasury last week to have been $510,807 27; payments during that time, $,523,173 72; balance on last Saturday, $2,199,529 79. He also reported the receipts of the Sixth and Eighth Avenuo Railroads for the last quarter of 1863, as follows: October, Sixth Avenue, $33,975 50; Eighth Avenue. $35,684 80. November, Sixth Avenue, $29,848 33; Eighth Avenue $31,843 01. December, Sixth Avenue, $32,740 71; Eighth Avenue, $35,523; The purport of the resolution amendatory of the Relief Fund Ordinance, adopted at the previous meeting, has been misunderstood. It does not prevent the extension of the benefits of the fund to families of soldiers not resident here at the time of their enlistment, but withholds aid from families of all soldiers not credited to New-York. The board adjourned to Thursday, at. 1 o'clock, P. M.

abstract: Recruiting was brisker at the Park Recrutting Office yesterday than it has been for some time past. From the returns made up to Saturday night it appears that 5,180 volunters have been recruited, and 1,821 veterans have reenlisted, making a total of 7,001. Leaving a deficiency in the quota of New-York County (viz., 18,000) of 10,999 which has to be filled by March 1. The present average rate of enlistments is about 250 per day, which will amount in 14 days, or on Feb. 29, to 3,400, a balance of 7,599 to be filled by drafting, when no further bounties will be paid.
lead_paragraph: Recruiting was brisker at the Park Recrutting Office yesterday than it has been for some time past. From the returns made up to Saturday night it appears that 5,180 volunters have been recruited, and 1,821 veterans have reenlisted, making a total of 7,001. Leaving a deficiency in the quota of New-York County (viz., 18,000) of 10,999 which has to be filled by March 1. The present average rate of enlistments is about 250 per day, which will amount in 14 days, or on Feb. 29, to 3,400, a balance of 7,599 to be filled by drafting, when no further bounties will be paid.

abstract: GENERAL ORDERS, No. 15,--The CommandingGeneral, learning of the desperate advance of the rebel hordes upon his lines in quest of bread, meat, clothing and plunder, gave up his leave of absence and has returned to his command, not so much from doubt of the ability of the troops to hurl back the enemy, as to share with them the honors, toils and privations of the opening campaign.

abstract: Progress of his Campaign
snippet: Progress of his Campaign
lead_paragraph: The campaign in the Southwest develops in the most auspicious manner, and some of the results which, though foreseen to be necessary consequences of the moves, could yet hardly have been anticipated as likely to come so promptly, already show themselves. We yesterday indicated that the advance of SHERMAN's column toward Meridian as an objective, might be expected to have the effect of calling off a portion of JOHNSTON's force from Dalton, and that the weakening of the rebel force at that point would in all likelihood be followed by the advance of the Union force from Chattanooga.

abstract: Early Yesterday morning preparations were made for carrying out the programme for the reception of the Forty-fifth New-York Regiment. The neglect shown many of our veterans who have returned from the field being felt, it was determined to partially stone for past coldness by giving the Forty-fifth a grand welcome. Consequently the Fifth Regiment, Col. BURGER commanding, assembled at 9 o'clock at Washington-square, preparatory to the reception of the heroes. At 11 o'clock, the Forty-fifth, escorted by the Fifth, entered the city Hall Park preceded by DODWORTH's Band, and were reviewed by the Mayer and Common Council. This ceremony ended, the veterans proceeded, according to previous arrangement, to FALK's Broadway Garden, where a verp fine collation had been prepared for them. Music, speeches and "a good time generally" followed. The Forty-fifth has been in service nearly three years, during which time it has seen a great deal of hardship and been in many battles. Over three hundred of the men have reonlisted , and are home to enjoy a thirty days' furlough. The old soldiers as they passed through the streets, bearing their flag " all tattered and torn," were greeted by cheers from the throng assembled to do them honor.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--VERDI'S favorite opera, "Un Balio in Maschera," was given here last evening for the first time this season, the cast being the same in all respects as heretofore. The performance was unusually spirited, and was received with great satisfaction by a fashionable and attentive audience.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- VERDI's favorite opera, "Un Balio in Maschera," was given here last evening for the first time this season, the cast being the same in all respects as heretofore. The performance was unusually spirited, and was received with great satisfaction by a fashionable and attentive audience. The male members of thp company have the beet opportunity in this work, and they were especially good Last night. We doubt if Signor BELLINI, the baritone, has ever been heard to better advantage. The fire and energy, too, of Signor MAZZOLENI, created a perfect furore. The barcarolle of the second act had, of course, to be repeated : many numbers, indeed, enjoyed that distinction. Mme MEDORI did not seem to be in her usual voice, but seized the dramatic opportunities of the role with all her consummate power and tact. Mlle. SULZER was, as usual, excellent as Ulrica, and Mme. ORTOLANI-BRIGNOLI sang the page's music very charmingly. The performance, in all vocal respects, was thoroughly acceptable. The orchestra, however, under Signor NUNO, did not quite realize the full effect of the score, owing, of course, to deficient rehearsals.

abstract: The war news from Gen. GRANT'S Department is highly interesting. A dispatch from Chattanooga states that Gen. LOGAN, with the Fifteenth Army Corps, left the vicinity, of Huntsville, Ala.,
lead_paragraph: The war news from Gen. GRANT'S Department is highly interesting. A dispatch from Chattanooga states that Gen. LOGAN, with the Fifteenth Army Corps, left the vicinity, of Huntsville, Ala., some days ago, moving southwardly, and we have rebel accounts of the presence of some of his forces at Lebanon, Ala., some twenty miles south of the Tennessee River. The cavalry expedition under Gens. GRIERSON and SMITH, started from Memphis, moving across the country southwardly. It was understood that these columns were intended to act in conjunction the one to attack, and the other to cut off the retreat of POLK and FORREST, whe were scouring Central and Northern Mississippi. This movement was generally regarded as a great flanking movement on JOHNSTON'S army. A Nashville dispatch to the Cincinnati Gazette says that Gen. SHERMAN entered Jackson, Miss., on the 5th, the rebels offering but little resistance, and falling back over Pearl River. It was thought that the rebels were receiving reinforcements from Dalton. There was a considerable fight at Clinton, Miss., on the 4th. Our troops charged a rebel battery, and lost 15 killed and 30 wounded. The enemy were driven off, and our troops continued their advance. Another dispatch from Chattanooga says that Gen. THOMAS' army is now in motion for Tunnel Hill and Dalton. All these reports indicate a grand combination of movements, having in view the complete redemption of Mississippi, Alabama and Georgia.

abstract: Speech at Produce Exchange, New-York
snippet: Speech at Produce Exchange, New-York
lead_paragraph: Major-Gen. W.S. HANCOCK, Commandant of the Second Army Corps, Army of the Potomac, visited the Produce Exchange, yesterday, during business hours. He was moat cordially welcomed by the merchants in attendance, many of whom were personally introduced to him. He entered freely into conversation with some of the leading business men, and took every available opportunity to impress on those present the urgent necessity of doing their utmost to encourage recruiting, so that our armies may be strengthened and prepared for a vigorous and desolve spring campaign, which promises to be the final one of the war.

abstract: Repudiation--Richmond Enquirer and Whig
snippet: Repudiation--Richmond Enquirer and Whig
lead_paragraph: We published two days since, two articles from the Richmond Enquirer of Feb. 4 and 5 respectively, as well as one from the Whig of the former date, all recommending the Confederate Government to give up all attempts to mend the currency or to impress supplies, but to buy everything they want cotton and tobacco. The Enguirer says that "the Confederate currency hae nearly lost its Purchasing power," and that the system of impressment, which was substituted for it. "has almost failed, in a few months more will have lost its potency altogether." What then is to be done?

abstract: Vallandigham, C. L., in the Supreme Court
snippet: Vallandigham, C. L., in the Supreme Court
lead_paragraph: The United States Supreme Court has decided against the application of VALLANDIGHAM to annul the sentence passed upon him by the military court. It pronounces that it has no jurisdiction over the case. In other words, that the military authority for the common defence, in time of war, inheres in the Commander-in-Chief to the exclusion of the civil authority.

lead_paragraph: Advices from North Carolina to the 13th inst. were received at this port yesterday by the steamship S.R. Spaulding. Maj.-Gen. PECK had arrived at Newbern and taken command, going vigorously to work to strengthen the defences of the place, and making other extensive preparations to receive the rebels if they again attack the town. Widespread dissatisfaction with the rebel Government is reported among the people of North Carolina, and a movement has been inaugurated, says the Wilmington Journal, in which Gov. VANCE is charged with being concerned, to take the State out of the Confederacy. The Raleigh State Journal had suspended publication, being the second paper in the city which had succumbed to lack of support of rebel principles.

abstract: Grant's Initiative in the Spring Campaign
snippet: Grant's Initiative in the Spring Campaign
lead_paragraph: There is no more encouraging feature of the grand campaign that has just opened up over the vast theatre of war, under control of Gen. GRANT, than the fact that it presents our armies in the imperial attitude that befits them -- that is, with all the moral and material power of the initiative on our side. Incalculably advantageous though this power be to the side able to wield it boldly, the campaigns of the past three years have too often presented the sorry spectacle of Union Generals and Union armies, in a war whose essential theory is the offensive, reduced to a passive defensive, waiting to take blows when they should have advanced to deliver them; and, on the other hand of the side whose natural attitude is one of defence, assuming a vigorous offensive and winning great advantages in consequence. LEE has twice been able to relieve the menaced Capital of the Confederacy by a bold initiative, forcing the Union armies across the Potomac, and pushing his invasion even into the Free States. It does not turn the force of the point to say that no direct material benefit was gained by these invasions -- that in both instances the test battle turned against the invaders; they gained enough to make the movements well worth while -- they relieved their soil of the Union armies for the time being, and they won prestige abroad, an element for which they are always willing to bid high. In like manner when the Army of the Cumberland, under Gen. BUELL, had advanced to within cannon range of Chattanooga, BRAGG was able, by a vigorous and timely assumption of the offensive, to throw his antagonist first back on Nashville, and then, by a second turning movement, threatening his communications, compel him to retire to his base on the Ohio.
headline: {'main': "Grant's Initiative in the Spring Campaign.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Grant's Initiative in the Spring Campaign.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: are going about the City now and almost daily engaging carman to take bales and boxes of goods from he walk in front of large stores and warehouses, to be delivered somewhere up town. The thief, arriving at the place of destination before the carman, receives the goods, pays the carman and dismisses him. On Tuesday last, a case of goods, valued at $2,340, was in this manner taken from the front of Messrs. SCHACK & HOTOP's store. No. 47 Murray-street, and conveyed to No. 48 West Nineteenth-street. Here the carman was met by one WILLIAM RICHARDSON, who paid the cartage, and told the carman that a mistake had been made, and that he wanted the goods taken to No. 148 West Nineteenth street; this the carman refused to do. At this time, Officer TILLEY, of the Third Precinct, who had been notified of the matter, emerged from his hiding-place and attempted to arrest RICHARDSON, but he ran away. Officer TILLEY pursued him, and after a run of several blocks, arrested him and took him to the Third Ward Station-house. Another case occurred at the store of Messrs. DENISON, BINSSE & Co., No. 98 Duane-street. Three cases of goods were at the store door, when a carman drove up and took one valued at $600; he was going off with it, when he was noticed by a young man engaged in the store, who stopped him and notified Mr. DENISON of the matter; the carman was found to have an envelope, given him some two blocks off by a young man, with instructions to go to No. 98 Duane-street, take the largest case of the three, and deliver it some one and a half miles up town; the case was sent to the place designated; but the thief, probably suspicious at the delay, failed to appear. If the carmen would make it a rule invariably to go in the store and ask whether the matter was right before taking any goods, this style of swindling would be immediately stopped.

The thief, arriving at the place of destination before the carman, receives the goods, pays the carman and dismisses him. On Tuesday last, a case of goods, valued at $2,340, was in this manner taken from the front of Messrs. SCHACK & HOTOP's store. No. 47 Murray-street, and conveyed to No. 48 West Nineteenth-street. Here the carman was met by one WILLIAM RICHARDSON, who paid the cartage, and told the carman that a mistake had been made, and that he wanted the goods taken to No. 148 West Nineteenth street; this the carman refused to do. At this time, Officer TILLEY, of the Third Precinct, who had been notified of the matter, emerged from his hiding-place and attempted to arrest RICHARDSON, but he ran away. Officer TILLEY pursued him, and after a run of several blocks, arrested him and took him to the Third Ward Station-house. Another case occurred at the store of Messrs. DENISON, BINSSE & Co., No. 98 Duane-street. Three cases of goods were at the store door, when a carman drove up and took one valued at $600; he was going off with it, when he was noticed by a young man engaged in the store, who stopped him and notified Mr. DENISON of the matter; the carman was found to have an envelope, given him some two blocks off by a young man, with instructions to go to No. 98 Duane-street, take the largest case of the three, and deliver it some one and a half miles up town; the case was sent to the place designated; but the thief, probably suspicious at the delay, failed to appear. If the carmen would make it a rule invariably to go in the store and ask whether the matter was right before taking any goods, this style of swindling would be immediately stopped.

abstract: BURNS, of Gettysburgh, the old hero, who alone of all the inhabitants there and thereabouts, shouldered his gun and went forth to fight the enemy, is in town. He paid a visit to the TIMES Office yesterday. Mr. BURNS is a hale-looking old gentleman, and bears on his face the indications of courage. He has recovered from his wounds. The Government have taken steps to properly provide for him by giving him a pension.

abstract: Brig.-Gen. J. VOGDES sailed Monday, in steamship Fulton for Hilton Head to join his command on Folly Island. Gen. VOGDES is a resident of Brooklyn, where he has been quietly sojourning for the past three weeks, having received a month's respite from the severe duties of his position in the front of Charleston. Gen. VOGDES will be remembered as the officer who relieved and saved Fort Pickens to the Government, and who was subsequently captured on Santa Rosa Island and held a prisoner eleven months. During four months of his captivity he was confined as a hostage for the rebel privateers. In the operations before Charleston he has borns ??? conspicuous part, having constructed the batteries on Folly Island which led to the capture of the whole of Morris Island. He also opened the third parallel in Fort Wagner. He is accompanied by his Aids, Messrs. KISSELBURGH and WILCOX.

abstract: A number of gentlemen met last evening at the rooms corner of Broadway and Twenty-third-street, for the purpose of organizing a Campaign Club, Owing to the severity of the weather, the number present was not so great as was expected; still, the attendance was good. Mr. CHARLES S. SPENCER being called to the Chair, made a short speech, saying that they had met for the purpose of organizing, to remain in active life during the year, a Lincoln Campaign Club, made up of men who support the Administration, [applause;] that the President should be reelected; he had well discharged his duties, faced every difficulty, and nobly borne up the banner through the war and to the present day; that he had the confidence of the loyal men of the North, and it would be the height of suicide now to cast him aside and take an untried man. On motion, a committee consisting of one representative from each Ward was appointed on organization and permanent officers. The committee is as follows: First Ward, Henry Smith; Second, Buckley; Third, Costar; Fourth, Liest; Fifth, Nathan Kingsley; Sixth, Dwyer; Seventh, McKiney; Eighth, Andrew Blakely; Ninth, Tousey; Tenth, J.R. Lawrence; Eleventh, Seaman Lawrence; Twelfth, Abram Wakeman; Thirteenth, H.A. Smith; Fourteenth. Borst; Fifteenth, Taylor; Sixteenth, Gardner; Seventeenth, John Lather; Eighteenth. Elliot C. Cowden; Nineteenth, Van Brunt; Twentieth, Hasty; Twenty first, James Owens; Twenty-second, Allen. The officers of the present meeting, and Mr. JAMES KNOX, were afterwards added. A communication was received from SIMEON DRAPER, Esq., inviting the "Lincoln Campaign Club" to meet with the "Union Lincoln Association" at the Church of the Messiah, on the evening of the 22d inst., at 7 1/2 o'clock, which was accepted. The meeting then adjourned to meet again on Wednesday evening next.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--DONIZETTI'S opera Of "H. Polluto" was given here last night. The house, as may well be supposed, was slim; and the performance, being new to all the artists, lacked spirit and ensemble. The individual singers were, in
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- DONIZETTI's opera Of "H. Polluto" was given here last night. The house, as may well be supposed, was slim; and the performance, being new to all the artists, lacked spirit and ensemble. The individual singers were, in separate numbers, good, and the fluent finale to the second act went off well, but the effect of the whole opera was hardly satisfactory.

abstract: as a Reconstructionist
snippet: as a Reconstructionist
lead_paragraph: WENDELL PHILLIPS has taken a new role. He has devoted his years hitherto to tearing down; now he is turning his hand to building up, as he calls it. It is an odd sight -- this veteran demolisher who has displayed nothing but a fierce heart and a violent hand now becoming an upbuilder, and lending himself to the work that, most of all, requires a cool head, a steady pulse, a sure eye.

abstract: Land Laws of England. Cobden-Delane Controversy
snippet: Land Laws of England. Cobden-Delane Controversy
lead_paragraph: The discussion between Messrs. COBDEN and DELANE has given a fresh impetus to the discussion of the Land Laws in England, and it is now being carried on with such vigor that there is little doubt that the Liberal party will, before very long, be forced to take it up and give it the most prominent place in their political programme. We shall probably, within the next ten years, witness as potent an agitation on this subject as that which preceded the passage of the Reform Bill, followed by a revolution still wider and more radical. It will not be due altogether, or even mainly, to the growth of democratic feeling in England, although this is perceptible. It will be due rather to the fact that the tendency to concentrate property of all kinds, and especially property in land, in few hands, which has shown itself in England during the last two hundred years, has, during the last fifty years, increased with alarming rapidity. The growth of commerce and manufactures, so far from lessening the inequality of conditions which has long been the curse of English society, has increased them. The class of yeomen or small freeholders who were for centuries the bone and sinew of the English population, disappeared in the course of the last century; the small shopkeepers and manufacturers are being fast driven out of sight by the large capitalists, and the increase of wealth among the middle classes, so far from helping to break up the land monopoly, and facilitate its distribution among a larger body of holders, has so far helped to strengthen and narrow it. In other words, the men who have made fortunes in trade become themselves competitors for the large estates, and use all their money and influence in making land more and more of a fancy article, and in increasing the obstacles to its transfer. The great ambition of every Englishman who makes a fortune in business, is to purchase an estate in the country, not simply because this is the safest mode of investing his money, but because it is the great and only way to found a family and take a place among "the aristocracy;" and, of course, the easier it is to keep land together and regulate its descent, the easier it is to found the family. There is probably no class in England more enamored of entail and primogeniture than magnates who began life as errand boys or junior clerks in the city.
headline: {'main': 'The Land Laws of England.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Land Laws of England.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: An exhibition will be given for the benefit of the "Institute of Reward for Orphans of Patriots," at Cooper Institute, at 2 and 7 1/2 P.M., on Monday next, the anniversary of WASHINGTON's Birthday. The Superintendent, Mr. RANDALL, several of the Principals and 1,000 scholars, will unite in the exhibition, which will be an interesting one to all lovers of juvenile entertainment. VALENTINE MOTT, M.D., LL.D., President, on behalf of the Board of Directors, has issued a circular asking for subscriptions toward the establishment of the "State Orphan House," no subscriptions binding until they amount to $50,000. when they will be payable to the Treasurer. ARTHUR F. WILMARTH, Esq., Home Insurance Company, No. 135 Broadway, or to any other person duly authorized by the Board of Directors.

abstract: A telegram from Cumberland Gap says that on the 12th inst. the rebel Gen. LONGSTREET had his headquarters at Morristown, and his army was encamped, under marching orders, at Strawberry Plains. Deserters, who are very numerous...
lead_paragraph: A telegram from Cumberland Gap says that on the 12th inst. the rebel Gen. LONGSTREET had his headquarters at Morristown, and his army was encamped, under marching orders, at Strawberry Plains. Deserters, who are very numerous, come into our lines reporting that LONGSTREET's confidence in his men is so slight that on that account he is deterred from attacking Knoxville. Our correspondent at Nashville furnishes interesting information of the situation both at Knoxville and Chattanooga, and gives an account of a recent serious affray between two regiments of cavalry belonging to JOHNSTON's army, in which forty-two men were killed and wounded.

abstract: Conscription and its Effects
snippet: Conscription and its Effects
lead_paragraph: As the end of the rebellion draws nearer, and its condition becomes more desperate, the oppression under which the Southern people labor is made to bear more heavily upon them, and there begin to be symptoms of a speedy resistance on their part. The newspapers, which have been and are heartily in the service of the leaders, indicate it by the violence with which they speak of the shifts and schemes employed by the people to escape from the tyranny which is burdening them. And it is indicated more plainly by the notes of hostility and defiance which rise, and grow louder and louder, in those parts of the Confederacy where the people have not wholly thrown away their care for their own freedom in the intensity of the struggle the past three years. In North Carolina especially, do we find these developments. Public meetings are held, whose resolutions attack the Conscription Act, denounce the despotism of the Confederate Government, and call upon Gov. VANCE to convoke a convention, and newspapers declare that "North Carolina cannot and will not submit to have every able-bodied man conscripted, and the whole State turned into a military camp."

abstract: The steamship Creole, from New-Orleans, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing advices to the 11th. There was little news, except that of a political character. The friends of Mr. HAHN, the regular Free State candidate for...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Creole, from New-Orleans, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing advices to the 11th. There was little news, except that of a political character. The friends of Mr. HAHN, the regular Free State candidate for Governor, held a grand mass meeting on the evening of the 10th, which was largely attended, Capt. STEPHEN HOYT, of Massachusetts, had been appointed Acting Mayor of New-Orleans by Gen. SHEPLEY, Military Governor. The registry of voters was proceeding rapidly. About 4,500 had been registered. Judge ATOCHA had withdrawn his name from the bolters' ticket as candidate for Auditor. He supports Mr. HAHN. The steamships Havana and Continental, from New-Orleans Feb. 9 and 10, the former via Havana Feb. 13, also arrived yesterday.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday a bill was noticed authorizing the New-York and  Harlem Railroad to extend their road from Fourth-avenue through Broadway to Whitehall-street, in accordance with the resolution passed by the Mayor and Commonalty of New-York, and further provide for the removal of the omnibuses from Broadway; also a bill amending the act relative to fees for searches in the office of the New-York County Clerk. A petition was presented from PETER COOPER relative to the New-York City Departments. Bills were introduced authorizing the construction of a Grand-street Ferry and South-street Ferry Railroad; to amend the general law relative to Fire Insurance Companies, in regard to the investment of their surplus profits. Bills were passed amending the act legalizing the Riot and Bounty Ordinances of the New-York Supervisors; incorporating the New-York; and Brazil Steam Navigation Company. The adverse vote on the Lexington-avenue Railroad, Bill was reconsidered, and the bill will be reconsidered.

abstract: We call the attention of the Provost-Marshal (if he have any authority in the matter,) to the fact that the service is suffering detriment by the selfish efforts of recruiting agents, in inducing volunteers to enlist in arms of the...
lead_paragraph: We call the attention of the Provost-Marshal (if he have any authority in the matter,) to the fact that the service is suffering detriment by the selfish efforts of recruiting agents, in inducing volunteers to enlist in arms of the service in which they are not needed.. Thus we understand that hundreds of men have lately been induced, by the arts of these men, to enlist in the heavy artillery. These agents hold out seductive representations of the charms of this branch of the service, and allure their victims by telling them they will have "good beds," "no marching" to do, etc., etc. Now, it will be as well for recruits to understand at once that these baits are all a delusion and a snare. What the service now needs is not heavy artillery, but light infantry ; and those who enlist in the heavy artillery will, beyond a doubt, in the majority of cases, be "transferred," and their dreams of "good beds," etc., prove as unsubstantial as the baseless fabric of a vision. There are, doubtless, a certain class of men who would be unwilling to enlist for the everyday work of the war, whom yet the large bounties would tempt to volunteer for the kind of fancy duty pictured by the recruiting agents in their alluring posters. If the agents can only swell their commissions, they probably care little for the mere fact that the promises under which they induced their recruits to enlist cannot possibly be made good. This should be looked after, for it is proving something of an obstacle to legitimate enlistments.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, yesterday, a resolution, by Mr. BRANDON, was  presented and laid over, to donate $300 to BRIDGET MULHARE, in consideration of the loss of an eye by her son, a boy of eight years, who was shot during the riots, while looking from the window of his mother's residence. No. 135 East Thirty-...
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, yesterday, a resolution, by Mr. BRANDON, was presented and laid over, to donate $300 to BRIDGET MULHARE, in consideration of the loss of an eye by her son, a boy of eight years, who was shot during the riots, while looking from the window of his mother's residence. No. 135 East Thirty-fifth-street. It was suggested that was subject belonging to the Board of Supervisors, but as the introducer of the resolution was not present, the paper was laid over. It appears that Mrs. MULHARE, who is a widow, has been at considerable expense for medical treatment of her son, and has applied to the Comptroller for a reimbursement of her outlays on this account. There is no provision of law to pay for personal damages by riot, hence the only way to meet such a case as this is to make a suitable donation. The board concurred in adopting the resolution for a Joint Special Committee of six, to act in conjunction with the Mayor and Gen. SANDFORD, to select a suitable plot in one of the public Parks for a Division parade-ground; and Messrs. Repper, Opdyke and Riley were appointed to act with Messrs. McMahon, Ottiwell and Ryers, of the Board of Aldermen. The board adjourned to one o'clock P.M. on next Monday.

abstract: Query as to Quotas
snippet: Query as to Quotas
lead_paragraph: -It is a matter of regret that the Secretary of War or the Provost-Marshal-General has not yet seen fit to define precisely the meaning of the call for troops, under which the draft is ordered for the 10th of March. It is shrouded in the most embarrassing obscurity, and we have been left to infer its meaning from such unauthoritative intepretations as have been put upon it by Washington correspondents. It has been generally understood that the call for 500,000 men included the call of last November for 300,000 -- that is, was simply an addition of 200,000 to that levy. But it is now claimed that Provost-Marshal-General FRY has explicitly declared that the call for 500,000 not only includes last November's 300,000, but also the draft of last Summer, and counts in, also, commuters under the $300 exemption clause. According to this interpretation, quite a number of States have already filled their full quotas; and it would appear that the call was simply made, for the purpose of adjusting the balance of dues from the States that have not furnished the requisite number. If this be the correct interpretation, why not have an authoritative announcement to that effect? -- and, if it be not correct, it would certainly be worth while that the public should be disabused of the erroneous impression. It will make a very important difference in the number of men to be added to the army. If the total reinforcement to be added to our effective force in the field is to be limited to the number that will remain from the President's call after all the deductions named have been made, it would indicate either a very great confidence in the speedy crushing of the rebellion, or else a very inadequate appreciation of the imperative needs of the country. The coming draft will certainly produce the benefit of adjusting the balance, clearing off all old scores, and making a clean sheet for future requisitions if they should be needed -- what beyond that we have no means of judging. We trust, however, it will give in addition a surplus sufficient to add handsome reinforcements to the thinned ranks of our veteran regiments.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SHERMAN introduced a bill to encourage immigration. The bill appoints a Commissioner of Immigration, who shall be an officer of the State Department, to be assisted by two clerks, who shall collect and...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SHERMAN introduced a bill to encourage immigration. The bill appoints a Commissioner of Immigration, who shall be an officer of the State Department, to be assisted by two clerks, who shall collect and dessiminate all needful knowledge concerning the resources and character of this country. A Superintendent of Immigration shall be appointed with an office in New-York, who shall procure and regulate the transportation of immigrants. Mr. WILSON, from the Committee of Conference on the Enrollment Bill, submitted the report of the Committee, which was read and ordered printed. The report fixes the commutation at 8300, but provides that this shall only exempt for one year. Mr. CONNESS introduced a joint resolution, directing the Provost-Marshal-General to enlist persons in the naval service, and that such enlistments shall be duly credited on the proper quota, but the recruits, in consideration of the opportunities for prize money, are to receive no bounties; the resolution also provides that the President may transfer seamen enlisted in the land service to the naval service, when the exigencies may demand it. An amendment was added that seamen, upon enlisting, shall receive three months' advance pay as a bounty, to be refunded from any prize money to which such enlisted seamen may become entitled.

abstract: Houses and Rents in New-York
snippet: Houses and Rents in New-York
lead_paragraph: -The advance in rents of dwelling-houses, this Spring, though not yet definitely determined, promises to equal 25 to 35 per cent. over last year, and, if we are to judge by present indications, with a very limited supply of houses. This large advance certainly seems unexplainable on any other hypothesis than that rents during the past year have been below the proportionate rates of other articles of necessity, which few people will believe. The large advance now taking place is simply owing to the unusually large demand for houses, coming mainly from a class of people, transient in their abiding-places extravagant in their habits, never before among us, and destined, by changes of circumstances, social and political to leave, ere long, as suddenly a[???] they have come. The City is overrun with refugees from the South, speculators and others from all parts of the country, who have rushed hither, attracted by the mania for speedy money-making, or by the fact that this City offers the most varied facilities for spending time and money, while the re-establishment of peace is being awaited. The hotels and boarding-houses have been thronged all Winter by crowds of Southerners, to whom, in comparison with prices current in rebeldom, everything has seemed cheap. With no faith in rebel currency, and a strong suspicion of that of this Government, real estate, especially desirable dwelling-houses, has seemed the most attractive investment they could make, and sales of such property, at greatly enhanced prices, have been very large. The speculators and transient residents here, with full purses, are inspired with a desire to appear aristocratic and ostentatious at any price, and so we are having an immense influx of "shoddy" families, who seize the beat houses, at the highest rents, though they may never have seen a kitchen range, or be able to tell the difference between a speaking-tube and a penny whistle. Hundreds of families long resident here will be crowded out of their houses this Spring by this advance in rents, which they cannot afford to pay, and be compelled to take up with fewer conveniences, or find refuge in the country. But as long as "shoddy" pays well, we suppose there is no help for it, the only consolation being that this state of things will last no longer than does the money of the fast-livers, and we shall see these irruptions on the face of society disappear even more rapidly than they have appeared.

abstract: THE CHARGES AGAINST THE CITY INSPECTOR AND HIS DEPARTMENT.--The Committee on Retrenchment and Reform of the Board of Alderman have de  termined to go on with an investigation of the charges made by THOS. N. CARR against the City Inspector's Department, and take all the testimony they can obtain...
lead_paragraph: THE CHARGES AGAINST THE CITY INSPECTOR AND HIS DEPARTMENT. -- The Committee on Retrenchment and Reform of the Board of Alderman have de termined to go on with an investigation of the charges made by THOS. N. CARR against the City Inspector's Department, and take all the testimony they can obtain bearing upon the matter. Mr. CARR tacitly refused to appear and testify, and this course obliged the committee to ask for power to compel Mr. CARR to come before them. A resolution to give this advantage to the committee has passed the Board of Aldermen, and in the other board has been referred to a committee, who have not seen fit to report upon it. The committee will proceed, in private, on Thursday, and from day to day, till the investigation is pursued as far as they can pursue it. The whole testimony, question and answer, will be written out, with the view of its entire publication on closing the examination. City Inspector BOOLE invites them to the closest scrutiny of the affairs of his department, and has written a letter to the committee, tendering any facility in his power to aid them in getting at full understanding of the management of his department. The subject of Mr. CARR's charges has been submitted to Gov. SEYMOUR, but he is averse, it is understood, to giving it consideration until there is supporting testimony or specific charges. The Grand Jury have also had the subject before them, but dismissed it after the examination of a few witnesses.

abstract: In the senate, yesterday, Mr. FOSTER, of Connecticut, introduced a bill to provide for the renting of abandoned lands, tenements,  c., in the insurrectionary states, and for the care and employment of persons freed by the Proclamation. The bill legalizes the action of the...
lead_paragraph: In the senate, yesterday, Mr. FOSTER, of Connecticut, introduced a bill to provide for the renting of abandoned lands, tenements, c., in the insurrectionary states, and for the care and employment of persons freed by the Proclamation. The bill legalizes the action of the Secretary of the Treasury in appointing supervising agents, and provides for suitable military protection, so far as it may not interfere with the purposes of any campaign. The Senate then took up the report of the Committee of Conference on the Enrollment Bill, and a number of Senators expressed their views upon it. After full discussion the bill was passed -- 26 ayes to 16 nays. Both Houses adjourned over until Tuesday next.

abstract: The steamship City of Manchester, from Liverpool via Queenstown, arrived yesterday afternoon, bringing three days' later news. The war...
lead_paragraph: The steamship City of Manchester, from Liverpool via Queenstown, arrived yesterday afternoon, bringing three days' later news. The war between Denmark and the German States had commenced. On the 31st of January, the Prussian Field-Marshal Gen. VON WRANGLE peremptorily summoned the Danes to evacuate Schleswig, which demand was refused by Gen. DE MEZA. Thereupon the Prussians passed the frontier, and shots were exchanged without effect. The Danes retreated, blowing up the Sorg bridge, and taking up a position near Missunde, on the River Schlei. Here, on the 2d, they were attacked by the Prussians, and a battle resulted, continuing six hours, in which troops of all arms were engaged, when the German forces were repulsed with severe loss. The battle was renewed on the 3d, at which time boats were ready for the transport of the German troops over the Schlei. Two Danish war-vessels had had an engagement with Prussian land batteries at Eckenforde. One ship was struck four times in the hull. No person was injured. On the 3d an embargo was placed upon all German shipping in Danish ports, and the first vessel detained was the Prussian brig Myrtha at Elsinore. The Danish fleet is considered numerous enough to carry out the embargo. The British Parliament was opened on the 4th by a speech from the Queen, and owing to the Danish question, the event excited the greatest interest, in anticipation that the policy of England would be speedily ascertained. An impression prevailed that the Government had left the matter open, to a considerable extent, to be influenced by the opinion of Parliament. The London Post says that England is in honor bound to furnish material support to Denmark, and other reports affirm that she is resolved to intervene actively in the conflict. Her first act would doubtless be the occupation of Copenhagen. It was possitively asserted that France and Russia would stand aloof, leaving England to act in the matter with out their assistance. In the Divorce Court on the 2d a motion was made in the case of the O'KANE-PALMERSTON scandal. The Queen's counsel moved that the case be made absolute, calling upon; the petitioner, O'KANE, to show cause why the trial should not at once proceed, or the case be stricken from the court records. The petitioner, in a letter to his solicitor, decides to drop the suit, but asserts his ability to prove his allegations. The London Times has an editorial on Mr. SEWARD's instructions to Mr. ADAMS to press the claims for damages done by the Alabama and reasserts its oft-expressed argument against the liability of the British Government. It questions whether Secretary SEWARD is in earnest, but will not suspect him of a design to seek a quarrel with England. Sir JOHN LAWRENCE, the new Viceroy to India, arrived at Calcutta on the 12th. The war on the frontier had ended. On the 5th of January the pirate Alabama was reported to be on the watch for vessels fifty miles south of Rangoon, which information conflicts with the report via San Francisco, that she was blockaded at Amoy on the 2d by the gunboat Wyoming. The Emperor NAPOLEON had received the address of the Corps Legislatif, and in reply dwelt on the necessity of maintaining a stable Government. Other Continental news is interesting.

snippet: and the Democratic Party; Hon. S. S., Speech on Slavery; (United States House)
lead_paragraph: It is related that JUANA, mother of the Emperor CHARLES V., upon the death of her husband, PHILIP the Handsome, of Austria, had his body laid in state in a magnificent dress, and watched over it, in the hope of returning life, till she could endure the rottenness no longer. It was wonderful devotion, but an American case far beats it. A King died here -- struck through the inwards one April morning by a cannot ball fired by certain lunatic subjects of his in Charleston Harbor. He was a King not handsome like PHILIP, but as hideous as sin. And yet not for three weeks but for almost three whole years, has his disconsolate relict hung over him, refusing to make him dead. It is only when human nature cannot possibly stand the stench longer, that consent is given to shovel him under.

abstract: Enrollment Bill, the Passage of
snippet: Enrollment Bill, the Passage of
lead_paragraph: a law. Both Houses, yesterday, agreed to the report of the Committee of Conference, and the President has, doubtless, signed it ere this. The essential changes made by the Conference Committee pertained chiefly to the exemption clause. The senate's proposition to fix the commutation at $400, was modified so as to retain it at the old figure of $300, and the House proposition that such commutation shall exempt for only one draft, was changed so as to permit the commutation to exempt for one year. In this shape the bill passed, and is, perhaps, as effective as we could hope to get it at the hands of Congress. It improves materially upon the old act, and its final passage is, after all, in sufficient time for the draft ordered on the 10th of March.

abstract: Prescott, William H., Life of, by Geo. Ticknor
snippet: Prescott, William H., Life of, by Geo. Ticknor
lead_paragraph: Mr. TICKNOR has written the life of PRESCOTT with the sympathy of a friend, the candor of a philosopher, and the learning of a scholar. It was not a difficult subject, perhaps, for a biographer, especially for one so well versed in the details of the art as the historian of Spanish literature. The character of Mr. PRESCOTT was a simple one in general, though it had its peculiarities; and his career, from the necessities imposed by his condition of health, and the uniform nature of his pursuits, had but little variety. Yet within these limits, the story told by his biographer has much of the picturesque, while what in the lives of other authors might be considered as ordinary incidents, in his case became extraordinary by the peculiar privation which he suffered, and by the energy of will and overmastering purpose which enabled him to overcome all defects, and achieve triumphs seldom won by those in possession of every advantage. The life of any successful man must always be of interest, for success in general implies a nice adaptation of means to ends, some happy disposition of nature, and an honest and laborious improvement of it. We care not what calling he may have pursued, if it be a worthy one and he has achieved distinction in it, it will repay us to sit down with the man, whether he be farmer, mechanic, merchant, sailor, soldier, statesman or what not, and listen to his narrative, first how he ruled his own spirit, and then came to rule or be superior to his fellows.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, bills were introduced relative to fees for searches in the County Clerk's office in New-York; making an appropriation for the payment of the state bounty to volunteers; amending the Fire Act of the Eastern District of Brooklyn; legalizing the grant to the Harlem Railroad Company. A resolution...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, bills were introduced relative to fees for searches in the County Clerk's office in New-York; making an appropriation for the payment of the state bounty to volunteers; amending the Fire Act of the Eastern District of Brooklyn; legalizing the grant to the Harlem Railroad Company. A resolution was offered authorizing the Comptroller to borrow, in anticipation of legislative action, such sums as may be necessary to continue the State bounty to volunteers. The Senate adjourned until Feb. 29.

abstract: The Board of Supervisors met specially yesterday to act upon the County Appropriation Bill for 1864, or rather that portion which must be submitted to the Legislature for sanction, and which was reported to the Board on last Tuesday by the Committee on Annual Taxes. The ordinance...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors met specially yesterday to act upon the County Appropriation Bill for 1864, or rather that portion which must be submitted to the Legislature for sanction, and which was reported to the Board on last Tuesday by the Committee on Annual Taxes. The ordinance making the appropriations was adopted precisely as it was presented by the committee, no additions or alterations being made. It foots up $1,117,990 16, and added to the $4,736,917 49 appropriated by permanent on the 26th ult., made up of items authorized by permanent laws, gives a total of $5,854,909 65 as the whole county budget for the year. What changes may be made in these figures at Albany it would be useless to conjecture. The board adjourned to 10 o'clock A.M., on Tuesday.

abstract: Louis Kunzze vs. The American Exchange Fire Insurance Company. -- This was an action to recover on a policy of insurance. The plaintiff, who is a jeweler, residing and doing business at Tompkinsville, S.I., insured the stock and fixtures of his store, and the furniture in his house, in the American Exchange Insurance Company, to the amount of $1,100. The policy commenced to run on the 1st of May, 1862. On the 24th of March, 1863, his premises were burned down, and his property destroyed. He alleges that it was worth at the time of the fire $804, but the company refused to pay this sum, and this suit is brought to recover it. The defendants allege that on the 23d of March, at plaintiff's request, the risk insured by them was transferred to another building, in Stapleton, S.I., whither the plaintiff purposed moving; and they further allege that at the time of the fire there were no goods in the store at Tompkinsville, and that plaintiff made a fraudulent and false statement of his loss.

abstract: ACADEMY of MUSIC.--The GAUNOD night was, as usual, an immense success. Every seat was occupied, and long before the commencement of the opera the familiar notice was suspended outside, saying: "Standing room only." The standing room was perhaps not to be found, but the people were none the less satisfied.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY of MUSIC. -- The GAUNOD night was, as usual, an immense success. Every seat was occupied, and long before the commencement of the opera the familiar notice was suspended outside, saying: "Standing room only." The standing room was perhaps not to be found, but the people were none the less satisfied. No opera ever produced in New-York has seized the general public so completely as "Faust." If it could be given every evening, we are persuaded it would be to the interest of the management. But this, in view of the newly inaugurated and successful subscription principle, is impossible. The performance last evening was in all respects admirable. Miss KELLOGG, who is without doubt the perfect Goeth???n ideal of Marguerita, sang with exquisite and even surprising power and taste. Miss SULZER was also unusually good; and of the male artists we can add nothing to, or detract from, the praise we have already bestowed upon them.

abstract: BOILER EXPLOSION AND DESTRUCTION OF A BUILDING. -- An explosion occurred in the iron foundry of Messrs. CORRENS & REED, corner of Water and Jay streets, about 4 ???/??? o'clock last evening, resulting in the partial destruction of the building and to the injury of several of the workmen. A fire had just been built in the boiler for the purpose of driving the fan of the furnace, preparatory to casting, when a loud explosion occurred, and the boiler was thrown some distance and turned upside down. The walls were shattered and the roof was lifted up several feet. A portion came down upon the ground foot with a crash, burying the men beneath. The walls were completely shattered, so as to render a thorough reconstruction necessary. An alarm of tire having been given, the firemen soon arrived, and, together with the police of the Forty-second Precinct, succeeded in exhausting the workmen. One man was impelled out of the front door and thrown across the street. The names of the injured parties are BARNEY MCGUERREN, residing at No. 19 Bridge-street, leg broken; PATRICK MCCRUDDEN, residing at No. 161 Water-street, scalded; PETER MCPHILLIPS, residing in Walworth-street, near Myrtle-avenue, cut on the face; JAMES BARRETT, No. 39 Main-street, bruised about the head. Drs. COCHRANE and YOUNG attended upon the parties and dressed their wounds. None of them appear to be dangerously injured.

abstract: One of the most important events in the history of the rebellion, and which inaugurates a new era in the manufacture of heavy guns, took place on Thursday. between 12 and 1 o'clock, at the Fort Pitt...
lead_paragraph: One of the most important events in the history of the rebellion, and which inaugurates a new era in the manufacture of heavy guns, took place on Thursday. between 12 and 1 o'clock, at the Fort Pitt Works. A gun, with calibre of 20 inches diameter, was cast on the Rodman principle, in some 22 minutes from the time of tapping the furnaces. The arrangements for casting this mammoth piece of ordnance were most perfect, and during its process everything worked like clock-work. The amount of metal used for this huge gun was 85 tons, or 170,000 pounds. The metal was melted in three furnaces, which were charged at 5 o'clock in the morning. At twenty minutes past twelve, everything being in readiness, the three furnaces were simultaneously tapped, and the molten metal was conveyed by means of three conductors to a large reservoir close to the mold. The mold was set perpendicularly in a mammoth pit, and was held in position by huge chains suspended from two large cities of a lifting capacity of forty tons each, and worked by steam. As soon as the reservoir was sufficiently charged, the metal flowed from it into the mold, and in twenty-two minutes from the time of tapping the furnaces, the mold was filled to within a few inches of the top. As the metal settled, the mold was filled by the workmen with metal from furnaces held in reserve in case of accident. The casting was perfected without the slightest confusion, the whole being done under the immediate superintendence of Mr. JOSEPH KAYE, foreman of the works.

abstract: Speech on Rebel Needs and Resources; Needs and Resources. Howell Cobb's Speech
snippet: Speech on Rebel Needs and Resources; Needs and Resources. Howell Cobb's Speech
lead_paragraph: The speech of HOWELL COBB, which we published a day or two since, pressed upon the people of Georgia two important points. The first was the absolute necessity of sending into the rebel army every man who could be found. He appealed to his hearers, with all the force that he was master of, to throw no obstacles in the way of the most stringent means of filling up the rebel ranks. If there was a prejudice which he could excite, if there was a false impression which he could produce, if there was a fear which he could call up before them, that would tend to prevent them from resisting or impeding this general conscription, he brought them all forward. He eulogized the rebel President, as he must needs when he was compelled to tell his hearers that he alone could say "who shall and who shall not be called into the field," and that" no other tribunal can decide that question; we must leave this power to him, or all must be lost;" and he had no words bitter enough for the men who tried to evade this call of the one man whom the necessities of the rebellion have clothed with absolute power over those deluded men who abandoned the Government of their fathers in pursuit of a "delusive phantom."
headline: {'main': 'Rebel Needs and Resources', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Rebel Needs and Resources', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Executive Committee of the New-York fire Department held a meeting on Thursday evening last, and the report then presented was very satisfactory. Mr. JAMES L. MILLER, the Chairman of the committee, and one of the best working members, has used great exertions for the advancement of this matter, and, aided as he is by great numbers of the exempts, substantial merchants, who in their younger days were "actives," will doubtless make it an enlire success. An office has been opened at No. 734 Broad way, under charge of Assistant-Engineer ALKEN, for hie reception of such articles as may be contributed by the citizens. A number have already been received, and, from present appearances, enoueh will be received to; make the space alloted the New-York Fire Department one of the most attractive in the Fair. A large number of merchants who are not members, but who are friends of the department, have also declared their intention to assist them. The department at White Plains have nobly responded to the call, and it is antioibated that nearly all the neighboring cities will do the same. At Yorkville the ministers of the various churches, called the attention of their congregations to the matter, and asked of them their cooperation. Over seventy companies have reported to the committee that they are "at work," and others who have not yet reported, are known to be also doing their best.

abstract: We learn from the Baltimore American, that during last week the force of Marshal McPHAIL succeeded in capturing one of the largest mails.
lead_paragraph: We learn from the Baltimore American, that during last week the force of Marshal McPHAIL succeeded in capturing one of the largest mails on the way to Dixie ever captured in this section of country. It consisted of letters from all parts of the United States, and had been left at a store on Baltimore-street, with a message to deliver it to a boy. It was given to the boy tied up in a newspaper, and by him delivered to the schooner Kent, bound to Herring Bay, Anne Arundel County. The schooner was taken on the river on suspicion of having goods bound for Dixie, and upon search the mail was found in a black traveling-bay belonging to one of the hands on board. An investigation traced it to the store spoken of, where the facts were learned about it. Besides the mail, a small lot of goods was found on board for Dixie, among which was, a small package for Gen. WINDER, Provost-Marshal-General, Richmond, and a number of excellent maps of the harbor of Charleston, and other important points of military interest. Besides the above, the force of Marshal MCPHAIL discovered a large deposit of gun caps, military braid, drugs, &c, which had been left on the roadside by a blockade-runner. The lot of goods that were packed consisted of the Blue Book and a number of copies of the Army and Navy Gazette of the United States. This seizure reflects great credit upon Marshal MCPHAIL and his efficient officers.

abstract: --Dr. DORAN'S new book, Their Majesties' Servants, is now in press and will shortly be issued by Mr. W. J. WIDDLETON. Under its rather affected title.
lead_paragraph: -- Dr. DORAN's new book, Their Majesties' Servants, is now in press and will shortly be issued by Mr. W. J. WIDDLETON. Under its rather affected title, (which refers to the license or patent granted by royalty to theatres in England as a prerogative of the Crown.) the work includes a complete anecdotical and biographical account of the English stage, from the restoration to the present generation of actors and dramatists. Mr. WIDDLETON's edition will form two volumes, 12mo, but, in conformity with the taste of the day, one hundred and fifty copies will be struck off on large paper, making two handsome octavos, and these copies will be illustrated with fine photographs of GARRICK, KEAN, Mrs. SIDDONS, Miss O'NEIL, and other celebrated actors and actresses, from the best character portraits of them extant.

abstract: Misery loves company, no doubt, but there was something more than the fact which that old proverb expresses, in the feeling of almost satisfaction, with which our people...
lead_paragraph: Misery loves company, no doubt, but there was something more than the fact which that old proverb expresses, in the feeling of almost satisfaction, with which our people read the announcement that hostile guns had been fired in Europe, and that the cloud of war which had been threatening in that quarter had really burst. And yet, we have not become so heartless a people as to rejoice when our neighbor's house catches fire, merely because our own is burning. Rather have we learned in the three bitter Years that we have passed through, to appreciate the evils of war as we never felt them before. And when we hear of four or five hundred brave men killed and wounded on the Eider, our hearts as instinctively think of the homes which have been made desolate, as if the fight were upon the Rapidan.

abstract: The Navy Department has received dispatches from the East Blockading squadron, detailing the capture of the British schooner Eliza and British sloop Mary, both from Nassau, while attempting to run out of Jupiter Inlet, Fla., with cargoes of cotton.
lead_paragraph: The Navy Department has received dispatches from the East Blockading squadron, detailing the capture of the British schooner Eliza and British sloop Mary, both from Nassau, while attempting to run out of Jupiter Inlet, Fla., with cargoes of cotton. One of the passengers on the latter was on his way to purchase machinery, with the intention of starting a woolen factory in the South. The sloop Caroline was also captured while attempting to run out of Jupiter Inlet. The British sloop Young Racer, laden with salt, was run ashore and destroyed. The schooner Wm.A. Kain was captured while waiting an opportunity to run the blockade with 57 bales of cotton and nearly 3,000 pounds of tobacco.

abstract: Effect of War in Europe
snippet: Effect of War in Europe
lead_paragraph: By the arrival yesterday of the steamship Africa at Halifax, we have three days' later advices from Europe. The news concerning the Dano-German war is very meagre. A dispatch from Hamburg on the morning of the 6th says that severe fighting has been going on, as numbers of wounded were constantly coming into Rends-burg; but no particulars were received, and it was supposed that the Prussians had prohibited the transmission of news. A later dispatch announces the evacuation of Schleswig by the Danes, and its occupation by the Allies. Nothing is known as to the capture of Missunde. The attack on that position on the 2d was made by a force of two thousand Prussians, who were opposed by two thousand Danes. The Prussians twice attempted to carry the Danish works by assault, and were repulsed on both occasions with heavy loss. In the British Parliament the Queen's Speech had been under consideration by both Houses, and an address in reply had been adopted. In the course of the debate in the House of Lords on the foreign policy of the Government, Earl DERBY characterized the policy of Earl RUSSELL as humiliating to England, and repudiated the idea of British responsibility to the Government of the United States for the depredations of the Alabama. He trusted such a reply had been forwarded, to Wadhington as would forever put an end to such demands. In his reply Earl RUSSELL said that England had not given the slightest promise of assistance to Denmark. In the Commons, during the discussion of the speech, Mr. DISRAELI expressed himself of the opinion that the Queen should have made some allusion to American affairs, and complained of her silence. Lord PALMERSTON replied vigorously, defending the course of the Government. At a ball given on the 3d inst. by LOUIS NAPOLEON, at the Tuileries, he remarked to a knot of Field-Marshals and Generals that the war in the North did not concern France, and her course, therefore, would be non-intervention -- a sentiment which was concurred in by those to whom it was addressed.

abstract: ANOTHER BANQUET AT THE METROPOLITAN HOTEL.--A costly and elegant entertainment was given on last Friday evening at the Metropolitan Hotel by Col. E. G. ALLEN, the owner of the patent of ALLEN  BRAND'S breach-loading gun, to the scientific operatives...
lead_paragraph: ANOTHER BANQUET AT THE METROPOLITAN HOTEL. -- A costly and elegant entertainment was given on last Friday evening at the Metropolitan Hotel by Col. E. G. ALLEN, the owner of the patent of ALLEN BRAND'S breach-loading gun, to the scientific operatives in the employ of Messrs. ROBINSON & CHAMBERLAIN, the manufacturers of the arm. About forty persons sat down to a sumptuous feast, and, after partaking of the substantiate, there was a genial flow of champagne, speeches and story-telling. Remarks of an appropriate character were made by Col. ALLEN, Messrs. E. ROBINSON and E. CHAMBERLAIN, Col. HAYES, who crossed the Rocky Mountains with Gen. FREMONT, HORATIO F. AVERILL, Esq., of the New-York Bar, Col LEE, a cousin of Gen. R.E. LEE, of the rebel army, and others. We have rarely seen so much real enjoyment among a party of gentlemen. The official reports of "ALLEN's breach-loading rifle," speak of it as something really remarkable. One hundred and forty-eight rounds were fired at the rate of ten rounds in sixty-two seconds, without the slightest heating of the arm, and it is understood that the manufacturers are unable to supply the great demand for this new invention of firearm.
