abstract: One of the most horrible murders that has for a long time past occurred in this City, was committed about 11 o'clock, on Friday night, at No. 339 Seventhavenue. A wife was murdered by her husband, and so far as the investigation of the case has proceeded...
lead_paragraph: One of the most horrible murders that has for a long time past occurred in this City, was committed about 11 o'clock, on Friday night, at No. 339 Seventhavenue. A wife was murdered by her husband, and so far as the investigation of the case has proceeded, it would seem that it was almost coid-blooded and diabolical act. The actors in the drama are EDWARD HUNTER and his wife ELIZABETH; the former about 47 years of age, a native of England the latter aged 44 years, and reported to have been born in Albany, this State. For some time past the two have not been living on good terms, and it appears from the testlmony which we publish below, that the wife left her husband some time ago, and has since steadily refused to cohabit with him on the ground of ill-treatment which it is alleged was practiced by him to such an extent that her life became endangered. On Friday evening some of the members of the family, who reside with the father in Seventh-avenue, wishing to go to the theatre sent for the mother, who was living by herself in Tenth-street, to go to No. 339 and take charge of an infant during the evening. The wife and mother went to the house of her husband, and while all the family, except a lad 11 years of age, were absent at the theatre, the murder was committed. The deed was performed with a hatchet, the blade of which was sunk deep into the brains of the poor woman. The deceased is said, by those who knew her best, to have been a most amiable and inoffensive woman. The husband was arrested soon after the deed was committed.

abstract: the Question of the
snippet: the Question of the
lead_paragraph: Among the questions which tend continually to trouble and perplex Europe, that arising from the abnormal position of the Danubian Principalities, and the restless character of their Sovereign, is not the least knotty and prominent. It was one of those questions on which the Emperor NAPOLEAN based his plea for a general congress, and it would seem as if his French Majesty and Prince COUZA were determined that it should remain still a bone of contention for the Great Powers to snarl over.

abstract: A dispatch from Cairo gives further details concerning the brilliant advance of Gen. SHERMAN'S army. It passed through Jackson, Miss., in two columns, driving the enemy so precipitately across Pearl River that he left his pontoons and two pieces of artillery behind him. Our forces...
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Cairo gives further details concerning the brilliant advance of Gen. SHERMAN'S army. It passed through Jackson, Miss., in two columns, driving the enemy so precipitately across Pearl River that he left his pontoons and two pieces of artillery behind him. Our forces seized provisions and supplies, and swept on, reaching Meridian in the short space of ten days after leaving Vicksburgh. Large numbers of deserters had come to our army from Tennessee, Kentucky and Mississippi regiments. Refugees report that great fear is felt by the Mobilians at the threatened attack upon the city. The rebels have there a garrison of 15,000 men.

abstract: Free Labor, Capabilities of
snippet: Free Labor, Capabilities of
lead_paragraph: There has been nothing more remarkable in the history of the Slavery question, both here and in Europe, than the implicit faith which the public has always placed in the accounts of negro character and capabilities. This could, of course, scarcely be said if the subject had possessed no importance for the outside world, except an ethnological or physical one. In that case, nothing could be more natural than that the mass of people should be content with such accounts of them as those whites who had more dealings with them chose to tell; but the question of their laziness or industry, their strength or weakness, their acquisitiveness or carelessness, their docility or indocility, have, for over half a century, been of the very greatest interest in a commercial point of view. The supply of at least two of the articles which play the most prominent part in modern trade, is both entirely due to their labor. Their quality as laborers was, therefore, a matter of great interest to merchants, even while they were all slaves; and soon as any portion of them became free, of course it became of twice as great interest as ever. Accordingly, few discussions have ever been carried on with more violence and persistence than that about the industrial value of the few negroes of the British West Indies, and yet at the end of thirty years nobody seems to know much more about it than at the outset. The planters, whose ruin emancipation has either caused or precipitated, maintained stoutly that it was impossible to secure from free negroes the regular and steady labor necessary for the successful cultivation of either cotton or sugar. One portion of the public here and in England has always accepted their testimony as conclusive; another portion refused to believe them, both on general principles of human nature, and because the witnesses were interested parties and naturally prejudiced in favor of the slave system and against the negro. As the demand for cotton and sugar, and especially cotton, continued to increase, and as land was to be had in Jamaica and elsewhere for an old song, and as both Englishmen and Americans have been ransacking the earth for the last half century for things to speculate in, it will always remain a marvel that no effort was made up to this day to test the matter practically, by offering the free negroes regular wages for regular work. Nothing seems simpler than to go to Jamaica, buy a plantation, and try, cash in hand, to get the blacks to labor. Half the ventures in which merchants risk their capital every day are twice as wild as this, and yet it was positively never done; and if this war had not broken out, it is probable it never would have been done; a singular illustration of the force of a prejudice, even among such an intensely practical class as capitalists looking out for an investment.

abstract: --At the select ball given by the Empress EUGENIE in her private apartments at the Turleries recently, her Majesty wore a white dress shot with gold, and with gold fringe at the bottom of the skirt and at the upper part of the corsage. A belt of gold...
lead_paragraph: -- At the select ball given by the Empress EUGENIE in her private apartments at the Turleries recently, her Majesty wore a white dress shot with gold, and with gold fringe at the bottom of the skirt and at the upper part of the corsage. A belt of gold encircled her waist. Her head-dress was in green velvet, ornamented with diamonds and emeralds, and the necklace formed of several rows of pearils with drops of emeralds. The Princess CLOTHILDE wore a blue dress trimmed with lace and looped up with bows of crimson velvet. The Princess MATHILDE was in white and black; the Countess WALEWSKI in lilac and white; the Duchess DE MORNY, in pink; and the Countess DE POURTALES, in blue, with a veil of blue gauze forming a turban, and fastened on the front of the head by an ornament of precious stones, Madame FLEURY was in white, black and gold, and wore a head-dress of an original kind. A plate of dead gold came forward from the comb and advanced as far as the forehead.

abstract: There is one thing in which the Enrollment Act is defective, and that is in not making the draft permanent and continuous, instead...
lead_paragraph: There is one thing in which the Enrollment Act is defective, and that is in not making the draft permanent and continuous, instead of occasional and desultory. It has left it to the discretion of the Executive to call out troops at such times and in such numbers as it deems necessary; but the tendency of every Administration is and will be always to avoid all resort to a draft as long as possible. It is, in many respects, a vexatious and always a heavy burden; and the Executive not unnaturally will always shrink as long as it can from the unpopularity which is sure to result from imposing it. We have had ample experience of this already. The consequence is that when the draft at last has to come, it is a tremendous draft that alarms the community, disturbs industry, and drains the labor market. Regiments are allowed to dwindle down to skeletons, and 1,000 men are needed to bring them up to their proper strength.

abstract: Prussian Constitutionalism
snippet: Prussian Constitutionalism
lead_paragraph: The most difficult of all things to reconcile are liberty and royalty. "Monarchy," says MAZZINI, "has succeeded nowhere save in England." But why has it succeeded in England? Because there a foreign dynasty was brought in, after the expulsion of the Stuarts, to fill the throne, which having no power in the country, and owing its dignity altogether to the favor of the nation, or of a faction, was content to barter its prerogatives for the honors and emoluments of the kingly office. Monarchy has, in fact, succeeded in England, because in England monarchy is no longer itself, but a nomocracy -- a government of law, a government of the representatives of the people, not that of the individual, whether man or woman, who wears the crown. Various attempts have been made, in the present century, to establish English constitutionalism on the European Continent, vat if we excent the Nehterlands which have been ever free since they threw off the Spanish yoke, and the recently formed Kingdom of Italy, those attempts have everywhere proved partial or total failures. They have succeeded very imperfectly in the Peninsula; they have been utterly abortive in France; and, that they have fared no better in Prussia, let passing events proclaim.

abstract: Re d' Italia; Iron Frigate trial at New-York
snippet: Re d' Italia; Iron Frigate trial at New-York
lead_paragraph: Since Noah's ark was made, the bulwarks of ships have been high and straight. When iron-clads came in vogue these features were preserved, and iron laid plainly on the old-fashioned sides. The Re d'Italia is the first broadside armored vessel with newly-shaped bulwarks. Her sides Illustrate an attempt to counteract the oscillatory influence of armor, by inclining the upper portion of her bulwarks toward the centre of her hull. The idea is American, and its first practical test is over. Nothing hitherto. written about this craft has touched this point -- to which every other attribute is secondary, Hence the importance of the trial trip, just concluded.

abstract: The explosion at BUCHANAN  BULLARD'S paper-mill, at Schuylerville, Saratoga County, which was briefly noticed in Saturday's Times, proves to have been one of the most destructive boiler accidents that ever occurred in this vicinity. This papermill boiler moved horizontally, with fearful velocity,...
lead_paragraph: The explosion at BUCHANAN & BULLARD's paper-mill, at Schuylerville, Saratoga County, which was briefly noticed in Saturday's Times, proves to have been one of the most destructive boiler accidents that ever occurred in this vicinity. This papermill boiler moved horizontally, with fearful velocity, passing like an iron-clad ram, or a combination of 200-pound shot, through eleven buildings, wrecking them as completely as if an earthquake had toppled them over. The calamity took place at 2 o'clock on Saturday morning, when many of the structures were filled with slumbering occupants, all unconscious of danger; and it is really wonderful that scores of people were not killed and wounded. Thus far, only two of the victims have died, but several others were injured.

abstract: Death of Hannah Kelly, the last slave in
snippet: Death of Hannah Kelly, the last slave in
lead_paragraph: -- Hannah Kelley, reported to be the last alave in Pennsylvania, died in Cross Creek township Jan. 15, at the advanced age of 103 years. She was owned by John Gardner, deceased, formerly of Jefferson township, but for a number or years has been boarded with lier free colored relatives in Cross Creek township. Not withstanding her great age she was remarkably healthy, and gave fair promise of outliving her grandchildren, had she not been brought to her death by a horrible accident. Rising early on New-Year's morning, she was warming herself by a very large fire at the end of a coal scaffold, close by the door other house, and in some way caught fire, and was so terribly burnt before assistance could be given that she diep.

abstract: Circular of Attorney-General on; Dinner and Presentation to; Williams, Austin B.
snippet: Circular of Attorney-General on; Dinner and Presentation to; Williams, Austin B.
lead_paragraph: SIR: Many persons, against whom criminal indictments or against whom property proceedings under the confiscation laws are pending in the courts of the United States, growing out of the participation of such persons in the existing rebellion, have in good faith taken the oath prescribed by the Proclamation of the President, of the 8th of December. 1863, and have therefore entitled themselves to the full pardon and restoration of all rights of property, except as to slaves and where the rights of third parties have intervened, which that proclamation offers and secures. The President's pardon of a person guilty of acts of rebellion will, of course, relieve that person from the penalties incurred by his crime, and where an indictment is pending against him therefor, the production of the pardon, signed by the President, or of satisfactory evidence that he has complied with the conditions on which the pardon is offered, if he be not of the class excepted from the benefits of the proclamation, will be a sufficient reason for discontinuing such criminal proceedings and discharging him from custody therein. Nor is it less doubtful that a bona fide acceptance of the terms of the President's Proclamation by persons guilty of acts of rebellion, and not of the excepted class, will secure to such a person a restoration of all the rights of property except as to slaves, and where the rights of third parties shall have intervened; not-withstanding such property may, by reason of those acts of rebellion, have been subject to confiscation under the provisions of the Confiscation Acts of Aug. 6, 1861, chapter 60, and July 17, 1862. chapter 195. For without adverting to any other source of power in the President to restore their rights of properly, the 13th section of the Act of July 17, 1862, authorizes the President, at any time thereafter, by proclamation, to extend to persons who may have participated in the existing rebellion, in any State or part there of, pardon and amnesty, with such exceptions and at such times and on such conditions as he may deem expedient for the public welfare. It will hardly be questioned, I suppose, that tne purpose of this section, inserted in a law mainly intended to reach the property of persons engaged in the rebellion was to vest the President with full power to relieve such persons on such conditions as he should prescribe from the penalty of loss of their property by confiscation. Although the proceedings for confiscation under the Acts of August 6, 1861, and July 17, 1862, are in rem against the property seized, ye under both acts the ground of condemnation is the personal guilt of the owner in aiding the rebellion. By the pardon and amnesty, not only is the punishment of that personal guilt remitted, but the offence itself is effaced, that being the special effect of an act of amnesty of the Government. Of course it arrests and puts to an end all penal proceedings founded thereon, whether they touch the person or the property of the offender. There is, therefore, no case of judicial proceedings to enforce the penalties of acts of rebellion which cannot be reached and cured by the constitutional or statutory powers of the President to grant pardon and amnesty, whether those proceedings be against the person of the offender by criminal indictment, or against his property under the Confiscation Acts referred to. The President has accordingly directed me to instruct you that in any case where proceedings have been commenced and are pending and undetermined in the district or Circuit Courts of the United States for your District, against a person charged with acts of rebellion, and not of the excepted class, whether they be by indictment or seizure and libel of his property for confiscation, the rights of other parties not having intervened, you will discontinue and put an end to these proceedings, whenever the person so charged shall produce evidence satisfactory to you that he has, in good faith, taken the oath and complied with the conditions prescribed by the President's Proclamation of the 8th of December, 1863. Nor is it necessary that the evidence he produces should be a deed of pardon signed by the President. It would be quite impossible for the President to furnish the multitude who are now availing themselves of the benefits of the proclamation, and who are likely to do so hereafter, with this formal evidence of pardon; it will be sufficient to justify your action if the party seeking to be relieved from further proceeding shall prove to your full satisfaction that he has in good faith taken the oath, and brought himself within the conditions of pardon and amnesty set forth in the proclamation. If in any case you have good reason to believe that the oath has been taken for the mere purpose of obtaining the possession of personal property seized under the Confiscation Acts, with intent to remove it from the subsequent reach of the officers of the law, you will make report of the facts and reasons for your belief at this office before discontinuing the proceedings or restoring such property to the possession of the owner. Fugitives under section 5 of the Act of July 13, 1861, chapter 3, are not of the class reached by the President's Proclamation; for under that act, the question whether the property seized is subject to forfeiture depends upon the predicament of the property itself, and not upon the personal guilt or innocence of its owner. In this respect forfeitures under that act have more resemblance to cases of prize of war captured at sea as enemy's property, than to proceedings under the Act of August 1861, and July 1862. Such forfeitures are provided, not so much to punish the owner for disloyal acts, as to prohibit commercial intercourse and weaken the public enemy, which are always efficient instruments and legitimate effects of public war. But although the remission of forfeitures under the Act of July, 1861, are thus not within the scope of the Proclamation of Pardon, still ample power is conferred on the Secretary of the Treasury by the 8th section of that act to mitigateor remit all forfeitures and penalties incurred under the act. And it is not to be doubted that in all proper cases under that act, where the owner of the property residing in the territory in rebellion compiles with the condition of the proclamation, the Secretary of the Treasury will exercise the power of remission of such forfeiture in the same spirit of generous forbearance and liberality which inspired and characterized the proclamation.

lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Huntsville, Ala., gives the bald statement that a heavy battle is reported to have taken place between the forces of Gen. SHERMAN and the rebels under POLK, near Brandon, Miss., in which POLK was whipped, and lost 13,000 in prisoners alone. A few days since the report of a battle at Brandon came to us from rebol sources. The same dispatch says that Gen. Dodge has frustrated an attempt on the part of a large force of rebels to cross the Tennessee River at three separate ferries. The enemy are believed to have been Rhoddy's command. Our loss is reported to have been slight.

This paper -- like MERCER's -- will be thoroughly Anti-Slavery in tone, and I think will be called the Murfreesboro Daily Tribune. Murfreesboro is a place of three thousand population, and, at least during the war, will have a large national garrison located within its limits. The country about is thickly settled, and no doubt, need be entertained as to the success of the new journal.

abstract: Edinburg Review on England Preceding Waterloo
snippet: Edinburg Review on England Preceding Waterloo
lead_paragraph: Almost all foreign criticisms on our war, and a very large number of the domestic ones have been based on the assumption that war is necessarily fatal to national prosperity, if protracted beyond a very short period. In other words, that the outbreak of hostilities reduces production to a point at which saving or the accumulation of capital becomes impossible. The fact of a nation being engaged in an armed struggle, however, let it be on ever so extensive a scale, is by itself no more a proof that its progress is suspended, than lavish expenditure on the part of an individual that he is ruining himself. We have in each case to ascertain the proportion borne by the outlay to the income before we can form any opinion in the matter. If the drafts made by war on the labor and capital of the country be so heavy that there is no surplus after the ordinary wants of the people and the army are satisfied, it is high time to make peace. The prolongation of the contest after this point produces much the same effect as bleeding might be expected to produce in a man who was suffering from debility.

abstract: Campaign; Mobile Threatened
snippet: Campaign; Mobile Threatened
lead_paragraph: Although the grand objects of SHERMAN'S advance have been from the start evident to every one capable of looking at the map with a military eye, yet we have, ever since he crossed the Big Black, been left in tantalizing obscurity as to his progress. This state of things has been the necessary consequence of the manner in which Gen. SHERMAN has made his march. Having gone forward to stay, and expecting to open up a new base on the Gulf, he cut himself entirely loose from his base on the Mississippi, abandoned his line of communications, tore up the railroad and bridges in his rear, and thus severed all communication with the world that is behind and awaits with eagerness the reports of his progress. In this condition of things it was plain enough that we should have to depend on the rebels for our current history of this important movement.

abstract: Livingston, Edward, Life of, by C. H. Hunt; Dana, J. T. Text-Book of Geology
snippet: Livingston, Edward, Life of, by C. H. Hunt; Dana, J. T. Text-Book of Geology
lead_paragraph: The author of this handsome volume was attracted toward the subject of it from being intrusted to prepare the notice of EDWARD LIVINGSTON'S life for The New American Cyclopedia. Finding that no satisfactory record existed of the man whose career so strongly excited his sympathies, he determined to become his biographer. After the commencement of his task he was, fortunately for his purpose, intrusted with the whole mass of private papers and correspondence left by Mr. LIVINGSTON, and still in the custody of his surviving daughter and her husband. The unrestrained use of these invaluable materials has enabled him to produce a work of singular interest -- one, indeed, as important for the civil and political history of the times in which its subject was a chief actor, as it is delightful in picturing to the life, a character almost unique in his talents, virtues, and loveable qualities. LIVINGSTON, indeed, was no common man. He combined in unexampled measure with the high ability and culture that connect his name with his country's glory, the domestic virtues, the sweetness of temper, and the charm of untroubled cheerfulness, through the most wearing vicissitudes of fortune, that endeared him to his family and private friends. The circumstances that placed him in the light of a penal legislator and jurist, caused his name to be better known to the educated public than that of any other American, WASHINGTON alone excepted. How nobly he filled the functions allotted to him, the slightest acquaintance with legal literature will show. His System of Penal Law for the State of Louisiana, is never named by philosophical jurists without praise. Its publication fixed his rank among the leading reformers and philanthropists of the day, while its professional merits have secured him in the deliberate judgment of the "most competent living authority, the title of the first legal genius of modern times." This work, though admittedly the crowning monument of his fame, and sufficiently important to have occupied the working hours of an ordinary life, was one incident -- a mere episode in the busied and varied career of its author. The recital of this must be sought in Mr. HUNT's volume by the rising generation; but it still lives in the memory of many cotemporaries of his later years. Few men have filled with equal success the parts of so many-sided a life of public service. Repeatedly a member of Congress, United States Attorney, Mayor of New-York, Aid-de-Camp and Military Secretary to Gen. JACKSON, United States Senator from Louisiana, Secretary of State, and Minister to France -- in all capacities he was never found wanting, but secured the esteem and respect of all that were associated with him. He was, in every sense, a genuine son of New-York. Mr. HUNT commences his work with an interesting genealogical sketch of his family, the LIVINGSTONS, who have played a part of such importance in our State and colonial annals; and it should not be forgotten that his noble disregard of self, and devotion to the sufferers in the fearful prevalence of yellow fever in New-York during the term of his Mayoralty in 1803, it was that exposed him to the abuse of his confidence by a subordinate, from whence resulted the temporary ruin of his fortunes, and his removal to the Southern section of the country, with which his name became afterwards associated, even more intimately than with his native State. A vacant niche in the Pantheon of American Biography has been well filled by Mr. HUNT's labor of love. By it the man and the statesman is securely placed in the attitude that will be appreciated by posterity, when personal memories have faded out. Mr. BANCROFT's introduction is a masterly sketch of LIVINGSTON's services to his country. A word must be said about the mechanical execution of the book. It is equal in typography to the best current specimens of European bookmaking, and in paper, print, and graphic embellishment leaves nothing to be desired.

abstract: a Southern Loyalist, Death of
snippet: a Southern Loyalist, Death of
lead_paragraph: -- We mentioned, yesterday, the death of Hon. JOHN E. BOULIGNY, a Union member of Congress from Louisiana -- one of the few Southern men who adhered to the cause of the Union from the very beginning, at the sacrifice of all his property and great numbers of his oldest and most devoted friends. He was a man of ability and of high character; and his action in this contest involved sacrifices and losses on his part which few of our Northern people can fully understand. He leaves his family unprovided for. His last efforts were to secure for them, at the hands of the Committee on Private Land Claims in Congress, compensation for property taken by the Government for public uses. At the last Congress the claim was favorably considered by the same committee, and there would seem to be special reasons of decided, force why it should receive prompt attention from the present Congress. We feel confident that the peculiar circumstances of the case will lead the committee to take as early action as possible upon it.

abstract: Richmond papers up to the 20th, received at Fortress Monroe yesterday, fully confirm the rapid progress which Gen. SHERMAN has already been reported as making. An official dispatch to the rebel War Department of the 18th announces his arrival at Quitman, Miss., a point on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, twenty miles south of Meridian, toward Mobile.
lead_paragraph: Richmond papers up to the 20th, received at Fortress Monroe yesterday, fully confirm the rapid progress which Gen. SHERMAN has already been reported as making. An official dispatch to the rebel War Department of the 18th announces his arrival at Quitman, Miss., a point on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad, twenty miles south of Meridian, toward Mobile. The dispatch adds that "the movement was the boldest of the war." It also says that Meridian was evacuated on the 14th, and that Gen. SHERMAN meditated no step backward, as he was destroying the railroad in his rear. His progress had been uninterrupted, but the rebels announce that a desperate fight will be made at Mobile. Gov. WATTS had issued a proclamation, announcing that the city was about to be attacked, and requiring non-combatants to leave. According to dispatches from Mobile, Admiral FARRAGUT's fleet had made its appearance off Pascagoula, on the 14th, moving eastward, and on the 18th evidently made an attack on the rebel fortifications at Grant's Pass, which leads from Mobile Bay to Pascagoula Bay, between Dauphin Island and the mainland. A dispatch of the 19th says he had not renewed his attack, but gives no details of the one that had evidently taken place. Stormy weather prevailed, which was the cause of the delay.

abstract: The only obstacle to be encountered was the fact that EICHELER had then a wife living somewhere in this country. He assured the widow that for good reasons he had commenced a suit for divorce against his wife, and that there was an excellent prospect of a speedy and favorable result. In that event the marriage was to be consummated at once. The law's delay rendered the fair widow impatient, and when a fellow-countryman, named JOHN MAEN, proposed for her heart and hand she consented to become his wife, and five weeks ago they were married. Since that time the husband and wife have resided at No. 69 Division-street. When EICHELER became cognizant of this fact, he was at first highly indignant, and subsequently very gloomy and dispirited. Last Wednesday morning he visited the place, and had an interview with Mr. and Mrs. MAEN. He told the latter that he did not care to live any longer now that she was the wife of another. Late the following evening EICHELER returned to MAEN's recidence, and said that he was going to enlist in the army the next day, and had come to bid them both good-bye. He took out his pocket book and offered some money to Mr. MAEN, at the same time urging the latter to go out and get two bottles of wine, with which to take a parting drink. MAEN declined to go for the wine and EICHELER thereupon went for it himself. Subsequent events showed that EICHELER's motive was to get MAEN out of the room, and during his absence to murder the wife. This is the only conclusion to which one can came, judging from what immediately followed. EICHELER was absent but a short time, when he returned with two bottles of wine and three tumblers. In each of the tumblers he had secretly placed a quantity of white powder, which, as subsequent chemical analysis proved, was arsenic. Wine was poured into the tumblers, and all the persons engaged in the affair drank of it. MAEN was, however, suspicious that all was not right, and drank very sparingly of the liquid. EICHELER was noticed to be very much excited during the drinking of the wine, and left hurriedly immediately after. Mrs. MAEN soon became alarmingly ill and remained so for many hours despite the most active remedies which her physicians could administer.

abstract: the Asylum for the
snippet: the Asylum for the
lead_paragraph: -- A petition has been sent to the Legislature embodying complaints from some of the pupils against the management of the institution for the education of the blind. We understand that a committee has been appointed which will at once proceed to investigate these charges, which relate to alleged deficiencies in the boarding department, severity in the discipline of the institution, &c. The management of this, which is one of the oldest and most useful of our charitable institutions, is in the hands of some of our most excellent and most highly esteemed citizens, who give to it a great deal of their time and personal attentention. They allege that these complaints emanate from a few of the pupils, who have been necessarily restrained in the indulgence of vicious propensities, and who have taken this method of revenging themselves. Whatever the facts of the case may be, it is well that they are to be made the subject of prompt official inquiry; and it is to be hoped that the results may be laid with equal promptness before the public, whose judgment in the matter should not be prejudged by one-sided statements.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The rentree of Signor BRIGNOLI last night in BELLINI�s opera of �Purltani,� was the occasion of a very pleasant demonstration on the part of the public toward that deservedly popular artist. On his entrance he was received not only with the usual demonstrations of applause, but was greeted also with a floral tribute from the ladies such as we seldom see paid even to the favored of their own sex. Signor BRIGNOLI was embarrassed by the warmth and honest earnestness of this reception, and in his ??? grand scena, �Ah! te oh l cara,� barely did justice to himself. A tremendous and unmistakable encore gave him the opportunity of once more placing himself correctly before the audience; of showing that he still has a voice unequalled in quality, and mezzo-roce that has never been surpassed. The return of this fine artist enables Mr. MARETZEK to produce many operas that would otherwise be lost to the season, and his addition to the company is therefore a most valuable boon to the public.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The rentree of Signor BRIGNOLI last night in BELLINI�s opera of �Purltani,� was the occasion of a very pleasant demonstration on the part of the public toward that deservedly popular artist. On his entrance he was received not only with the usual demonstrations of applause, but was greeted also with a floral tribute from the ladies such as we seldom see paid even to the favored of their own sex. Signor BRIGNOLI was embarrassed by the warmth and honest earnestness of this reception, and in his ??? grand scena, �Ah! te oh l cara,� barely did justice to himself. A tremendous and unmistakable encore gave him the opportunity of once more placing himself correctly before the audience; of showing that he still has a voice unequalled in quality, and mezzo-roce that has never been surpassed. The return of this fine artist enables Mr. MARETZEK to produce many operas that would otherwise be lost to the season, and his addition to the company is therefore a most valuable boon to the public.

lead_paragraph: The one hundred and thirty-second anniversary of the birthday of WASHINGTON was celebrated, yesterday, with more than ordinary enthusiasm. The military display was not equal to former occasions, but the "turn out" of the people was unusually large and enthusiastic. Flags were displayed from the public buildings, prominent places of business, and many private residences, and in various other ways was the disposition to commemorate "the day we celebrate" manifested.

abstract: The rebel Congress has finally concluded its action on the Military Currency and Tax Bills, which the papers publish in full, but which we have not room for this morning. The measures are of the most sweeping description. The Congress had also passed a bill to suspend the writ of habeas corpus, another to abolish blockade-running; and another to put all this business in the hands of the Government, which should send out only cotton and tobacco for food and supplies.

abstract: The escape of the Yankee officers from the Lib. by continued to be the liveliest topic of yesterday, and conjectures were rife as to the means of the escape other then those described in the published accounts. The sentinels, as usual, were enriched with...
lead_paragraph: The escape of the Yankee officers from the Lib. by continued to be the liveliest topic of yesterday, and conjectures were rife as to the means of the escape other then those described in the published accounts. The sentinels, as usual, were enriched with laurels that their nauve mouesty, if nothing else, would cause them to decline. After all, however, this grand delivery does not exceed in glory or secrecy the escape of JOHN MORGAN from the Ohio Penitentiary, and yet neither the connivance nor carelessness of sentinels or others have received any credit from MORGAN or his historians, Yankee or Southern. It is most probable, in fact, that this distinguished General is, more than anybody else, responsible for the success with which STREIGHT and his chums made their exit from the Libby. The experience and example of the one was an admirable lesson for the other.

abstract: Mr. Pomeroy's Circular on; Circular on Mr. Chase; Congress, Address and Adjournment; Raffling at; Abandonment of
snippet: Mr. Pomeroy's Circular on; Circular on Mr. Chase; Congress, Address and Adjournment; Raffling at; Abandonment of
lead_paragraph: By last evening's mails we received full files of Richmond journals from Feb. 9 to 20 inclusive. Their contents are interesting. The particulars of affairs in Alabama, especially at Mobile, are meagre, but show that SHERMAN's approach had inspired the authorities with great fear. The escapade of Union officers from Libby Prison had created great excitement, and the papers award the fugitives great credit for their adroitness. Fifty-eight of the one hundred and nine who escaped, are said to have been recaptured. The rebel Congress adjourned on the 18th for a vacation until May next, after passing the Tax Currency and Military Bills, and appointing a day of fasting and prayer on the 8th of April next. These measures are of the most desperate character. The present currency is compulsorily funded by a repudiation of one-third of its value on the 1st of April next; a tax of live to fifteen per cent, is levied on all real, personal, or mixed property; while the conscription sweeps all classes and conditions into the army. The habeas corpus is suspended, and tobacco and cotton are to be run through the blockade, to get food from foreign sources. The Congress issued a long address before it adjourned, intended to bolster up the hopes of the desponding rebels a few months longer. An article in the Richmond Examiner, on the prospects of the Confederacy, reviews the military situation, and thanks its stars that matters are no worse than they are -- that certain anticipated disasters have not occurred, and that a recent rebel raid actually captured a railroad train and a steamboat -- from which it draws the consolation that rebel prospects are hopeful and cheering. In the generosity of our hearts, 'twould be cruel to refuse them these little crumbs of comfort.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The performance of "lone," last evening, was received with peculiar favor by the audience.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The performance of "lone," last evening, was received with peculiar favor by the audience. Sigor MAZZOLENI, in particular, seemed to be the object of the warmest attention on the part of his friends; his entree was the occasion of a perfect ovation. Beyond a tardy recognition of this gentleman's merits in the embarrassing role of Glauco, we see no particular reason for this demonstration. The same enthusiasm might have been bestowed with equal propriety upon Madame M??? and Mlle, SULZER, who completed (in the absence of Signor BIACHI, who was unwell,) the really remarkable cast of this opera.

abstract: In reference to the siege of Corinth he had high military authority for saying that it could not have been more wisely conducted than by Gen. HALLEOK. If there has been disaster, impartial history will attribute it to others besides Gen. HALLEOK. That Gen. HALLECK has not always been consulted, and, when Consulted, his opinion has not always been adopted. So far as the Army of the Potomac was concerned, victory had always perched upon their banners against equal numbers, and if Gen. HALLECK's advice had been taken after the splendid victories of South Mountain and Antietam, and a column sent up on the Virginia side to intercept, the rebel army would have been captured by Gen. MCCLELLAN. He considered that the refusal to do this was unjustifiable. Mr. JOHNSON also referred to the battle of Gettysburgh, which he considered one of the finest battles on record. At a critical juncture, when it was all-important that the enemy should be pursued, Gen. MEADE, feeling the responsibilities of his situation, consulted with Corps Commanders, who advised against the movement: he thought Gen. MEADE should have assumed the responsibility. We should look, however, at the facts in the case. Should he have failed in his purpose, the Government would then have been at the mercy of the rebels.
lead_paragraph: In reference to the siege of Corinth he had high military authority for saying that it could not have been more wisely conducted than by Gen. HALLEOK. If there has been disaster, impartial history will attribute it to others besides Gen. HALLEOK. That Gen. HALLECK has not always been consulted, and, when Consulted, his opinion has not always been adopted. abstract: Alabama, Pirate, Debate in House of Lords on Dispatch withheld by Mr. Adams; Liverpool Post on the Alabama and American Claims
snippet: Alabama, Pirate, Debate in House of Lords on Dispatch withheld by Mr. Adams; Liverpool Post on the Alabama and American Claims
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords on the 10th, the Earl of Derby said, there is another question which I should like to put to the noble Earl, but, as I have given him no notice, I will either take his answer now, or repeat my question on Thursday. The noble Earl has laid various papers on the table of the House, and, among others, the correspondence with the Government of the Federal States of America on the subject of the Alabama. I have seen elsewhere that a considerable amount of correspondence has taken place upon another subject -- namely, the remonstrances made as to injuries apprehended or sustained by American commerce from vessels sailing from British ports. I wish to know whether the Government are prepared to lay upon the table that correspondence as well as the dispatches relating to the Alabama; and, further, whether they are prepared to produce any correspondence containing representations on the part of the Government of the apparent violation of the law by American cruisers in enforcing their rights, and also with respect to some very curious decisions which have been come to in the prize courts of the United States.

abstract: Pearson, Zachariah C., English Blockade-runner, Troubles and Trials of
snippet: Pearson, Zachariah C., English Blockade-runner, Troubles and Trials of
lead_paragraph: Mr. ZACHARIAH CHARLES PEARSON, Ex-Mayor of Hull, who went so largely into the blockade-running business, with such an unsatisfactory result, both for himself and his creditors, has had a hearing before the Bankruptcy Court. Some of his creditors seem to have opposed his discharge, and he was examined before the Commissioner as to his past transactions. He seems to have been in the condition of the man whose tombstone told his story as follows: "I was well; I wished to be better; I took medicine, and here I am" In 1860 ZACHARIAH'S business was "in a flourishing state." He was well. But he wished to better, and took to, blockade-running, and like almost all men who go into an illegitimate trade, he found himself very speedily a bankrupt.

abstract: The Chesapeake case is now fully decided. A few days ago the Admiralty Court, at Halifax, decided that the vessel should be delivered to her owners.
lead_paragraph: The Chesapeake case is now fully decided. A few days ago the Admiralty Court, at Halifax, decided that the vessel should be delivered to her owners. The Police Judge at St.Johns, before whom several of the vessel's piratical captors have been tried, has ordered the prisoners to be committed to jail, to await delivery to the United States under the Extradition Treaty. The Judge declares that the pirates had no proper commisions nor authority for their act, and that it was simply piracy, robbery and murder. The prisoners will make application for a writ of habeas corpus, so as to bring the case before the courts.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday Mr. GRIMES presented a petition from citizens of Idaho, praying for a division of that territory, because one portion is inaccessible to the other.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday Mr. GRIMES presented a petition from citizens of Idaho, praying for a division of that territory, because one portion is inaccessible to the other. Mr. HALE presented the petition of certain naval contractors asking for relief because the price agreed for their work would not compensate them. Mr. SHERMAN introduced a bill to amend the act to aid in the construction of a Pacific Railroad. The bill changes the value of shares from one thousand to one hundred dollars each, and authorizes the issue of one million of them. The bill makes other important changes. The Secretary of War was instructed to transmit to the Senate the evidence adduced before the military commission which tried the cases of officers charged with speculating in cotton. A bill was passed to enable Colorado and Nevada to form State Governments. The Senate then took up the joint resolution reviving the grade of Lieutenant-General, and after a very lengthy discussion, in which the merits of Gens. MCCLELLAN, GRANT, HALLECK, and others were freely discussed, the Senate adopted the amendment reported by the Military Committee, striking out the recommendation of Gen. GRANT for the position, and the resolution as thus amended, passed, yeas 31, nays 6, and the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Memphis Meeting
snippet: Memphis Meeting
lead_paragraph: A mass convention was held yesterday in Memphis, inaugurating a general movement in Tennessee for the reorganization of the civil government in the State. One of the features of the call, we observe, is that "emancipation immediate and unconditional is our best and only true policy." The Unionism of the State has settled firmly on that principle.

abstract: By the steamers Hecla and City of London, which arrived at this port yesterday, we have foreign advices to Feb. 11 inclusive, four days later. The news is highly interesting.
lead_paragraph: By the steamers Hecla and City of London, which arrived at this port yesterday, we have foreign advices to Feb. 11 inclusive, four days later. The news is highly interesting. In Parliament, on the 9th and 10th, brief but important debates took place concerning the dispatches of Mr. SEWARD to Mr. ADAMS, in which he alludes to claims for indemnification which this Government may present for the ravages done by the Anglo-rebel privateers. The Earl of Derby demanded to know if such a dispatch had been received by the British Government, and Earl ROSSELL said not. Mr. LAYARD, in the House of. Commons, on the 10th, made a statement to the same effect. The case of the Alexandra was likely to come before the House of Lords. The war in Denmark was progressing very unfavorably for the Danes. The pressure of the Austro-Prussian forces was so great that the Danish Commander had evacuated Schleswig entirely and abandoned the great Danish fortification, the Dannewerke, leaving sixty guns to fall into the hands of the Germans. Several severe engagements had been fought, resulting against the Danes, though not without severe loss to the invaders. An engagement occurred on the 6th near Obersse, between the Austrians and Danes, in which the latter were defeated, with the loss of six guns and 200 prisoners. Col. Prince WILLIAM, of Wurtemburg, was severely wounded. A telegram from Kiel, of the 7th, says the Danes were retreating in great haste to Jutland, leaving the Germans in full occupation of Schleswig. The excitement in Copenhagen, because of the abandonment of the Dannewerke, was so great as to induce the King to recall the Danish Commander and his Chief of Staff, and a strong clamor was setting against the King. A dispatch from Flensburg, Feb. 9, says the Germans took that place after a severe fight, in which they lost 1,100 in killed and wounded. Rumors of an armistice prevailed, but they were not authentic, for the Danish Bigsraad had voted in favor of a vigorous prosecution of the war. The comments of the English and French press on recent events was one of regret that Denmark should have been placed in such a humiliating position, but offering no succor. The English papers warn Austria and Prussia against pursuing their course to an extremity, and that a day of retribution will soon be at hand. The tone of the German press and official documents seemed to grow bolder and more defiant with the successful advance of the armies. The pirate Florida left Brest on the night of the 9th, and the Kearsage was supposed to be in pursuit. Continental news unimportant.

abstract: An important order relating to the sale of cotton has been issued by Gen. GRANT. Nashville is made a depot, and everybody having cotton or other produce for sale can carry it to market and sell it, in accordance with the United States Treasury regulations.
lead_paragraph: An important order relating to the sale of cotton has been issued by Gen. GRANT. Nashville is made a depot, and everybody having cotton or other produce for sale can carry it to market and sell it, in accordance with the United States Treasury regulations. This allows competition among buyers and sellers, and bars all opportunity for speculation among military officers. All cotton dealers are ordered from the front. As our army advances, depots will doubtless be established further South.

abstract: Yulee, Senator, and the Amnesty Proclamation
snippet: Yulee, Senator, and the Amnesty Proclamation
lead_paragraph: -A letter from St. Augustine, Florida, mentions that Senator YULEE has never held office under the Confederate Government, nor in the State Government of Florida since she seceded, and that he therefore comes within the terms of the Amnesty Proclamation. It would be a little curious if YULEE should avail himself of this. He was one of the active conspirators at Washington during the closing months of Mr. BUCHANAN's Administration, forming one of that little clique of Senators and members of Congress from the South who directed the movements of the rebels in the Southern States, and pulled the wires of the secession machinery. Among the letters recently found in the houses of leading rebels at the South was one from YULEE, written from Washington early in January, 1861, saying that, upon consultation, the Secession members had decided to remain in Congress as long as possible, in order to defeat measures that might be brought forward against the rebellion -- such as raising troops, making loans, &c., &c. These men staid there just as long as they could be useful to the rebel cause and escape hanging, and then they resigned, and went to their own place. YULEE was one of them. It would be nothing remarkable to see him turning back again, and taking the oath he has already broken, for the sake of avoiding the punishment he has richly deserved. But we hope he will be modest, and put it off as long as possible.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--The popular manager was favored with a good house last evening, notwithstanding the stormy threatening of the weather. The old but ever acceptable opera of "Somnambula" afforded the opportunity for the second appearance of Slgnor BRIGNOLI. He appeared, in the first...
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The popular manager was favored with a good house last evening, notwithstanding the stormy threatening of the weather. The old but ever acceptable opera of "Somnambula" afforded the opportunity for the second appearance of Signor BRIGNOLI. He appeared, in the first and second acts, to have recovered a good share of the confidence which failed him, for a time, on Monday night. He was finely supported by Miss KELLOGG, who appears to peculiar advantage in this opera. The second act went off with decided eclat, and BRIGNOLI and KELLOGG were called before the curtain. But, to the disappointment of the audience, BRIGNOLI somehow found himself unequal or unwilling to go on with the third act, and that most disagreeable of all opera incidents, an apology "from Indisposition," was the consequence. Signor LOTTI, on the shortest notice, assumed the unfinished story of Elvino, and went through the music most respectably.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SUMNER presented the usual number of petitions for the abolition of Slavery. Mr. POMEROY presented petitions from citizens of Kansas, asking for mail routes. Mr. RAMSAY ditto, from...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SUMNER presented the usual number of petitions for the abolition of Slavery. Mr. POMEROY presented petitions from citizens of Kansas, asking for mail routes. Mr. RAMSAY ditto, from citizens of Minnesota. Mr. SHERMAN presented a petition from citizens of Ohio, asking for the sale of mineral lands Mr. SPRAGUE presented the petition of of citizens of Rhode Island, asking that black soldiers be placed on same footing as white. Mr. MCDOUGALL introduced a bill to amend the act incorporating the Pacific Railroad Company. On motion of Mr. FESSENDEN, the Senate reconsidered its action on the Revenue bill, and the Chair was authorized to appoint a new Conference Committee. The bill to equalize the pay of soldiers was taken up, and an amendment adopted offered by Mr. SUMNER, giving to all soldiers enlisted under the act of 1861 the same pay and bounties. The Senate took no further action on the bill. The Chair was authorized to appoint a Committee of Conference on the disagreeing votes on the Lieutenant-General Bill. On motion of Mr. WILSON, the Military Committee were instructed to inquire into the expediency of extending the bounties to April next.

abstract: THE SANITARY FAIR. -- The attendance at the Sanitary Fair yesterday and last evening was large, but not as much so as it was on the previous day. The Academy was crowded, bat still, visitors were able to move about with some degree of comfort. The sales were brisk and a considerable amount was realized. The Knickerbocker Hall and the New-England Kitchen were well patronized, and in fact, overcrowded, but all who entered were accommodated. The fair thus far has been a great success, not only in regard to the cash receipts, but in relation to the attendance. Everybody wants to see the fair, and everybody goes.

abstract: The  Democratic State Convention, which met at Albany on Wednesday, was called for a specific object-the appointment of delegates to the National Convention at Chicago; and having performed that duty, it very wisely adjourned. No attempt was made to erect a...
lead_paragraph: -The Democratic State Convention, which met at Albany on Wednesday, was called for a specific object -- the appointment of delegates to the National Convention at Chicago; and having performed that duty, it very wisely adjourned. No attempt was made to erect a platform, nor did the convention make any formal expression of its opinions on the great questions at issue before the country. The everlasting contest between Mozart and Tammany from this City made its annual appearance, and was further diversified by the claim of the McKeon Democrats to be also recognized and admitted. On this occasion, as the controversy had no practical importance, each of the three factions was indulged -- the representation being equally divided between them. Tammany went through her usual performance of whining, protesting and withdrawing -- but nobody minded it a bit.

abstract: Congress, the Manifesto of
snippet: Congress, the Manifesto of
lead_paragraph: It will always, we are satisfied, be a matter of pride and satisfaction to the friends of the North that, in spite of the intensity of the feeling roused by the struggle in which it has been engaged for the last three years -- in spite, in short, of the fact that this struggle is a civil war, its writers and speakers have, except in very rare cases, refrained from the railing and vituperation on which the Southern leaders seem to rely largely both for exciting the sympathy of foreigners and keeping up the courage of their own people. In fact, there has been no characteristic of the contest so marked and so strange as the absence of vindictiveness on the part of the people of the Free States. Our offences against good taste have consisted rather in exaggerated estimates of our own strength, and undue depreciation of that of the enemy; or, to put it in plain English, in inordinate bragging, than in abuse or scolding. This calm or phlegm, whichever it may be called, has unquestionably been a source of military weakness; but it has, as unquestionably, been a proof of moral strength. If it has served to prolong the war, it will do for our reputation what the war alone could never have done.

abstract: On Wednesday, we published a transcript of the seventy-five bids given by forty-two bidders for the new $2,000,000 Bounty Fund Loan, and stated that the whole amount desired by these parties at a premium would be awarded at the premium rates offered; that this amount was "$1,891,800, leaving $108,200 to be awarded at par, at the option of the Comptroller"...
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday, we published a transcript of the seventy-five bids given by forty-two bidders for the new $2,000,000 Bounty Fund Loan, and stated that the whole amount desired by these parties at a premium would be awarded at the premium rates offered; that this amount was "$1,891,800, leaving $108,200 to be awarded at par, at the option of the Comptroller" It appears we were mistaken on these points. It has transpired that Comptroller BRENNAN has decided not to accept any of the bids below the premium rate of one per cent., and that he has made awards of the stock only in accordance with this decision. Upon refering to our list of bids, weare enabled to see that. under this ruling, the awards of stock give a total of $987,500, and aggregate $2,390,060 of premiums upon it. This certainly is handsome for the City; and. for the purpose of giving premium bidders another chance, the Comptroller has readvertised for bids for $1,000,000 of the stock, to be opened on March 7, at 2 O'clock, P.M. To show the awards inexact comparison with the rejected bids, we republish our list of the bids, with columns appended exhibiting complete details of the matter -- the lastcolumn of figures showing the amount of premiums on the accepted bids:

abstract: Dinner to at N. Y.
snippet: Dinner to at N. Y.
lead_paragraph: Some fifty residents of Colorado, temporarily in this City, gave a complimentary dinner on Wednesday evening at Delmonico's, in Fifth-avenue, to Ex-Gov. GILPIN, who is also here on business connected with that rich and growing Territory. The occasion was one of marked and peculiar interest. It was certainly a little remarkable that so many gentlemen, living in so remote a region, should happen to be in this City at the same time; but it is not at all singular that, being here, they should unite in paying a tribute of respect and grateful acknowledgment to one who has evinced so zealous and so enthusiastic an interest in the progress of their Territory as Gov. GILPIN, In response to a complimentary toast, the Governor made some interesting remarKs concerning the general prospects of Colorado, and the relations of the central portions of the continent to the welfare of the Union and tne grand future of the American people. He was followed in pertinent and eloquent remarks by several invited guests, as well as by a number of the gentlemen who had tendered him this compliment.

lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details-of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editoriais on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKELY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest. complled from sources many of whicn are otherwise inaoccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: FATAL. MALPRACTICE -- A NEW-YORK DRUGGIST HELD FOR CAUSING THE DEATH OF A WILLIAMSBURGH WOMAN. -- Coroner BARRETT, of Brooklyn, E.D., last evening concluded an investigation into the cause of death of Mrs. Leonora Kinddr, of No. 239 Second-street, Brooklyn, E.D. The facts as sworn to may be substantially set forth as follows: On Monday, the ???5th inst., Mrs. Kinder, and her sister, Josephine Maull, the latter living at No. 129 Cannon-street, N.Y., called by previous agreement on Benj. Martin, druggist, corner of Houston and Manhattan streets, N.Y., and the former there drank, by his advice, a quantity of the oil of tansy extract of cotton and gin; the druggist suggested to her that she better go to a person on Broadway whom he knew and where he had taken many persons situated as she was; she preferred the mixture and drank it. On leaving he desired her to call again if the desired result was not produced, when he would repeat the dose. Before reaching her home in Brooklyn, E.D., she was seized with vomiting fits, which continued until she died. This fatal termination occurred two hours after drinking the medicine. The druggist was immediately arrested, and the inquest yesterday resulted in his being held to await the action of the Grand Jury. The testimony of all the physicians agreed as to the effect of the tansy, and that a very large dose must have been taken. Eight drops were discovered by a chemical analysis to the contents of the stomach and intestines, which was considered to be an overdose. An affidavit from Mrs. Langhorn, of Seventh-street, New-York, now suffering from a similar dose administered by the same druggist, was read, and her physician was sworn. The two cases were every way similar. The sister of the deceased testified that Martin tried to prevail on her to screen him by telling a different story, and said his act was a State Prison offence. Martin is of Massachusetts birth, 46 years of age. The deceased was the wife of a Lieutenant in the One Hundred and Thirty-third New-York Volunteers, and 23 years old. Coroner BARRETT has thoroughly investigated the case.

abstract: Circular; The Cabinet and Sec. Chase
snippet: Circular; The Cabinet and Sec. Chase
lead_paragraph: Our Democratic brethren of the Copperhead persuasion are becoming excessively impatient for the expected rupture in the Cabinet. Their eagerness is a little unseemly. If their disinterested devotion to the welfare of the Administration were less notorious than it is, they would almost incur the suspicion of having "private ends" of their own to serve, like GOLDSMITH's dog, in this Cabinet smash-up which they have been announcing for the past month as certain to occur immediately.

In the British House of Lords, Earl DERBY had attacked the policy of the Government in reference to the rebel steamer Alabama and the Laird rams, that theseizure of the latter had been made under menaces of the United States Government, and moved that the papers in the case be produced. Earl RUSSEL, replied, defending the course of the Government, and declining to produce the papers pending legal inquiries. abstract: National Freedmen's Relief Association, Anniversary
snippet: National Freedmen's Relief Association, Anniversary
lead_paragraph: There was a large attendance last evening at the Cooper Institute on the occasion of the celebration of the anniversary of the National Freedmen's Relief Association. WILLIAM CULLEN BRYANT presided. After an eloquent prayer by Rev. Mr. CHIDLAW, the Chairman briefly stated the object of the meeting and Introduced WILLIAM ALLEN BUTLER, who made an excellent speech. He was followed by Rev. HENRY WARD BEEOHER, who discoursed in his inimitable way, keeping the audience in the best of humor by his eloquence. When be had concluded a collection was taken up for benefit of the society, after which a smart, bright-eyed, light-haired little fellow, eight years of age was, intrnduced to the audience, and, in a neat little speech, gave them his history, saying that his father had been a lawyer In Western Virginia, but that he had sold him and his mother, and that they had been again sold, his mother for $500 and he for $200, and sent into Loalsiana. He gave a good description of the happiness felt by the negroes when they heard FARRAGUT's guns, and of their love for Gens. BUTLER and BANKS, who had freed them, established scnools for them, and given them such chances for advancement. A little daughter of the rebel Gen. HUGER, who was also present, recited a little poem in a very modest manner, which completely won for her the affections of all the ladies present. There was, also, a little daughter of a rebel officer who is supposed to have been killed on the Merrimac, but she was too young to speak in public. The children are perfectly white and do not bear the slightest evidences of negro blood; still they were sold by their fathers and remained slaves until freed by our army.

abstract: and the Lieut.-Generalship
snippet: and the Lieut.-Generalship
lead_paragraph: The Senate deserves public thanks for its decisive vote, striking out Gen. GRANT's name from the joint resolution reviving the grade of Lieutenant-General. The attempt of the House to prescribe, as it virtually did, that one particular man, and no other, should receive that rank, was unconstitutional, unseemly, unsafe. But for so many other odd performances of the House, it would have excited astonishment.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday, and concurred in the resolution authorizing the Comptroller to lease at auction all ferry franchises, and all wharves, piers and slips and other improved Corporation property not now leased or which is not yielding revenue to the City. The...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday, and concurred in the resolution authorizing the Comptroller to lease at auction all ferry franchises, and all wharves, piers and slips and other improved Corporation property not now leased or which is not yielding revenue to the City. The "other improved property" is understood to mean vacant engine and school houses, &c. The Mayor sent in his veto on the resolution relative to procuring the customary badges for the members of the Common Council. His main objection is that gold is too high at present to allow of the expenditure contemplated. A resolution by Mr. GROSS, to give the use of the Chamber of the Board to the Superior Court, Special Term, without a jury -- Justice MONCRIEF presiding -- for the month of March, led to some sportive remarks, and was finally tabled by 10 to 8. This opposition is attributable to the fact that locks of desk drawers were broken and the stationery of several of the members was stolen while this Court used the Chamber during a short period last year. The Board adjourned to 1 o'clock P.M. next Monday.

abstract: Chesapeake Pirates, Case of at Halifax
snippet: Chesapeake Pirates, Case of at Halifax
lead_paragraph: The result of the criminal proceedings in the case of the Chesapeake at Halifax, is very gratifying. It seems now quite probable that the villains who planned and executed that crime, will not be allowed to escape punishment. We see that the Commissioner puts his decision upon the very ground which we suggested as the conclusive one in the case, viz.: that even if there was a rebel commission authorizing the man named PARKER to undertake a hostile enterprise, it did not allow him to authorize others, and as others had planned the affair and executed it, only bringing in PARKER with his commission after the crime was committed, there was no protection in his commission for them.

abstract: The closing lecture by Prof. DOREMUS, drew one of the largest and most intelligent audiences ever gathered inside of the Cooper Institute. His opening theme was the grand discoveries of chemistry made within the last century; the chiefest of these was the insulation, by PRIESTLEY and SCHEELE, of oxygen or vital air, which forms more than one-half of our globe.
lead_paragraph: The closing lecture by Prof. DOREMUS, drew one of the largest and most intelligent audiences ever gathered inside of the Cooper Institute. His opening theme was the grand discoveries of chemistry made within the last century; the chiefest of these was the insulation, by PRIESTLEY and SCHEELE, of oxygen or vital air, which forms more than one-half of our globe. This capital discovery was made the same year which gave to our Republic. Then the cordposite nature of water, by CAVLNDISH, in 1781; the brilliant revelations. by Sir HUMPHREY DAVY, through the aid of the galvanic battery, in 1807, of the metalic bases of the earths. Still more recently, the many revelations in organic chemistry, which have given us such insight into the mysteries of vegetable and animal life.

abstract: Navy; Report of Select Committee on; Feb. 17
snippet: Navy; Report of Select Committee on; Feb. 17
lead_paragraph: The shortcomings of the Navy Department have lately occupied the attention of the Confedererates. In the Richmond Enquirer we find a report of the "Joint Select Congressional Committee" appointed to examine into the operations of the department. The document states that the Committee confined their to the domestic operations of the department, because the President advised them that it would not be for the public good to examine into the foreign operations. They received some confidential information on this point, however, from a "gentleman in charge of the foreign contracts." The report states that "the committee have inquired into everything relating to the materials and the operations of the navy within the Confederate States; the means and resources for building a navy; the efforta to purchase for build vessels and to obtain ordnance and ordnance stores; the number and kind of vessels purchased or built; of whom purchased or by whom built; the contracts for them and how complied with; the contracts for war vessels now pending; the vessels owened by tine Government when the Navy Department was organized, and the number end kind now owned by it; the naval defences of the Missis???ippi River, and especially of New-Orleans, of the Cumberland, Tennessee and James Rivers, and of the City of Norfolk; the circumstances connected with the destruction of the Virginia, the Louisinne, the Mississippi, the Arkansas and other gunboats: the causes of our naval disasters, and of the failure of our navy to meet the expectations.":

abstract: The steamship Illinois, from Aspinwall Feb. 17, arrived at this port yesterday morning. There had been but one arrival from the west coast of South America since the last steamer's departure. The report that the French Minister had broken off friendly relations with Ecuador is not correct.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Illinois, from Aspinwall Feb. 17, arrived at this port yesterday morning. There had been but one arrival from the west coast of South America since the last steamer's departure. The report that the French Minister had broken off friendly relations with Ecuador is not correct. Trouble still continues in the interior of this country, and it was feared the revolution is far from over yet. The French frigate Pallas, Admiral BONET, sailed for Acapulco on the 11th inst., to enforce the blockade of the Mexican coast in the Pacific. No vessel will be allowed to enter any of the ports that have not declared In favor of the French except the Pacific Mail Company's steamers, which have the privilege to take fuel, water and supplies in Acapulco, but can land or receive no cargo. The other line of steamers will not be allowed even that privilege.

abstract: It was currently reported on 'Change yesterday afternoon that in a few days one of the fastest screw steamers afloat would leave a British port on a cruise after the Alabama, This new steamer has been purchased, and is being fitted out, at the sole expense of two first-class English houses -- one in London, and the other in this town -- both of whom have suffered heavily in consequence of the depredadations of the famous Confederate cruiser. The new vessel, it is expected, will steam three or four knots faster than the Alabama ever could or will do, besides being much stronger, and when armed (carrying guns of such a calibre and construction) the chances of the Alabama being able to cope with her will be hopeless. She will be commanded by a man who has already gained much notorlety in connection with ocean navigation, and in whom Capt. SRAMMES will find a toe "worthy of his steel. The mission of this new steamer, while it will be chiefly to hunt and catch the Alabama, will also be directed against the other Confederate cruisers -- Georgia, Florida, Rappahannock (should the latter get to sea), ??? d Tvscaloosa. Already two barques have left England with coals for the "new comer," Which will be discharged at one or two ports which this vessel will make her rendezvous. This steamer, of course, will act in conjunction with the Federal cruisers now on the look-out for the Alabama. We may here repeat that the action on the part of British merchants is prompted by heavy combined and personal losses in the destruction of neutral goods in American bottoms, and also by the fact that bitherto all the efforts or the Federal navy to capture the Alabama have been fruitless.

abstract: JOHN C. HORNE was arrested yesterday on a complaint made by Mr. B.F. BUTLER, of the banking house of Messrs. PHELPS, MAITLAND  Co., Nos. 45 and 47 Exchange-place. The charge is one of forgery. Mr. HORNE, it seems, claims to be a merchant in Havana.
lead_paragraph: JOHN C. HORNE was arrested yesterday on a complaint made by Mr. B.F. BUTLER, of the banking house of Messrs. PHELPS, MAITLAND & CO., Nos. 45 and 47 Exchange-place. The charge is one of forgery. Mr. HORNE, it seems, claims to be a merchant in Havana. He is charged with having forged indorsements on bills for exchange for the sum of $2,567 23, drawn by Messrs. DURANTY & CO., of Havana, indorsed by ADOLPH MARLITIGO and CARLOS DE MELINI CELI.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SUMNER introduced a bill to exclude disloyal persons from the public lands of the United States. Mr. HALE reported a bill to equalize the grade of line officers of the navy. Mr. WILSON introduced a bill providing that future enlistments in the regular army ...
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SUMNER introduced a bill to exclude disloyal persons from the public lands of the United States. Mr. HALE reported a bill to equalize the grade of line officers of the navy. Mr. WILSON introduced a bill providing that future enlistments in the regular army May be for three of five years, and that soldiers who enlisted in the Regular Army prior to July 22, 1861, may until the 1st of May, next with the existing bounties. Mr. COLLAMER, of Vermont. called up removes the color disqualification for mail carriers; together with the amendment providing that in Courts of the United States there shall be no exclusion on account of color. The bill was discussed at length, without concluding action. The Senate agreed to the report of the Committee of Conference on the Lieutenant. General Bill, and after a long session adjourned.

abstract: Russell, Earl, Reply to Earl Derby on Seizure of Birkenhead Rams
snippet: Russell, Earl, Reply to Earl Derby on Seizure of Birkenhead Rams
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords on Feb. 11 the Earl of Derby, in asking Lord RUSSELL to produce the correspondence between Her Majesty's Government and the United States, in reference to the Alabama and other vessels built in this country, from which the United States apprehended injury, said the noble Lord had refused to lay on the table the correspondence with regard to the rams built in the Mersey, on the ground that they were now under judicial consideration. He understood that the rams were detained by an order of Government in September, and that they were seized in October. From that time until Saturday last no steps were taken to Obtain a judicial decision as the legality of the seizure. On Friday last an information was issued which might have been filed In October or November, and in that way the question might have been brought to an early issue. Since that information was filed he was informed that Messrs. LAIRD had received an intimation that it was now necessary to send out a commission, four months after seizure, for the purpose of collecting evidence. He thought the production of the correspondence between this country and the United States, on the subject of these seizures, could have no sort of bearing upon the case about to be brought before the courts, that case being simply whether Messrs. LAIRD had or had not, in constructing these vessels, infringed the municipal laws of England. He reminded Lord RUSSELL that the papers he objected to produce had already been made public in America and laid before Congress. What he wanted to see now was the English as well as the American version. The noble Earl (DERBY) had copies extracted from the correspondence laid before Congress, and said the impression produced was that the Government had been compelled by the menaces and pressure placed upon them by the United States to make concessions, which they had refused to make in the first instance, in addition to the correspondence in reference to the Alabama and the steam rams. He wished also to have a copy laid before Parliament of any correspondence that may have taken place in reference to acts of violation committed by American cruisers upon English vessels. Alluding to the threat of the American Government, in a dispatch to Mr. ADAMS, to follow such vessels as the Alabama and the Florida in British waters, and seize them even If under the protection of the British flag, he said the dispatch, although not officially communicated to Her Majesty's Government, had nevertheless been laid before Congress, and it was expedient that we should come to a thorough understanding with the American Government on the subject.
