abstract: The Supervisors' Volunteering Committee paid the bounty of $300 to no less than 403 men Wedneday, by far the largest' day's work yet, swallowing up within a traction of $121,000 ol greenbacks. It was a busy day at the rooms of the committee thronged from morning till nignt, and giving the officials about as much as they could well attend to. With plenty of money on hand, let all give every encouragement possible by word and act, and our quota will be soon as far above par as the County volunteering loan is.

abstract: Very sad news comes to us from the Department of the South. The steamship Fullon at  rived last evening, bringing the intelligence of a desperate battle on the 20th inst. near Sanderson, Fla., between Gen. SEYMOUR'S forces and a superior body of rebels.
lead_paragraph: Very sad news comes to us from the Department of the South. The steamship Fullon at rived last evening, bringing the intelligence of a desperate battle on the 20th inst. near Sanderson, Fla., between Gen. SEYMOUR's forces and a superior body of rebels. After fighting three hours, Gen. SEYMOUR was compelled to retire, although we are told that he brought off safely the bulk of the wounded. Our losses were certainly heavy, as 240 of the wounded had arrived at Hilton Head; but the full details of the reverse has not reached ???s, as Gen. GILLMORE, just previous to the sailing of the Fulton, seized the newspaper and other correspondence, including the lists of killed and wounded.

abstract: Wednesday evening, at Jefferson Market Drill Rooms, the City authorities gave a grand banquet to the Second Regiment Fire Zouaves. The room was very neatly dressed, and the brilliant uniforms of many distinguished officers, and the handsome uniforms of the Zouaves, with the firemen's red collar turned over outside the coat, gave the room a splendid appearance. The tables were loaded with subtantials and delicacies; and the Zouaves, who, on many a hard fought field have proved their abilitv to attack and vanquish an enemy, last evening fully proved their ability to attack and enjoy a good dinner. In the absence of Mayor GUNTHER, Alderman HARDY presided. He welcomed the Zouaves home, paid a just tribute to their bravery in battle, and assured them they were very far from being forgotten by the City authorities. He then read a letter from Maj.-Gen. McCLELLAN, expressing his regret that prior engagements rendered it impossible for him to attend, which was received with loud cheers. Col. BREWSTER, in response to the toast of the "Seventy-third Regiment," gave a short history of the regiment's career from its commencement. In response to the toast of "The Fire Commissioners." HENRY WILSON, ESQ. made a most excellent speech. He praised in glowing terms,the valor of the regiment, and assured them that the Fire Commissioners always had and always would be their steadfast friends. Hon. F.A. CONKLIN, Col. THOMAS HOLT, of the Fifth Excelsior, and Lieut.-Col. M. BURNS, of the Seventy-third [Regiment, also made short and pertinent speeches, which were well received. Capt. MANNING, also of the Zouaves, then sang an excellent song, the entire regiment joining in the chorus, and his allusions to the gallant conduct of Gen. SICKLES, Col. GRAHAM, and "Mickey BURNS and his gray horse," elicited great applause. Gen. SPINOLA, Capt. SMITH, Capt. JACK DOWNEY, and many others, also spoke to the eminent satisfaction of the brave veterans, and at a late hour the festivities ended.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. There was an exceedingly good house last evening, attracted by that always interesting event, a debut. The claiment for operatic honors waa a young lady named HARRIS, and the opera wad necessarily "Lucia," a work wherein (it is said) failure is impossible.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- There was an exceedingly good house last evening, attracted by that always interesting event, a debut. The claiment for operatic honors waa a young lady named HARRIS, and the opera wad necessarily "Lucia," a work wherein (it is said) failure is impossible. There were rumors of Miss HARRIS' debut some months back, but wi arc persuaded thai she has followed good counsel In post-poniog The ordeal until the present time. Indeed, in view of the lady's extreme youth.it would have'been better had it been deferred even longer. The evenl however has turned out satisfactorily, and Miss HARRIS, the most youthful of our operatic singers, oida fair to become one of the most popular. Her reception last night was in the highest degree flattering. All that the generosity of an unusully gallant audience could bestow on the fair debutant was bestowed upon her long before she had done justice to herself. This excesisve applause, indiscreet la Itself, had at least the good effect ot, imparting a feeling of confidence to the little singer, and she warbled with increased spirit and affect as the opera proceeded.

abstract: Neutrality Laws and Rebel Pirates
snippet: Neutrality Laws and Rebel Pirates
lead_paragraph: -- We copy from an English paper a statement that some British merchants are fitting out two fast steamers to pursue and, if possible, destroy the Alabama and Oreto. Whether the statement is true we have no means of knowing. It would not be at all strange if British merchants, whose vessels have been seized and burned by these roving corsairs, should feel inclined to aid in arresting their career; and we shall be very curious to see what ground the British Government will take upon the subject. It will probably claim that they belong to the regular navy of a Power which it has recognized as a belligerent, and that the English neutrality laws will be violated by the fitting out of vessels to attack them. But a good many side questions will arise in the discussion, which will not leave it free from embarrassment.

abstract: Parker, Theodore, Life of, by John Weiss
snippet: Parker, Theodore, Life of, by John Weiss
lead_paragraph: As time draws on, and the characteristics of a State and people become daily more and more assured to America and its inhabitants, the material wealth that accompanies these developments of empire is far from being the sole endowment they bring with them. We are daily becoming mentally richer, also, the stock of native ideas fructifies, and, above all, is constantly increasing that inalienable heritage of coming generations, the memories of our good and great men -- the home crop of heroes springing from the soil, true to its instincts and sympathies, sharers of our conflicts and leaders of our victories. As "star after star decays" on earth, and the National pantheon enlarges its boundaries to admit those who become immortal, the voice of the true sage proves, perhaps, even more potent than when it was heard in life, for counsel, rebuke or warning, in seasons of difficulty and danger. The smoke and stir of turmoil no longer obscure theirtrue proportions; the asperities of life are softened, and a wider audience is prepared to listen to utterances that formerly provoked to anger, or were received with indifference. Conspicuous among those "standard-bearers of humanity" recently departed, is the remarkable man commemorated in these goodly volumes. THEODORE PARKER -- a name long associated with obloquy by his enemies, and hesitatingly championed even by his friends, who could not keep up with the speed of his intellectual processes -- is here portrayed at full length. He stands before us in all his strength and weakness, and our literature is enriched by the life-like resemblance of one whom all acknowledge as a true man, and posterity will probably account a great one.

abstract: NORTH WOODS WALTON CLUB. On Tuesday evening last, at the Astor House, this club celebrated their anniversary by a grand annual festival and dinner. A number of invited guests were present. Previous to the dinner a meeting was held, at which the following officers were elected for the ensuing year:
lead_paragraph: NORTH WOODS WALTON CLUB. -- On Tuesday evening last, at the Astor House, this club celebrated their anniversary by a grand annual festival and dinner. A number of invited guests were present. Previous to the dinner a meeting was held, at which the following officers were elected for the ensuing year: President, E.W. DODGE; Vice-Presidents, W.B. TAYLOR and DAVID BANKS; Secretary and Treasurer, C.M. SCOFIELD; Corresponding Secretary, W.B. LOOMIS; Marshal, R.U. OWENS; and Commissary, S.M. FOSTER. The labels were loaded with all the substantials and delicacies of the season, and surrounded by one of the most merry and jolly parties Imaginable. President E.W. DODGE made the opening speech, and welcomed the guests in a manner so sincere and hearty that they all felt as much at home as if they were old members of the club. Messers. CHARLES S. SPENCER, RICHARD BUSTEED and many other gentlemen spoke, and added to the interest of the evening. The old patriot soldier, BURNS, the only man who represented the Pennsylvania militia at Gettysburgh, was present, and I received much-attention. The glee club, composed of Messrs. A. SPENCER, G.W. ABBEY, JAS MILLER, J.T. KENT and W. B, TAYLOR, all of Utica, favored the company with some excellent singing; it is probably the best amateur glee club in the State. As set forth in the President's speech, the North Woods Walton Club was organized in 1857. Among its members are some of the most prominent men of the State, and in all sections of the State can its adherents be found. Its cardinal creed is that every man should once a year break away from the cares of business, ??? to the wilds, the lakes, the forests, and enjoy the sports found thereat and therein. So annually the members seek the wilderness of the north woods, build their huts, rely on their guns and their trout tackle for their sport and subsistence; on the beauties of nature and their own good companionship and jollity for the rest of what constitutes their annual enjoyment.

HANCOCK hopes soon to have his famous corps fully recruited, and soon again to lead them on to victory and glory.

abstract: We have said nothing of the recent arrest of Gen. (now Colonel) TOOMBS, and his trial, now progressing before a court-martial in this city, for the reason that we regarded it simply a case of military discipline in which the public would feel no particular interest.
lead_paragraph: We have said nothing of the recent arrest of Gen. (now Colonel) TOOMBS, and his trial, now progressing before a court-martial in this city, for the reason that we regarded it simply a case of military discipline in which the public would feel no particular interest. But it seems the event has got abroad, the story, gathering most marvelously as it traveled, is done up at length in the Richmond papers with an almost endless variety of minutiae and speculation, not one of which la correct. it is, therefore, due to Gen. TOOM???S and to truth that the facts should be stated as they are.

abstract: Congress; Tax Bill, Synopsis of
snippet: Congress; Tax Bill, Synopsis of
lead_paragraph: Cut off, as we are, from Tennessee and Kentucky, the question of meat supplies for our armies, from the area within our control, is one of grave consideration. According to census reports, there is no just ground for the impression, long prevalent with us, that the South was dependent upon the North for a large portion of the meat we consumed. We actually reared and slaughtered more animals, in proportion to population, than the North, and it is simply owing to the fact of our almost wasteful use of meat, in which they economized, that we became annual purchasers of this article to so great an extent. Thrown upon our own resources, div???ing our agriculture from the production of our great commercial staples to that of breadstuffs, and. along with it, to raising animals, hogs especially, since the war began, in section8 undisturbed by the march of armies, or not affected by epidemics among our stock, the supplies of meat are far more bountiful than ever known before. It but remains for our patriotic planters to respond to the call of Government for this article, which, under the modifications of the schedule and impressment prices, as well as improvement of currency by the of recent enactments of Congress, allowing more just as well as valuable compensation, we feel fully assured they will at once and cheerfully do.

abstract: THE CAMPAIGN TOWARD  ATLANTA. Gen. GRANT appears to have concluded that the great diversion which SHERMAN'S army was ordered to make in his favor by moving into the heart of Mississippi and Alabama, and calling off from his front a portion of JOHNSTON'S force, has had time to have its full effect and we now find him advancing THOMAS' army on the line toward Atlanta.
lead_paragraph: -- THE CAMPAIGN TOWARD ATLANTA. -- Gen. GRANT appears to have concluded that the great diversion which SHERMAN's army was ordered to make in his favor by moving into the heart of Mississippi and Alabama, and calling off from his front a portion of JOHNSTON'S force, has had time to have its full effect and we now find him advancing THOMAS' army on the line toward Atlanta. At latest advices a brilliantly successful advance had brought THOMAS' force to within three miles of Daiton, where it was expected JOHNSTON would attempt to make a stand. Dalton is forty miles south of Chattanooga, with which place it is connected by a double line of rail road. Thence he has a direct line of advance first to Rome and secondly to Atlanta. At the latter place we tap the secondary line of rebel communications, and there is not a doubt that it is the grand objective of Gen. GRANT'S present campaign; but whether he will take it by gradual approaches, or make one Of his "blunderingly audacious" marches upon lt,remains to be seen. The magnificent strategy Which has marked GRANT's initiative has already had the effect to disconcert all the rebel plans, divide their forces and throw them into utter confusion. He is now moving on a line of advance, and with aims that lend the very highest interest and importance to every step he takes. He has already taught the nation not to be surprised at anything he may do.

abstract: Freedmens' Relief Meeting, The
snippet: Freedmens' Relief Meeting, The
lead_paragraph: The National Freedmen's Relief Society, is an association in which every man of humane feelings, or of common prudence in political affairs, must have an interest. To care for the material wants and organize the labor of millions of human beings, whose fate is intrusted to the honor of the country, is the first of duties to every right-minded citizen. It was accordingly quite natural that the second annual meeting of this Society on Thursday evening last should be attended by a large and most intelligent audience. But it was not quite natural and suitable that almost from the beginning to the end of the meeting, nothing whatever clear and practical was laid before the audience as to the objects arrived at or the work accomplished by this association.

abstract: Analysis of his Report
snippet: Analysis of his Report
lead_paragraph: There are those who remember that, at the parting reception given by Gen. MCCLELLAN to his friends and following, at headquarters, at Warrenton, on the November day of 1862, when he was relieved from the command of the Army of the Potomac, the General in reply to the suggestions of members of his staff that he would be back in command in the course of a fortnight, used the following language: "If I never return to the Army of the Potomac, may I live to write its history. It is," added he, "a task to which I shall devote myself."

abstract: Capt. TYLER, of the Royal Engineers, in a lecture before the United Service Institution, Jan. 18, delighted his hearers by assuring them that" the turrets of the monitors and their port-stoppers were effective principally in preventing the guns from being worked." He...
lead_paragraph: Capt. TYLER, of the Royal Engineers, in a lecture before the United Service Institution, Jan. 18, delighted his hearers by assuring them that" the turrets of the monitors and their port-stoppers were effective principally in preventing the guns from being worked." He further stated that the report of secretary WELLES "confirmed the worst estimate that we (the English) had formed of them." The unprejudiced lecturer further told his hearers that the only Federal vessel that had ventured within 700 yards of Fort Sumter, the Keokuk, had to be withdrawn in a sinking condition, and afterward sunk. The 11-inch guns proved too much for the 11-inch turrets of the Monitors," added the lecturer, leaving his hearers to infer that the Keokuk was a monitor whose turret and hull had been riddled by Confederate balls. Our readers will bear in mind that this statement was made on the 18th of January, 1864, on an occasion of more than ordinary gravity, the subject under consideration being the great national question of harbor defence and the fortifications at Spithead. Capt. TYLER produced charts showing that there were three distinct channels, varying from 1,000 to 3,000 yards in width, open to an enemy's vessels, and which channels he said could not be obstructed, yet, as the Keokuk had been sunk at a distance of 700 yards, these channels could not be entered by our iron-clads.

abstract: --The obituary of the last month contains the names of two English authoresses of eminence, but as distinct in their walks of literature as in their fate--one dying prematurely in youth, the other surviving to extreme age. Miss PROCTER, the "golden tressed Adelaide" of her father's song, is best known...
lead_paragraph: -- The obituary of the last month contains the names of two English authoresses of eminence, but as distinct in their walks of literature as in their fate -- one dying prematurely in youth, the other surviving to extreme age. Miss PROCTER, the "golden tressed Adelaide" of her father's song, is best known by the two series of "Legends and Lyrics," long familiar to all lovers of poetry. Though the daughter of a poet, ("Barry Cornwall.") her verse is no echo of another's lyre -- but the genuine expression, always tender and graceful, of a mind at once elegant and original. Latterly, her writings have assumed a more ascetic character, possibly from the influence of the strong religious feeling which made her a convert to the Roman Catholic Church. The long and wasting illness from which she suffered was probably aggravated by her zeal in works of mercy and beneficence, exerted beyond the measure of her always delicate health.

abstract: Grant's Pass is an entrance to Mobile Bay from Grand Bay, and opens into the former above Fort Gaines. It is sufficiently deep for navigation, and was formerly used by the steamers plying between New-Orleans and Mobile. It is not commanded by the forts which guard the usual entrance to the bay, but...
lead_paragraph: Grant's Pass is an entrance to Mobile Bay from Grand Bay, and opens into the former above Fort Gaines. It is sufficiently deep for navigation, and was formerly used by the steamers plying between New-Orleans and Mobile. It is not commanded by the forts which guard the usual entrance to the bay, but has been fortified and protected, sand batteries having been erected on either side of the little island, upon which the keeper of the lighthouse used to live. In these batteries are mounted several 32-pounders. It was with these batteries that the engagement of the 16th doubtless took place. If Grant's Pass can be taken, it will be seen that Mobile would be at the mercy of our ships without the preliminary necessity of reducing Forts Morgan and Gaines.

abstract: JAMES T. FOX, of Company C, Sixth Ohio, and CHAS. SCHUSTER, of Company H, of the same regiment -- both of this city -- reached here yesterday morning, having escaped from Prison No. 5, Danville, Virginia. They made their escape by means of a tunnel seventy-five feet in length, which was dug by the prisoners in five days and nights. The exodus was effected on the night of the 28th of January, about seventy of the nine hundred prisoners in the building managing to reach fresh air before the sentry discovered them. The fortunate ones -- mostly Ohio and Illinois men -- then divided themselves into small squads and commenced their toilsome and dangerous flight in the direction of our lines. The men mentioned, in company with JOHN MILLENBAUGH, of the Thirtieth Indiana, reached our lines at Suffolk on the 13th instant, after experiencing all the privations and miseries incident to such a trip. There are six prison houses at Danville containing about 5,000 Union prisoners, the majority of whom were taken at Chickamauga. The men who reached this city are stopping at the corner of Sycamore and Pearle streets, having thirty days leave of absence from their regiment. They have not, yet been able to ascertain anything relative to the fate of the others who escaped at the same time. The prisoners at Danville are subjected to all the miseries of their fellow-soldiers in prisons elsewhere. Their food consisted at no time of more than two ounces of fresh beef, and eight ounces of corn-bread. The small-pox is raging among the prisoners, some five hundred having already died of that and other diseases. -- Cincinnati Commercial, 26th.

abstract: A SHREWN ROGUE.--A young man, 17 years of age, named CEAUDE HAMILTON alias HENRY DAVIS, was arraigned yesterday afternoon before Justice DOWLING, at the Tombs' Police Court, on the charge of grand larceny. DAVIS is a native of Bath, England. He has been residing in Quebec, Canada, for some time past, and about a week since came to this City,...
lead_paragraph: A SHREWD ROGUE. -- A young man, 17 years of age, named CEAUDE HAMILTON alias HENRY DAVIS, was arraigned yesterday afternoon before Justice DOWLING, at the Tombs' Police Court, on the charge of grand larceny. DAVIS is a native of Bath, England. He has been residing in Quebec, Canada, for some time past, and about a week since came to this City, and immediately engaged himself to Mrs. MARY MCLEISH, of No. 110 Grand-street, as waiter. On Friday Mrs. MCLEISH gave DAVIS a wallet containing $500, with instructions to convey the same to Mr. MCLEISH in another part of the building. Instead of doing as required, DAVIS ran away with the money. The Detective Police and other officers were at once notified, but the thief could no be found until yesterday afternoon, when Officer STANDISH, of the Twenty-sixth Precinct, caught him at the British Steamship office, as he was in the act of purchasing tickets for Liverpool. On searching his person all the stolen money was found except what he had expended in purchasing a suit of clothes. When taken before Justice DOWLING and confronted by Mr. and Mrs. MCLEISH, he denied having ever been in their employ. Mrs. MCLEISH was confident he was the right man, and yet she said there was something about his appearance very different from what it was previously. His hair, she said, was sandy when he was in her employ -- now it was black. The man was on the point of being discharged for lack of identification, when Justice DOWLING, determined to probe the subject to the bottom, suddenly caught hold of the prisoner's hair. Then the mystery was explained. The accused for the purpose of disguising himself had put large quantities of lampblack-grease and other compounds on his hair. He was fully committed for trial.

lead_paragraph: The ship Dreadnaught, Capt. ROCKWELL -- late LYTTLE, deceased -- arrived on Friday night from Liverpool via Fayal, with 214 passengers, among whom four deaths have occurred. She has had heavy gales the entire passage, losing rudder, spars, sails, &c., &c. Feb. 14, lat. 40°, 12′, lon. 60° 35′, exchanged signals with ship Rhine, bound east. She brings as passenger CHARLES GEORGE COLLEVILLE, Esq., of New-York.

abstract: Proclamation for Troops; Various Anti-Davis Meetings; Johnson's Island, Rebel Senator Brown's Testimony to Good Treatment of Rebels at
snippet: Proclamation for Troops; Various Anti-Davis Meetings; Johnson's Island, Rebel Senator Brown's Testimony to Good Treatment of Rebels at
lead_paragraph: A.G. BROWN, Confederate Senator from Misissippi, has written a letter to the Enquirer of the 13th, in reply to a communcation that appeared, charging the Federal Government with maltreating the rebel prisoners on Johnson's Island. Mr. BROWN says he has a friend there who corresponds with him regularly, and says his imprisonment was as mild as he could expect, and that he was in want of nothing but liberty. With regard to fuel, Mr. BROWN says his correspondent tells him the prisoners have a sufficiency, and (says Mr. BROWN) "on the 12th he gives a bill of prison fare, and I undertake to say that ??? the families in Richmond do not fare so well." Again the correspondent says: "My life here would be very endurable were I not a prisoner." Mr. BROWN says he does not know why this officer should be treated any better than others, and "besides, in speaking of the treatment of the prisoners, he constantly uses the word we." Mr. BROWN states his reasons for making this statement thus: "First I would do justica to an enemy; next, I would not exasperate that enemy by publishing exaggerated if not false aacounts of his cruel treatment of our prisonerst and thus induce him to change mild and even kind treatment, into hursh, if not cruel treatment; and, lastly, these accounts will meet the eye of many persons in our country who have friends on Johnson's Island, and, if uncorrected, they cannot fail to inflict unnecessary pain upon such persons. With a change of commanders there may come a change of treatment; but I am perfectly satisfied that, up to the 20th of last month, the prisoners on Johnson's Island were treated as well as their friends in the Confederacy could reasonably expect."

abstract: 11 o'clock, Capt. ALLAN RAMSAY, of the United States Marino Corps, son of Commodore WILLIAM RAMSAY, United States Navy, and nephew of Gen. GEORGE. RAMSAY, Chief of Ordnance, died at the headquarters of the Marine Corps of typhoid fever, having passed through a very severe attack of small-pox. Capt. RAMSAY, though a young man, being only 26 years of age, was one of the most distinguished in his corps. He was appointed a Lieutenant in the corps in 1857, since which time he has been actively employed, mostly at sea. He was on the famous sloop-of-war Richmond during all her fights on the Mississippi, and fought his guard with such undaunted bravery and success as to receive frequent and most flattering and official mention. During the present rebellion he has been in fifteen engagements, mostly hard-fought ones. His funeral will take place this afternoon, at 2 o'clock, from the Marine Barracks. -- Washington Chronicle, Feb. 16.

abstract: THE ALLEGED POISONNING CASE.--A charge was some time since made against DAVID MUNGAR, alleging that he had caused the death of a young girl named AMARYLLIS L.D. SERLES, by poison. The accured was arrested, and an investigation was made by Coroner NORRIS, but there was no evidence whatever to show that he was guilty of such an offence.
lead_paragraph: THE ALLEGED POISONNING CASE. -- A charge was some time since made against DAVID MUNGAR, alleging that he had caused the death of a young girl named AMARYLLIS L.D. SERLES, by poison. The accured was arrested, and an investigation was made by Coroner NORRIS, but there was no evidence whatever to show that he was guilty of such an offence. The Jury, however, brought in the following verdict: "We find that the direct cause of the death of AMARYLLIS L.D. SEARLES was pulmonary consumption; but we find that her death was hastened by the ill-usage of DAVID MUNGAR, and we recommend that he be held to await the action of the Grand Jury." In accordance with this recommendation, the accused was held to answer. He is 44 years of age, and a painter by occupation.

abstract: MUSICAL--Mr. SPENCER B. DRIGGS, whose ingenious inventions and bold theories in connection with the piano-forte have resulted in many important improvements to that instrument, has recently complated a grand piano-forte which, by its power, quality and duration of tone, deserves to rank as an advance...
lead_paragraph: MUSICAL. -- Mr. SPENCER B. DRIGGS, whose ingenious inventions and bold theories in connection with the piano-forte have resulted in many important improvements to that instrument, has recently complated a grand piano-forte which, by its power, quality and duration of tone, deserves to rank as an advance on anything yet accomplished. It may be seen at No. 744 Broadway, and is well worth a visit from parties interested in this truly domestic orchestra; this real condenser of polyphony; this solitary muse of the parlor -- the piano-forte. The day is not far distant when America will supply Europe with pianos -- the day already being past when Europe could supply America. The writing on the wall was seen distinctly in 1862, when an American house (STEINWAY & SONS) bore off the prize at the great London International Exhibition. It was curious then to notice how timidly the great bulk of makers clung to the oldest devices of their craft, and how positively those who had only stepped a little forward found themselves in advance of their cotemporaries. In America there has been a steady effort during the past ten years to go ahead of the times; to leave the old beaten path and strike out boldly into new regions of sound. Hence, the superiority which, in 1862 was regarded as astonishing, but which was, nevertheless, cordially and generously acknowledged. Mr. DRIGGS stands alone in his department, as a pioneer, He has literally hewn a way for himself. From the commencement, the prospects were new and delightful; but it is only now that he has, as it were settled upon his theories and cultivated them to the point of absolute productiveness. The grand piano, to which we have referred, is an achievement of which he may well feel satisfied. We cannot enter into an explanation of the technical peculiarities of its construction. They are striking to the general perception, and philosophical to the informed mind. The results are a beautiful and extraordinary quality of tone; a power and roundness of sound that we have not heard equalled. When the instrument has been supplied with a better action than the one which it now possesses, it will, we are sure, command the attention of the musical world. We learn with satisfaction that a large and wealty. Corporation has taken the patents in hand, and intend manufacturing pianos on Mr. DRIGGS' principles. Anything that adds to the charm of home is a benefit to the community, and a good piano is one of the happiest means to this end. Mr. DRIGGS has spent a fortune in maturing his plans; we hope he may amass a largor one in their consummation?

abstract: The first cannon-shot fired before Sumter awoke an echo such as has not been heard for centuries. Every man who reflected at a11, knew that that report was the signal for momentous and terrible events. No one who heard of that opening shot, fired almost with...
lead_paragraph: The first cannon-shot fired before Sumter awoke an echo such as has not been heard for centuries. Every man who reflected at a11, knew that that report was the signal for momentous and terrible events. No one who heard of that opening shot, fired almost with levity and bravado, could say where and when the war it inaugurated would end. It is almost equally so with the first rumors which come of the opening clash of arms in the Duchies, and the comparatively petty local struggle there between Germans and Danes. The people and officials of other European States listen almost with trembling anxiety for the news from this contest between 30,000 men on one side and 40,000 on the other.

abstract: A dispatch from Memphis, dated Friday, reasserts the statement that Selma, Ala., is in possession of Gen. SHERMAN. The reports from Gen. SMITH'S cooperating column of cavalry are not favorable. Stragglers say that the rebel forces under FORREST, RHODDY, LEE and ADAMS, have...
lead_paragraph: A dispatch from Memphis, dated Friday, reasserts the statement that Selma, Ala., is in possession of Gen. SHERMAN. The reports from Gen. SMITH's cooperating column of cavalry are not favorable. Stragglers say that the rebel forces under FORREST, RHODDY, LEE and ADAMS, have been concentrated against him, and that at West Point, Miss., a severe battle had been fought, in which SMITH was driven back. SMITH's reverse is attributed to the slow movement of one of the brigades, which delayed the expedition eight days. A report that the entire expedition was slowly falling back toward Memphis was discredited.

abstract: Loochow Surrendered by the Taepings
snippet: Loochow Surrendered by the Taepings
lead_paragraph: The Tae-pings have experienced another great disaster; They have been compelled to surrender Loochow to the Imperialists. The siege of this important stronghold promises to be a marked event in the history of this Chinese rebellion. The stockades, which impeded approach to the city walls, were strongly garrisoned, and obstinately defended, GORDON and his troops being frequenty repulsed from them -- on one occasion with very considerable loss. But at length his perseverance and skill triumphed over all difficulties, and the enemy were successively driven from their positions, and had to take refuge behind the ramparts. The city was now completely beleaguered by the Anglo-Chinese and Mandarin forces, so that it could receive neither succors nor supplies from without. This state of things, coupled with the remembrance of their repeated defeats at the stockades, had such an effect on some of the Taeping chiefs, that a council was held, and it was proposed to give up the contest as hopeless, and abandon Loochow to the besiegers. But MO-WANG, the commandant of the garrison, rejected the idea with scorn, and strenuously insisted that the place should be defended to the last extremity. His opinion and authority, however, only prevailed for a moment. In a few days after, the rebel brave was murdered, and then the chiefs, who had advocated surrender, opened communications with GORDON and the Tuctai, and agreed to give up the city, if their lives and property were guaranteed to them. This condition was assented to by the Imperialist leaders, and immediately they were put in possession of the coveted fortress. The Tuctai had now an excellent opportunity for the display of his magnanimity and good faith, and for giving an instance of Imperialist clemency which would tend to conciliate the Tae-pings. But so far has this unworthy representative of the Brother of the Sun and Moon been from manifesting any of these high qualities, that he has been guilty of a cruelty and perfidity which will inspire the rebels with the courage of despair, and which, if not promptly repudiated and punished by the Government at Pekin, may constrain all Europeans to abandon the Imperialist service, and change once more the fortunes of the war.

abstract: We are informed that the late Government sale of burned vessels at the Gosport Navy-Yard, in Virginia, was well attended, and that the bidding was lively. Wrought scrap iron sold for 2 cents per lb., anchors, 10 cents; chains, 10 cents; boiler plate iron, 8 cents. This was sold to the Government.
lead_paragraph: We are informed that the late Government sale of burned vessels at the Gosport Navy-Yard, in Virginia, was well attended, and that the bidding was lively. Wrought scrap iron sold for 2 1/2 cents per lb., anchors, 10 cents; chains, 10 cents; boiler plate iron, 8 cents. This was sold to the Government. A lot of old guns was sold at 1 1/2 cents per lb. to Mr. BALDWIN, of New-York; a lot of old shells per 1 1/2 cents to Mr. BOWMAN, of Baltimore; old composition for 30 1/2 lead for 7 1/2 and copper for 36 1/2 to Messrs. HOWE & PRESBY, of this city. The burned hull of the sloop-of-war Germantown was bought for $2,900. by Mr. BUCK, of Norfolk. The hull of sloop-of-war Plymouth brought $3,900; the hull of iron-fastened gunboat No. 1, of about 300 tons, with engines and boilers. $520: the hull of copper-fastened gunboat No. 2, of 300 tons, with engines and boilers, $825; a coppered and copper-fastened boat of 70 tons, $525; all sold to R. MCGONIGLE of this city. Considering that the Germantown and Plymouth lie in about eighteen feet of water, and the others in about six feet of water, and that it wil cost about $12,000 to raise them, and get the copper and other material out of them, the above prices were considered high.

abstract: the Military Importance of
snippet: the Military Importance of
lead_paragraph: The rebels certainly have a faculty of turning up where they are not expected; and the late blow they have delivered -- namely, at our force in Florida -- is the most unexpected of all. Everybody agrees that Florida has no strategic value, either to ourselves or the rebels. It is quite removed from the great lines of operation; and as a military possession seems hardly worth while being made a serious bone of contention. But the rebels appear to have discovered in it some kind of value, and that, too, of sufficient moment to have made it worth their while sending a powerful force to oppose and punish the Union expedition that has lately made that peninsula the theatre of its operations. For an adequate explanation of this we are driven to fall back on the consideration of the material value of Florida to the rebels, in the point of view of the question of its supplies of beef cattle, respecting which important developments were lately made.
headline: {'main': 'The Real Military Importance of Florida.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Real Military Importance of Florida.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: WILLIAM GREENWOOD, who was confined in Toronto upon a charge of murder, cheated the hangman by committing suicide on Monday night last. The plan which he adopted to put an end to his awful life was of the most desperate character. The window of the cell in which he was confined is about six and a half feet from the ground, and running along beneath it is the bed. The suicide must have stood upon the bed, have tied the towel to the iron bars, having previously made a noose or a slipknot on the other end of the towel, which he then placed over his head and tightened around his neck. The towel, however, was a long one, and reached from the window to within a foot or two of the floor. In order, therefore, to strangle himself he was compelled to lie down, so that the towel might have the desired effect upon his neck. He seems even, to have clutched the bed in his hands, and have pulled himself with all his strength upon the towel, so that there might not be any chance of his failing to put his awful intention into execution. So lightly was the towel bound around his neck, that the blood flowed or rather burst from his mouth and nose, and flew upon the bed-clothes and floor of the cell. It was certainly an awful death, and shows what a fearfully wicked, depraved and determined man he was.

The towel, however, was a long one, and reached from the window to within a foot or two of the floor. In order, therefore, to strangle himself he was compelled to lie down, so that the towel might have the desired effect upon his neck. He seems even, to have clutched the bed in his hands, and have pulled himself with all his strength upon the towel, so that there might not be any chance of his failing to put his awful intention into execution. So lightly was the towel bound around his neck, that the blood flowed or rather burst from his mouth and nose, and flew upon the bed-clothes and floor of the cell. It was certainly an awful death, and shows what a fearfully wicked, depraved and determined man he was.

abstract: Liverpool Post on the Alabama Case, and who is to pay for damages by
snippet: Liverpool Post on the Alabama Case, and who is to pay for damages by
lead_paragraph: -- The article from the Liverpool Post referred to in our foreign news by the Africa, is a noticeable one. It is headed, "Who is to Pay?" -- a question of interest always. It begins by stating the estimated value of the eighty vessels and cargoes destroyed by the Alabama, the Florida, and the Georgia at £3,000,000, and mentions the intimation of our Government that England would be called on to pay the damages. It there shows that on an intimation from our Government that war would follow the sailing of the rams, orders were given by the English Government to stop them, which orders were based on no further testimony as to those vessels, than had been presented to the Government by Mr. ADAMS two months before, and on which they had steadily refused to act up till this intimation of Mr. ADAMS that letting them go was war, and would be considered as such.

abstract: ings which has been erected by the trustees, to whom the disposal of Mr. PEABODY's munificent gift to the City of London was referred wilt be ready for occupation in the course of the present month. The building, which has c cost £22,000 is situated at Bethnal Green. The number of applications for rooms far exceeded those to be disposed of, and some difficulty has been experienced in making a selection of the occupants. There is every expectation that the speculation will be most successful, as the building has been formed with the view of affording the utmost accommodation to the occupants Rooms have been constructed of the dimensions of 12 feet by 15 feet 6 inches -- a sufficient size for a small family. There are rooms of a smaller size, and some for single men. '1 here are also shops on the basement floor with suites of rooms adjoining, and winch, it is believed can be let at a rental of about £60 a year. The domestic comforts of the inmates have been carefully studied. There are separate lavatories for the men and for the women and children, a plentiful supply of water, and excellent ventilation. The remark is made, however, that the rent which will be charged for the rooms (which will be from 2s to 3s. and 5s. a week) will be above the means of the poor for whom Mr. PEABODY mainly intended his gift. -- From the London Star, Feb. 3.

lead_paragraph: To the long list of States whose Legislatures or Union Conventions have declared ABRAHAM LINCOLN the first choice of the people for next President, Indiana and Iowa are now to be added. abstract: For some time past complaint has been made that considerable of the City property was unproductive, and Comptroller BRENNAN has unfairly been held responsible for the fault. The difficulty was in not having authority to lease the
lead_paragraph: For some time past complaint has been made that considerable of the City property was unproductive, and Comptroller BRENNAN has unfairly been held responsible for the fault. The difficulty was in not having authority to lease the unproductive and poorly productive property to advantage, the charter restricting the Comptroller to one-year terms, unless by an order of the Common Council, when, if no limit of time were fixed, the terms could be extended for any period not exceeding ten years. Only last Thursday the necessary resolution to effect the object of making leases profitable to the Corporation was concurred in by the Board of Councilmen, and already it has received the Mayor's approval, and lists of unleased property are advertised for lease at five and ten-year terms on Monday and Tuesday, March 28 and 29. The lists, includes over a dozen brick buildings; the hotel at the foot of Eighty-sixth-street, East River; the Houstonstreet Ferry to Brooklyn; the Twenty-third-street Ferry to Greenpoint; the Grand-street Ferry to Williamsburgh; the ferry from the foot of Chambers-street to Hoboken, and the Christopher-street Ferry to Hoboken.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Asia at this port yesterday morning, we have two days later news from Europe. The English Parliament had discussed, on the 11th of February, the correspondence between Mr. SEWARD and Earl RUSSELL, and the Earl of Derby had demanded that the papers relative to all the vessels which had been seized on supposition that they were for the rebels, be laid before the House, which Earl RUSSELL declined to do. The opposition then attacked the Government very strongly, and charged the Cabinet with submitting to humiliation and insult in its management of American affairs. The rumors of an armistice to the belligerents in Schleswig had assumed official shape, and it was said the proposal came from England, seconded by France, Russia and Sweden. The terms were the evacuation of Schleswig by the Danes, with the exception of the Island of Alsen. A rumor prevailed that Prussia had rejected the proposal. There was no additional fighting reported. Reinforcements continue to be sent forward to the allied army. MAZZINI had been indicted in Paris as an accomplice in the plot to assassinate the Emperor. The Queen of Spain had been safely delivered of a daughter.

abstract: VAN AMBURGH & CO.'s MENAGERIE. -- This meritorious exhibition, located at Nos. 539 and 541 Broadway, was crowded to excess on Saturday by the juveniles, and it is not in the least strange that the great lion-tamer should be patronized extensively when we take into consideration that an exhibition of such magnitude, established by private enterprise, does not exist on either side of the Atlantic. Every inhabitable portion of the world is here represented by some animal or bird, several of which we have never before seen in a menagerie. In our juvenile days, the old Zoological Institute, located in the Bowery, was a favorite with us, where, if our memory serves as right, VAN AMBURGH first entered the dens of wild animals, and astonished the world by his bold and daring performances, exercising a complete control over the lions and other animals, which he had subjected to his will. The imitators of VAN AMBURGH, however, have not been so successful, and several instances have occurred in which persons have forfeited their lives by their temerity.
